headline: Hashish Seized in Soviet
abstract: LEAD: Five tons of hashish worth $120 million have been seized in a joint Soviet-Canadian operation, the official Tass news agency said today. The agency said the hashish had been smuggled into the Soviet Union from Pakistan and was bound for Canada.

headline: Investor Would Expand From Realty to Rails
abstract: LEAD: Howard Kaskel's recent disclosure that he held an interest in Kansas City Southern Industries has taken many in the railroad industry by surprise. After all, the New York investor is best known for running a real estate empire that his father, the late Alfred Kaskel, began building in the 1930's.

headline: No-Contest Plea Made By Posner
abstract: LEAD: Victor Posner pleaded no contest today to charges of evading more than $1.2 million in Federal income taxes by inflating the value of land donated to a Miami Bible college.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 12, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  International

headline: BID FOR HEILMAN SPURS STOCK
abstract: LEAD: A group led by the Australian investor Alan Bond today offered $38 a share for the G. Heileman Brewing Company, the nation's fourth-largest brewer.

headline: GERMAN? YES, AND A TOUCH OF RUSSIAN
abstract: LEAD: As a child in distant Soviet Central Asia, Larissa Grams was allowed to speak only German at home - more precisely, the Schwabisch dialect her forebears took to Russia two centuries earlier.

headline: Judge Upholds Special Prosecutor's Role on North
abstract: LEAD: A Federal judge today upheld the authority of a special prosecutor to investigate the Iran-contra affair and to enforce a grand jury subpoena against Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North. The judge, Aubrey E. Robinson Jr. of Federal District Court in Washington, ruled that the Justice Department had acted properly in granting a special backup appointment to the special prosecutor, Lawrence E.

headline: Danger in the Gulf: How U.S. Navy Girds for Escort Duties With Tankers
abstract: LEAD: When the first Kuwaiti tankers to fly the American flag pass through the Strait of Hormuz, probably in the next several days, they will be escorted by American warships assigned to see them safely past an avowedly hostile Iran.

headline: ITT and United Technologies Profits Up Sharply
abstract: LEAD: Two prominent conglomerates yesterday reported sharply higher profits in the most recent quarter. The ITT Corporation's net income soared 65 percent, while the United Technologies Corporation's net earnings more than doubled from last year, when the company took a large charge against earnings.

headline: Advertising; Nissan Winner Due
abstract: LEAD: The two agencies in the finals for the $150 million Nissan Motor Corporation U.S.A. account expect to learn of the winner on Friday. Tatham-Laird & Kudner, Chicago, is presenting on Wednesday, and Chiat/Day, Los Angeles, on Thursday. The previous agency was the William Esty Company.

headline: Jacobs Stake In Allegheny
abstract: LEAD: Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor, said yesterday that he owned about 900,000 shares of Allegheny International, or about 9 percent of the financially troubled company that makes Sunbeam, Oster and Mixmaster appliances.

headline: Administration Stands Firm On ABM-Pact Interpretation
abstract: LEAD: The Reagan Administration today said that it would not back away from its broad interpretation of the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty despite a recent warning from the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

headline: Connally Plan After Filing
abstract: LEAD: John B. Connally, the former Treasury Secretary and three-term Governor of Texas who filed for bankruptcy on Friday, said he might return to legal work or assisting others wanting to ''put deals together.''

headline: Sprinkel Says He's Resigning
abstract: LEAD: Beryl W. Sprinkel confirmed today that he planned to resign in late November as chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers.

headline: SOVIET HAS PRAISE ON WEAPONS TALKS
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A Shevardnadze, told the United Nations General Assembly today that the emerging nuclear missile pact between the Soviet Union and the United States means ''the idea of nuclear disarmament is close to the beginning of its fulfillment.''

headline: Canada Tornado Death Toll 27; Search Goes On
abstract: LEAD: Hundreds of rescue workers dug through mounds of twisted rubble at a trailer park and an industrial area today that had been devastated by tornadoes that killed at least 27 people and injured more than 200.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Alberto-Culver Co., Melrose Park, Ill., a maker of beauty and hair products, said it had begun seeking consents from Lamaur Inc. shareholders for a special shareholders meeting in order to remove Lamaur's board and elect its own nominees.

headline: Advertising; Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Panni Products, a maker of potato dumpling mix and potato pancake mix, to Franznick & Cusatis

headline: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 6, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL/3-25

headline: Financial Firm In Britain Sold
abstract: LEAD: British and Commonwealth Holdings P.L.C., with interests in transport, hotels and finance, said today that it was buying Mercantile House Holdings for $:490 million, or $800 million.

headline: Nominee Airs Views on Debt
abstract: LEAD: David S. Ruder, the White House nominee for chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, told Congress today that he was not overly concerned about the level of debt building up on the balance sheets of American corporations.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN THE NEW-PARENT BUSINESS; A Little Bundle - of Coupons
abstract: LEAD: SOON after Karen LaBarbera of Brooklyn gave birth to her third child at Beth Israel Hospital recently, she was handed another bundle -a plastic-wrapped packet that included diapers, a magazine for new parents and coupons good toward the purchase of infant products made by a variety of manufacturers.

headline: Rock-a-Bye Baby
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Drop in Jews Leaving Soviet
abstract: LEAD: A State Department spokesman expressed concern today that the recent level of Jewish emigration from the Soviet Union had declined to 796 in June, from 871 in May. Charles E. Redman, the Department spokesman, said Jewish emmigration had increased in each previous month this year.

headline: Asarco to Sell M.I.M. Shares
abstract: LEAD: Asarco Inc., a leading producer of silver, copper and zinc, said Friday that it would sell 155.6 million common shares of M.I.M. Holdings Ltd., an Australian mining company, in an international offering.

headline: Drexel Hired By Publisher
abstract: LEAD: American City Business Journals said yesterday that it had retained Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. as its investment banker because it had received several unsolicited inquiries about a sale of the company.

headline: Guatemala Chief Asks Support for Peace Pact
abstract: LEAD: President Vinicio Cerezo of Guatemala, addressing the General Assembly, appealed today to the United States and other countries to ''respect'' the wishes of Central American leaders and support the peace accord signed in Guatemala last month.

headline: NATO Is Seeking a New Secretary General
abstract: LEAD: Lord Carrington, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, is making plans to retire, and the alliance has begun the search for a new leader, according to Western diplomats.

headline: Fannie Mae Using Realty Conduit
abstract: LEAD: The Federal National Mortgage Association's first issue of conventional mortgage securities through a real estate mortgage investment conduit, or Remic, is expected this week through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.

headline: SOVIET CONFIRMS NEW MISSILE BUT DENIES VIOLATION
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union said today that it was deploying a new intercontinental ballistic missile but denied that the missile violated the second strategic arms limitation treaty, signed in 1979.

headline: A PLETHORA OF PROPOSALS
abstract: LEAD:  Following are the major Central America peace plans:  Contadora Group

headline: Reagan and Nakasone Meet Today
abstract: LEAD: Japanese Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, in the United States to deliver a speech to the United Nations General Assembly, will meet with President Reagan in New York Monday to discuss a wide range of issues, including Japanese concerns about trade legislation pending in Congress.

headline: Alfonsin's New Drive On Debt
abstract: LEAD: President Raul Alfonsin of Argentina, responding to his party's defeat in midterm elections last Sunday, has announced plans for a new diplomatic offensive aimed at reducing the social and economic burdens of servicing the country's $53 billion foreign debt.

headline: TWO MISSILES MISS
abstract: LEAD: A United States Navy fighter plane fired two missiles at an Iranian plane above the Persian Gulf over the weekend, but the Iranian aircraft was not hit, Reagan Administration officials said tonight.

headline: Seoul Is Urged To Bolster Won
abstract: LEAD: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d has urged the South Korean Government to accelerate the revaluation of the won against the dollar, the news agency Yonhap reported on Saturday.

headline: Anti-Military Protests Continue in Panama
abstract: LEAD: Hundreds of people demonstrated against the military-dominated Government here today, and armed men set fire to a building owned by the publishers of the opposition newspaper La Prensa while riot police watched.

headline: Stride Rite Picks President
abstract: LEAD: The Stride Rite Corporation, which makes children's shoes, has elected Michael W. Rayden president and chief operating officer, effective next Monday.

headline: 2 Ousted In Japan on Soviet Case
abstract: LEAD: Two executives of a Japanese aircraft instrument company resigned after a subordinate was accused of selling information to Soviet officials, a company spokesman said today.

headline: Questions for the Admiral
abstract: LEAD: Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter will be questioned on a host of documents and testimony by others, including Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North. These are among the questions he is most likely to be asked:

headline: Iranian Vessels Said to Fire on Chemical Tanker
abstract: LEAD: Two Iranian patrol boats fired at a Liberian-registered chemical tanker today just outside the Persian Gulf, smashing a porthole with a bullet, shipping officials reported.

headline: Iraqi Warplanes Raid Iranian Tankers
abstract: LEAD: Iraqi warplanes made a series of bombing runs over Iranian oil tankers today as Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger finished a tour of the Persian Gulf.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: LEAD: The British Petroleum Company said yesterday that it planned to raise $:1.5 billion ($2.4 billion) by the sale of new stock. It will use the proceeds to reduce its debt.

headline: Walsh Considers Reagan Session
abstract: LEAD: The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair is considering a proposal to interview President Reagan as part of the criminal investigation, a Government official with knowledge of the inquiry said today.

headline: Loss at Toronto Bank
abstract: LEAD: Toronto Dominion Bank has reported a third-quarter loss of $325.2 million (Canadian), or $247.1 million (American), primarily because of a large increase in reserves for possible losses on loans to third world countries. However, the bank, Canada's fifth largest ranked by assets, said it expected to report a profit for the fiscal year ended Oct.

headline: Witness Is Principal Target Of Grand Jury Investigation
abstract: LEAD: Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter's lawyer said today that his client had been named the ''primary target'' of a Federal grand jury investigating the Iran-contra affair and that there was an ''imminent threat of prosecution.''

headline: Submarines for Sale: Run Silent, Run Cheap
abstract: LEAD: Looking for a used submarine? So are hundreds of other people.

headline: Market Place
abstract: LEAD: WEAKNESS in the dollar has forced interest rates higher, stirred fears of renewed inflation and, periodically, rattled both the stock and bond markets in the United States.

headline: Chief Sees Growth For Hospital Corp.
abstract: LEAD: Thomas F. Frist Jr. says he is excited about the future. The co-founder of the Hospital Corporation of America, one of the great growth companies until the Government changed the Medicare rules in 1983, believes the health-care provider is ready to grow again.

abstract: LEAD: Victor Posner pleaded no contest today to charges of evading more than $1.2 million in Federal income taxes by inflating the value of land donated to a Miami Bible college.

headline: CHILEAN ARMS MAKER HELPS FILL A WORLD DEMAND
abstract: LEAD: The Iran-Iraq war and Washington's prohibition on arms sales to Chile have combined to help what was once a small explosives company become a significant manufacturer and exporter of armaments.

headline: Mid-September Car Sales Fell 36.2%
abstract: LEAD: Mid-September sales of American-made passenger vehicles were down 36.2 percent on a daily rate basis from the comparable period last year, the seven domestic manufacturers reported today.

headline: Advertising; International Economy Magazine Debut Is Set
abstract: LEAD: David M. Smick, 33, and Richard H. Medley, 35, partners in Smick & Medley & Associates, Washington-based economic consultants, are now additionally co-publishers of The International Economy magazine, which will be published six times a year, It will be what they consider to be a much needed ''written forum for the international policy debate.

headline: The Book Clubs, Chapter 2
abstract: LEAD: THE first suggestion of a sultry New York summer was already in the air when he arrived from Lisbon. But the youthful, elegantly dressed executive did not seem to notice. His mind was on other things: The takeover was complete; the family dynasty that had controlled the publishing empire for years had bowed out.

headline: Nutrasweet Faces A Senate Hearing
abstract: LEAD: Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, said he would hold a hearing in September on health concerns about aspartame, the popular artificial sweetener marketed under the brand name Nutrasweet by the Monsanto Company. The hearing will be held by the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, which has jurisdiction over the Food and Drug

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: LEAD:  Western Growth

headline: Getting the Rhino Into the Computer
abstract: LEAD: IS the gorilla in Seattle related to the one in San Antonio?

headline: Witness for Demjanjuk Is Said to Try Suicide
abstract: LEAD: A psychologist from Texas tried to commit suicide last night after retracting her defense evidence at the trial of John Demjanjuk, who is accused of being a Nazi war criminal, the Israeli police saido=oday.

headline: At Philippine Academy, Cadets Say They're Loyal
abstract: LEAD: Cadet Leo Leuterio, whose T-shirt says ''Courage, Integrity, Loyalty'' -the motto of the Philippine Military Academy - admits there has been confusion and some sleepless nights on the campus since the coup attempt last week against President Corazon C. Aquino.

headline: KENNER TAKES PROPOSAL OF $51 A SHARE BY TONKA
abstract: LEAD: Kenner Parker Toys Inc., appearing to defeat a hostile takeover offer, said today that it would be acquired in a friendly $612 million deal by a smaller rival, the Tonka Corporation.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, AUGUST 20, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  Markets

headline: Band's Quest For Stardom
abstract: LEAD: By 7:45 P.M. Madison Square Garden was filling with young, excited rock-and-rollers. A good omen, thought Steve Mountain, manager of the opening act, the Hooters, as he looked at the 18,500 seats.

headline: REAGAN DENIES 'PLOY' ON IRAN HEARING
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan, responding indirectly to the Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair, said today that he was not seeking to divert attention from the inquiry by focusing on other issues.

headline: Chad Reports Expelling Last Libyan Troops
abstract: LEAD: The Chad radio said today that Chadian troops had swept all remaining Libyan troops from Chadian territory and reconquered the Aouzou Strip, the northernmost area of the country.

headline: Hyundai Officials Assess Dispute
abstract: LEAD: The Hyundai Motor Company of South Korea said recent labor disputes in South Korea cost the company about 20,000 sales it could have made this year. But officials said Hyundai still expected to sell 300,000 cars in the United States in 1988, compared with about 250,000 in 1987.

headline: Shultz and Others on the Iran Deal
abstract: LEAD:  Nov. 16, 1986: ''My own information about the operational aspects of what was going on was fragmentary at best.''  - Secretary of State George P. Shultz  Nov. 17: ''There is a lot of what transpired that I don't know about.''  - Mr. Shultz  Nov. 20: ''It was not kept from the Secretary of State.

headline: TOP REAGAN AIDES PUSH GULF POLICY
abstract: LEAD: Top Reagan Administration officials, seeking to overwhelm Congressional opposition to President Reagan's Persian Gulf policy, acknowledged the risk in escorting Kuwaiti vessels today, but argued that it is far more risky to do nothing.

headline: IRANIAN OFFICIALS URGE 'UPROOTING' OF SAUDI ROYALTY
abstract: LEAD: Iran, vowing to avenge the deaths of hundreds of Iranian pilgrims in a riot in Mecca, called today for the ''uprooting'' of the Saudi Arabian royal family, raising the specter of religious war in the already tense Persian Gulf region.

headline: Fireman's Fund To Buy Its Stock
abstract: LEAD: The Fireman's Fund Corporation, a major insurance company based in Novato, Calif., said that its board has authorized the repurchase of up to six million shares, or about 9.5 percent of its outstanding common stock. In December, the board had authorized the repurchase of 5 percent of common shares, nearly all of which have been purchased.

headline: Dollar Rises in Tokyo
abstract: LEAD: The dollar opened at 143.50 yen on the Tokyo foreign exchange market today, up from Friday's close of 142.53.

headline: PANAMA MILITARY ARRESTS KEY CRITIC IN NEW CRACKDOWN
abstract: LEAD: Attacking with guns and tear gas, security forces in Panama arrested a leading critic of the military leader today, hours after the main opposition newspaper was shut down and all radio and television stations put under censorship.

headline: OIL PRICE RISE EXPECTED
abstract: LEAD: The price of oil in the futures market is expected to rise sharply this week on fears that Iran will retaliate against Kuwait or Saudi Arabia for last week's violence in Mecca, and that such confrontations will limit the flow of crude supplies from the Middle East.

headline: U.S. Strategy On Gulf War
abstract: LEAD: The growing American entanglement in the Iran-Iraq war appears to be diminishing the maneuverability of the United States and enhancing the diplomatic role of the Soviet Union.

headline: Delta Offers Refunds on Safety Issue
abstract: LEAD: Delta Air Lines said today that it would offer refunds, even on restricted-fare tickets, to anyone concerned about flying the airline after its recent mishaps.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN GREETING CARDS
abstract: LEAD: IN the old days, people flocked to the card shop for birthdays, anniversaries, Christmas and Mother's Day, and a few big companies produced all the good cheer. Today more than 800 publishers vie for business in a $3.6 billion-a-year industry - and the noteworthy event might be a divorce or a promotion, the death of a dog or an unhappy 40th birthday.

headline: Third World Countries Issue Warning on Debt Payments
abstract: LEAD: Representatives of third world governments warned today that more of them may suspend or limit payments on their external debt.

headline: Sharon, Replying to Critics, Opens Lebanon War Scars
abstract: LEAD: Just as the five-year-old scars from Israel's invasion of Lebanon were starting to heal and just as the bitter memories were beginning to fade, Ariel Sharon has revived the wrenching debate here over who was responsible for Israel's most controversial war.

headline: The U.N. Today: Sept. 25, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  GENERAL ASSEMBLY

headline: Mecca Tragedy: Chain of Events Begins to Emerge
abstract: LEAD: Nearly six weeks after riots in the Moslem holy city of Mecca that left more than 400 people dead, a more detailed picture is beginning to emerge of what led to the violence.

headline: Chapter 11 Filing
abstract: LEAD: American Healthcare Management Inc. said that it had filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. The hospital company said last week that it would take the action if it did not reach an agreement with its banks on rescheduling repayment of $233 million or at least extending the deadline for repayment, which was last Friday.

headline: Rival Warns Murdoch
abstract: LEAD: Robert Maxwell, the British publisher, warned Rupert Murdoch today that he would not get ''a free ride'' if he tried to take over Pearson P.L.C., a publishing group that includes The Financial Times.

headline: Nekoosa Chief Busy With New Strategy
abstract: LEAD: William R. Laidig, chairman and chief executive of the Great Northern Nekoosa Paper Company, says he has a lot of woodworking machinery in his basement that he doesn't get much of a chance to use.

headline: HOPE IS SCANT BASQUE TALKS WILL SUCCEED
abstract: LEAD: Despite a recent disclosure that the Government and Basque radicals have entered into negotiations, there is little optimism that the 19-year terrorist campaign for Basque autonomy is about to end.

headline: Merrill's Stake in Building Sold Back to Olympia
abstract: LEAD: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it would report a one-time $100 million gain from a complex financial transaction in which it sold back to Olympia & York the right to acquire a 49 percent interest in one of Merrill's new headquarters buildings in lower Manhattan.

headline: U.S. Fears Soviet Use of New Nicaraguan Airfield
abstract: LEAD: Administration officials say the Nicaraguan Government has almost completed work on the longest airfield in Central America, which they fear the Soviet Union might use to extend its reconnaisance missions in this hemisphere.

headline: Pritzkers Add Sugar Refiner
abstract: LEAD: Chicago's Pritzker family agreed today to buy an 11.25 percent stake in the British sugar refiner S. and W. Berisford P.L.C. for about $120 million.

headline: 41 French-Speaking Nations Confer
abstract: LEAD: The leaders of 41 French-speaking nations and territories began a summit meeting here today to the accompaniment of angry human-rights demonstrations.

headline: In 3 Countries, a Tangle of Election Campaigning; Denmark: Ex-Prime Minister Enlivens Dull Campaign
abstract: LEAD: Denmark is approaching the end of a general election campaign that the candidates, the pollsters, the press and even the incumbent Prime Minister, Poul Schluter, pronounced extraordinary for its dullness.

headline: Dow Moves Upward by 19.93 Points
abstract: LEAD: After a two-day pullback, the stock market did a sharp about-face yesterday and for a time was again flirting with record highs.

headline: Abrams Denies Wrongdoing In Shipping Arms to Contras
abstract: LEAD: Assistant Secretary of State Elliott Abrams has defended his role in authorizing the shipment of weapons on a humanitarian aid flight to Nicaraguan rebels, saying the operation was ''strictly by the book.''

headline: Monoclonal Settles Lawsuit
abstract: LEAD: Monoclonal Antibodies Inc. said that it had settled a patent infringement suit filed against it in 1984 by Hybritech Inc. The settlement came after a

headline: Advertising; Publisher Is Named For Cosmopolitan
abstract: LEAD: Seth Hoyt, 44, who while at Rolling Stone helped D. Claeys Bahrenburg start Outside magazine, is now following Mr. Bahrenburg as publisher of Hearst's Cosmopolitan magazine.

headline: Gunmen Kill Peter Tosh, Reggae Star, in Jamaica
abstract: LEAD: Peter Tosh, a founding member of the Wailers, a reggae group that helped to popularize the vibrant Jamaican music style internationally, was killed at his home Friday night by gunmen, the police said. Mr. Tosh was 42 years old.

headline: Advertising; Calet, Hirsch & Spector Gets Rorer Assignment
abstract: LEAD: Calet, Hirsch & Spector/New York has been assigned Myoflex analgesic cream by Rorer Consumer Pharmaceuticals. No budget has been set yet, but last year's spending was on the $2 million level.

headline: U.S. Seeking Coffee Accord
abstract: LEAD: In an effort to resolve differences between coffee-consuming nations and producers, the United States is ready to seek a compromise with Brazil and other producers to regulate the coffee trade, the chief United States negotiator, Jon Rosenbaum, said today.

headline: Machine Tool Orders Fell 12.7% in August
abstract: LEAD: New orders for American-made machine tools dropped 12.7 percent in August from the previous month's level, according to a report to be released today by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association.

headline: Bombs Hurled in Sri Lanka Assembly
abstract: LEAD: Three bombs were hurled into a meeting of leaders of the governing party in Parliament today, wounding four ministers and 10 legislators shortly before they were to begin discussing a new peace accord with Tamil separatists, a senior official said.

headline: SCHOLAR LOSES HER WAY IN BRITAIN'S 'NEW PUNJAP'
abstract: LEAD: The scholar seems more street-smart than bookish as she barges in with all the trust of kith and kin on the humble homes of what she calls New Punjab in Old England, speaking Urdu and checking on the children, the health, the love lives of the families who are the stuff of her scholarship.

headline: A SEABROOK OWNER SETS BOND SWAP
abstract: LEAD: Financially drained by a $2 billion investment in the dormant Seabrook nuclear power plant, the Public Service Company of New Hampshire gave details today of a capital restructuring plan aimed at reducing the company's cash interest payments by $143 million a year.

headline: 2 FOR THE SEESAW THAT PASSES FOR TURKISH POLITICS
abstract: LEAD: In Turkey's great cycles of democracy and its suspension, two men who once wielded power, and who sparred as chaos seized their land, are waiting a recall to political life that may never come.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: LEAD:  Ripe for Restructuring

headline: Phillips-Van Heusen Rejects Rosewood Offer
abstract: LEAD: The board of the Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation today rejected as inadequate a merger offer for $22 a share, or a total of $333 million, from Rosewood Financial Inc.

headline: Trade Deficit Sets a Record
abstract: LEAD: The deficit in the United States current account, the broadest measure of the nation's international trade, widened to a record $41.1 billion in the April-June quarter, the Government said today.

headline: Bush, on Europe Tour, Stresses Allies' Resolve
abstract: LEAD: Vice President Bush began a tour of West European capitals and Poland today by citing allied resolve as a key factor in Moscow's willingness to conclude a treaty eliminating medium- and shorter-range nuclear missiles.

headline: Managua Journal; For the Sandinista Nine, It's No Time to Strike Out
abstract: LEAD: Twenty highly trained young Nicaraguans went off to battle this week, bearing the weight of national honor on their broad shoulders.

headline: A Loss at American Express
abstract: LEAD: The American Express Company said yesterday that it lost $47.9 million in the second quarter, a performance that largely reflected a $600 million addition to its banking unit's reserves against troubled Latin American loans.

headline: Congress Cool to Japanese
abstract: LEAD: Japan's trade minister got a frosty reception on Capitol Hill today as he sought to repair political damage caused by the Toshiba Machine Company's illegal sale of sensitive technology to the Soviet Union.

headline: Gandhi Ousts 3 Rebels From Governing Party
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi ousted three prominent rebels from the governing Congress Party today. They included a cousin who was once a powerful aide.

headline: Bolivians Fight Efforts to Eradicate Coca
abstract: LEAD: Joint Bolivian and American efforts to combat cocaine exports have run into strong opposition in recent weeks from organized peasant growers of coca, the raw material of the drug.

headline: Regan Takes the Stand, Looking Mellow and Quite at Ease
abstract: LEAD: Donald T. Regan, with the mellow smile of a Washington survivor, got a little of his own back today.

headline: AT ENGLAND'S 'GLORIOUS INDULGENCE,' IT'S ONLY SHEEP WHO ARE INDIFFERENT
abstract: LEAD: ''Picnics is all right for the small town suckers, but we're used to the high life, you know,'' Sportin' Life sang this evening, prophesying the sunset tableaux that followed a short while later out on the pastoral grounds of the Glyndebourne opera estate as the privileged bearers of the single most coveted ticket of the

headline: Poindexter Questioned on Conflicts With North's Testimony
abstract: LEAD: Senator George J. Mitchell, a Maine Democrat, questioned Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter yesterday over the admiral's testimony and that of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North. Following are excerpts of that exchange:

headline: VISITORS FIND A RESTRAINT IN IRAN DESPITE MECCA RIOT AND GULF WAR
abstract: LEAD: After several days of mourning and protest earlier this month over Iranian-Saudi violence in Mecca, this city has returned to relative calm - a possible indication that Iran's leaders have decided to let the issue cool.

headline: Casey Planned to Write Memoirs
abstract: LEAD: Shortly before William J. Casey was hospitalized last December, his literary agent circulated a proposal for a book of memoirs.

headline: Scotch Account Given to Grace
abstract: LEAD: Obviously pleased with the fresh and smart advertising Grace & Rothschild has recently been supplying for its J & B Scotch, the Paddington Corporation has now assigned the agency its Knockando single-malt Scotch. As a category, single malt and imported vodka are the only distilled spirits exhibiting growth.

headline: Market Place; Oil Stocks Retain Appeal
abstract: LEAD: AFTER enjoying a bull market for nearly a year, oil stocks still draw favorable recommendations on Wall Street. Spurred initially by rising crude oil prices, the run-up has reflected corporate restructurings and, more recently, heightened tensions in the Middle East.

headline: New Curb Seen On East Bloc
abstract: LEAD: Top officials of Cocom, the Western trade body, have made progress in tightening controls on sensitive exports to Warsaw Pact nations after a two-day meeting here, Cocom sources said today.

headline: Burger King Soda Deal
abstract: LEAD: The Burger King Corporation will disclose today whether Coke or Pepsi will be served in its outlets starting next year. Pepsi is expected to win. Pepsi-Cola, a unit of Pepsico Inc., has been supplying soft drinks to Burger King since 1983. Before that, Burger King served Coca-Cola Company products.

headline: Nicaraguans and the Winds of Peace
abstract: LEAD: A month after the signing of a Central American peace accord, Nicaragua is gripped by a mood of expectation unseen since the Sandinistas swept into power eight years ago.

headline: Merck Net Is Up 35.7%
abstract: LEAD: Merck & Company said today that second-quarter net income rose 35.7 percent, exceeding analysts' expectations. The company earned $235.1 million, or $1.72 a share, up from $173.2 million, or $1.23 a share, a year ago. Sales rose 23.8 percent, to $1.25 billion, from $1.01 billion.

headline: Santo Domingo Journal; Old Hand Shows His Magic, Juggling $600 Million
abstract: LEAD: Joaquin Balaguer is a few weeks away from his 80th birthday and virtually blind. But he is proving to be a dynamic President of this Caribbean country, fighting waste and corruption, directing a huge public works program and taxing the stamina of aides half his age.

headline: Bobby Seale and the Pigs, 1980's Style
abstract: LEAD: BOBBY SEALE has plans. Big plans. ''I want to become the barbecue kingpin of America,'' said the legendary co-founder of the Black Panther party, the symbol of revolution and the radical left for millions of Americans in the 1960's.

headline: Tatars to Meet Gromyko Today Over Homeland
abstract: LEAD: Crimean Tatars who staged an extraordinary 24-hour demonstration at the gates of the Kremlin this weekend will meet Monday with President Andrei A. Gromyko, one of their leaders said today.

headline: Iranian, in U.N., Rebuffs Reagan On Cease-Fire
abstract: LEAD: President Ali Khamenei of Iran rebuffed President Reagan today by failing to accept the United Nations Security Council's call for a cease-fire in the war against Iraq.

headline: Getting Intimacy and Passion Past the Censors
abstract: LEAD: IT is a steamy evening. A woman in strapless dress reclines on a sofa, as a man enters the room and rushes to her side. The seduction that follows begins with an ice cube: He runs it over her face and neck - then moves it lower. This is an ''An Intimate Evening, '' Revlon's new television commercial for its fragrance,

headline: Saatchi to List On Big Board
abstract: LEAD: Britain's Saatchi & Saatchi Company, whose growth to No. 1 in worldwide advertising circles was fueled by its ability to raise money through the sale of stock, has been cleared to apply for listing on the New York Stock Exchange, Saatchi announced yesterday.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Aegon N.V. is issuing 13.66 billion yen of 8 1/8 percent dual currency bonds due 1992 at 101 5/8 through Nikko Securities Co. (Europe). While interest is payable in New Zealand dollars, the bonds are redeemable 80 percent in yen and 20 percent in New Zealand dollars.

headline: Taiwan Gets News of China At First Hand
abstract: LEAD: For the last two weeks, a newspaper here has been publishing accounts of a neighboring land where people look familiar but live in different, and sad, circumstances.

headline: Aide Denies Shultz Tie to South Africa Contra Aid
abstract: LEAD: The State Department denied today that Secretary of State George P. Shultz had supported a proposal in 1984 to obtain aid from South Africa for the rebels in Nicragua.

headline: B.F. Goodrich Lifts Profit 61%
abstract: LEAD: The B. F. Goodrich Company reported a 61 percent increase in its second-quarter earnings, bolstered by gains in its core chemical, aerospace and defense units. Net income totaled $38.3 million, or $1.54 a share, up from $23.8 million, or $1.02 a share, a year before.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: LEAD: ''Although I was convinced that we could properly do it and that the President would approve it if asked, I made a very deliberate decision not to ask the President so that I could insulate him from the decision and provide some future deniability for the President if it ever leaked out.''

headline: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
abstract: LEAD: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization       $      Aug. 14   Aug. 7   Aug. 15        1987   1987   1986       Gasoline production, daily   7.2   6.7   6.9        Distillate production, daily   2.6   2.7   2.9        Gasoline stocks   227.2   228.9   213.6        Distillate stocks   119.4   115.1   120.7        Crude imports, daily   5.7   5.1   4.7        Product imports, daily   2.3   2.1   2.0        Crude stocks   324.3   323.2   333.1        Crude production, daily   8.2   8.2   8.4        Refinery utilization (%)   87.0   85.7   85.0

headline: Strategic Metals Stoke the Boiler Rooms
abstract: LEAD: THE rumblings out of Africa about possible supply interruptions of strategic metals - the likes of chromium, cobalt and platinum upon which Western nations depend for industry and military uses - may raise the pulses of sophisticated traders in London, at least for an afternoon. But in the United States, the rumors have set phone lines ringing as high-pressure salesmen offer their wares - options, futures contracts, and variations on those instruments - to gullible investors.

headline: Rainier's Chief Resigns Posts
abstract: LEAD: G. Robert Truex Jr. has resigned as chairman and chief executive of the Rainier Bancorporation. The company's president, John D. Mangels, will take over those posts, while Jon Christoffersen, president of the Rainier Bank subsidiary, will become president of the holding company as well.

headline: Austere Plan For Argentina
abstract: LEAD: The Government announced tough new economic measures today, including price increases and the sale of eight state companies, to repair what it called ''decades of economic damage.''

headline: India's Drought Is Worst in Decades
abstract: LEAD: Dawn broke in these parched farmlands today with gray clouds, raising a few hopes of rain. But by midmorning the sun was ablaze, once again burning farmers' hopes of relief from India's driest rainy season in decades.

headline: Timex Watch to Fallon
abstract: LEAD: Fallon McElligott of Minneapolis has won the $10 million Timex watch account, which Grey Advertising had resigned earlier this year. It will also be handling new product introductions. Timex made the selection after reviewing more than 100 agencies.

headline: India Shoes Gaining In the West
abstract: LEAD: The way Ajit Kumar Sen, a senior Government official, tells it, when India began exporting shoes to the Soviet Union in the 1950's, neither side insisted on high standards of workmanship.

headline: Hollywood Intrigue About Paper's Fate
abstract: LEAD: The Hollywood Reporter, a leading Hollywood trade publication, appears to be up for sale, media industry executives say. Several sources said they had been approached by a Los Angeles media broker, Norton J. Lehman, who recently handled the sales of both Broadcasting, a trade maagazine, and Variety, the trade paper, about a possible sale.

headline: Buying Wave in Japan Helps Dollar to Soar
abstract: LEAD: The dollar surged to its highest levels in almost six weeks yesterday, propelled by a wave of Japanese buying and a continued rise in interest rates in the United States.

headline: Rochester U. President Troubled by Fuji Case
abstract: LEAD: Asserting that the University of Rochester was committed to unbiased scrutiny of applicants for enrollment, the school's president said yesterday that he planned to meet with officials of the Eastman Kodak Company to discuss a ''very troubling'' incident involving the company and the university.

headline: IRAN-CASE COUNSEL PLEDGES TO PURSUE ALL LAWBREAKERS
abstract: LEAD: The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair said today that ''high office, well-intended policies or popular policies do not place anyone above the law.''

headline: Strikes Shut Korea's Car Plants
abstract: LEAD: Miners set buildings ablaze and workers barricaded a factory with forklift trucks as spreading labor turmoil halted car production in South Korea today, the Government said.

headline: Chile Is Said to Bar Author From Entering the Country
abstract: LEAD: The Chilean author Ariel Dorfman was prevented from entering the country today when he arrived at Santiago Airport on a flight from the United States, members of his family said.

headline: U.S. Is Asked to Clarify Lebanese Man's Arrest
abstract: LEAD: The Lebanese Government sent a note today to the United States Justice Department asking it to clarifiy its action in seizing a Lebanese citizen in the Mediterranean Sea and taking him to Washington for trial on hijacking charges.

headline: Cray Presents New Computer
abstract: LEAD: Moving to retain its pre-eminence in the supercomputer market, Cray Research Inc. today introduced the Cray-2S computer systems, an enhanced range of the Cray 2 supercomputer offering a 25 to 40 percent improvement in overall system performance.

headline: Advertising; Levenson Joins Scali, McCabe
abstract: LEAD: Robert H. Levenson, one of the creative stars at Doyle Dane Bernbach during its glory years, has joined Scali, McCabe, Sloves as vice chairman. That title was vacated last week by Sam Scali, a co-founder of the agency, who became president.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM GORBACHEV VIEWS
abstract: LEAD: Following are excerpts from written answers by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, to questions submitted by the Indonesian newspaper Merdeka, as provided by Tass:

headline: Holiday Inns Role for Bass
abstract: LEAD: Bass P.L.C., a big British brewing concern, said it is buying interests in 178 Holiday Inn hotels from the Holiday Corporation. The $475 million deal would allow Bass to run all the Holiday Inns outside the United States, Canada and Mexico.

headline: British Trade Gap Widens
abstract: LEAD: Britain registered a huge deficit of $1.5 billion in its balance of payments on goods and services in August, the Government said today.

headline: Alcoa Planning Big Write-Off
abstract: LEAD: The Aluminum Company of America said yesterday that it would take a $165.7 million after-tax charge against earnings for the second quarter. As a result of the charge, the company said it would report a loss for the quarter.

headline: Soviet Arms Concession Is Hinted
abstract: LEAD: A senior Soviet official said today that the Soviet Union would be willing to consider use of a monitoring system long advocated by the United States for nuclear testing, but only if the Americans agreed to negotiate a comprehensive test ban treaty.

headline: A Tamil Separatist Leader Dies in Protest Fast
abstract: LEAD: A prominent Tamil separatist leader died today after a 12-day fast to protest the way the Indian-Sri Lankan peace accord is being carried out. His death set off protests in the northern city of Jaffna.

headline: Real Estate; Broadway Wholesale District
abstract: LEAD: AT first glance, the stretch of Broadway from Greeley Square at 32d Street south to 26th Street seems like any other active shopping district.

headline: Chiat Wins Big Nissan Ad Account
abstract: LEAD: In what is believed to be the largest advertising account switch in history, the Nissan Motor Corporation U.S.A. has moved its $150 million in billings to Chiat/Day of Los Angeles.

headline: Senegal's Envoy Surrenders Son's License After Accident
abstract: LEAD: Senegal's Ambassador to the United States has surrendered his son's driver's license to the State Department in connection with an accident last week, a spokesman said today.

headline: Lomas Broadens Its Horizons
abstract: LEAD: For nearly 20 years, the Lomas & Nettleton Financial Corporation was the undisputed leader in the staid mortgage banking business.

headline: KEY RATES
abstract: LEAD:                 Previous   Year        In percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   8.50        DISCOUNT RATE   5.50   5.50   6.50        FEDERAL FUNDS   6.63   6.68   6.97        3-MO. headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 15,1987
abstract: LEAD:  COMPANIES

headline: Jaguar's Net Falls by 38%
abstract: LEAD: Jaguar P.L.C. said today that its earnings fell 38 percent in the first half partly because of higher-than-expected start-up costs for its new XJ6 model.

headline: Cavillo, Shevack Gets Tequila Sauza Account
abstract: LEAD: Cavillo, Shevack & Partners has been assigned the United States advertising for Tequila Sauza, with a budget of between $1 million and $2 million.

headline: 16 Hurt in Stagecoach Crash
abstract: LEAD: Sixteen people were injured today when a stagecoach operated by a concessionaire tipped over inside Yellowstone National Park. A park spokesman, Greg Kroll, said the stagecoach tipped over after the two lead horses of its four-horse team bolted and went off the road. He said four of those hurt were hospitalized with broken bones.

headline: A.M.I. Names New Chairman
abstract: LEAD: The two chief architects of a financial restructuring at American Medical International Inc. were promoted today to the top jobs at the hospital company, based in Beverly Hills, Calif.

headline: Making Arms
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Brazil's Debt Plan Takes an Odd Tack
abstract: LEAD: Despite a continuing crisis of confidence in the Government's management of the domestic economy, Brazil has decided to insist on what it calls a nonconventional approach to restructuring its huge foreign debt.

headline: GENENTECH LOSES PATENT
abstract: LEAD: In its second major setback in six weeks, Genentech Inc., a leading biotechnology company, lost the British patent for what it expects to become its main product, tissue plasminogen activator. The Chancery Division of the

headline: Uncertainty on 10-Year Notes
abstract: LEAD: The Treasury sold $9.25 billion of 10-year notes yesterday, amid conflicting views among securities dealers about investor demand for the issue at yesterday's average yield of 8.74 percent.

headline: CITY OF MIMOSA, UNTOUCHED BY WAR
abstract: LEAD: The church bells are first to greet the dawn as it seeps into the darkness of a wet and chilly morning in the Central Highlands. Hundreds of people respond to the call at a 5:15 mass in Dalat Cathedral and at smaller churches or the chapels of crumbling monasteries in the surrounding hills.

headline: RENEWAL OF RAIDS ON IRAN BY IRAQIS PROTESTED BY U.S.
abstract: LEAD: The United States, which has portrayed Iran as the main aggressor in the Persian Gulf war, has strongly protested Iraq's renewed attacks on Iranian targets, State Department officials said today.

headline: ... WHILE THE JAPANESE RETHINK TRADE STANCE
abstract: LEAD: A Japanese-American confrontation over the illegal sale of high-technology propeller-milling equipment to the Soviet Union by the Toshiba Machine Company has provoked a national debate in Japan on many international trade and security issues.

headline: Rio Journal; Plain Hoods to Police, Robin Hoods to Slums
abstract: LEAD: A burst of submachine-gun fire from the air sent guards and visitors running for cover on a recent Sunday afternoon as a small helicopter tried to free a prominent drug trafficker from a prison here.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Elantec Inc., Milipitas, Calif., an analog semiconductor maker, said Dave O'Brien had accepted the position of president and chief executive.

headline: Managua Braces for Return of Dissent
abstract: LEAD: Seven weeks after the signing of a Central American peace accord, Nicaragua is bracing for an ideological confrontation, and this week could be a watershed.

headline: Dart Lifts Dayton Bid To $68
abstract: LEAD: The Dart Group Corporation sweetened its bid for the Dayton Hudson Corporation by $3 a share yesterday, to $68.

headline: New-Home Sales Rose 3.5% in June
abstract: LEAD: After a huge decline in May, new-home sales rose 3.5 percent in June as a turnaround in mortgage rates bolstered a sagging sales market, the Government reported today.

headline: Yields Are Mixed
abstract: LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were mixed for the week ended yesterday, with little change from a week ago.

headline: Initial Schwab Offering Priced at $16.50 a Share
abstract: LEAD: The initial public offering of the Charles Schwab Corporation, the nation's largest discount broker, will begin today at $16.50 a share, according to underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

headline: Leader Says Tamils Will Turn In Arms
abstract: LEAD: The leader of the main Tamil insurgent group said today that his men would surrender their arms as part of an agreement intended to end this country's ethnic violence.

headline: Advertising; Banjo Aids Agency's Recruiting
abstract: LEAD: BEFORE Larry Kopald, senior vice president of Ketchum Advertising, sold his new client on its first campaign there, he had a tougher sale to make.

headline: Sharp Words on Immunity
abstract: LEAD: Near the end of the Iran-contra hearings yesterday, Representative Jack Brooks, Democrat of Texas, became involved in an exchange with Colonel North's lawyer, Brendan V. Sullivan Jr., about grants of immunity from prosecution.

headline: 19 SRI LANKANS ARE KILLED IN RIOTING OVER INDIAN PACT
abstract: LEAD: At least 19 people were killed today in rioting over an accord with the Indian Government of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi that would grant more autonomy to the Tamil minority in Eastern and Northern Provinces of Sri Lanka.

headline: About Real Estate; River Housing Gives Nyack New Look
abstract: LEAD: ''You're inquiring about our Disneyland on the Hudson, our Miami Vice?'' came the playfully sardonic voice of Jean Gardner, the clerk in Nyack, N.Y., when asked about a new condominium development now creeping up the banks of the Hudson River in the Rockland County village.

headline: Patents; Making Color Photo From TV
abstract: LEAD: A METHOD of making color photographs from a television screen, with an opportunity to select pictures, was patented this week for the Eastman Kodak Company, which is based in Rochester. Dana W. Wolcott, a staff member, was granted patent No. 4,695,902.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN THE PRIVATE EYE BUSINESS
abstract: LEAD: PRIVATE eyes don't just spy on cheating spouses anymore. More and more, they are investigating companies involved in mergers and acquisitions, pursuing corporate embezzlers, checking out insider trading scandals, uncovering illegal apartment sublets and proving insurance fraud.

headline: Rio Bus Fare Increase Is Revoked After Riot
abstract: LEAD: Tens of thousands of people protesting an increase in bus fares rioted in downtown Rio today, battling police, looting stores and setting buses afire before the Government rescinded the increase late tonight.

headline: Hanoi Said to Agree to Meet on Missing
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz confirmed today that Vietnam had relented and agreed to American conditions for a meeting with a special envoy to discuss the issue of missing servicemen.

headline: Bill Auction Is Well Received
abstract: LEAD: The Treasury's long-delayed auction of new three-month and six-month bills elicited good investor demand yesterday, spurred by the availability of interest rates well above 6 percent.

headline: Consumer Debt Rose In June
abstract: LEAD: Americans took out $3.46 billion more in credit in June than they paid off, but growth in borrowing this year is still far behind the 1986 pace, the Government said today.

headline: Money Fund Assets Off
abstract: LEAD: Assets of the nation's 390 money market mutual funds fell $508.1 million, to $241.40 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 100 institutional funds were down $1.27 billion, to $66.39 billion. Assets of the 200 general purpose funds were up $838.1 million, to $69.07 billion.

headline: ISRAEL GIVES U.S. IRAN ROLE REPORT
abstract: LEAD: Israeli officials said today that they had turned over a 60-page chronology of Israel's activities in the Iran affair to United States Congressional investigators on Wednesday.

abstract: LEAD:       $         Previous   Year     In percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago              PRIME RATE   8.75   8.75   7.50        DISCOUNT RATE   6.00   6.00   5.50        FEDERAL FUNDS   7.94   7.54   5.76        3-MO.
