headline: Open Positions on Short Sales Off 4.9% on Nasdaq
abstract: LEAD: The National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday that the number of shares sold short, and not yet covered, in the month ended Sept. 15 fell 12.1 million shares, or 4.9 percent, to 236.1 million shares.

headline: U.S. Fights Court Bid By A.T.&T.
abstract: LEAD: The Justice Department yesterday asked a Federal court in Washington to deny a motion by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company that could prevent the Martin Marietta Corporation from competing for a multibillion-dollar Government telephone contract.

headline: We Can Weave a New Safety Net
abstract: LEAD: AFTER years of regressive national policies, America's social safety net has come to resemble the contents of Ollie North's shredder.

headline: U.S. REPORTS FIRING ON IRANIAN VESSEL SEEN LAYING MINES
abstract: LEAD: The Reagan Administration said tonight that a United States helicopter gunship had fired on an Iranian vessel laying mines in the path of American ships in the Persian Gulf, setting the craft afire.

headline: Cablevision to Add Adams-Russell
abstract: LEAD: The Cablevision Systems Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Adams-Russell Company, a publicly held cable concern based in Waltham, Mass., for $474 million, or $43.075 a share.

headline: The Question of Liabiliyty
abstract: LEAD: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North testified yesterday that a turning point for him in the Iran-contra affair was the press conference Nov. 25. at which Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d discussed, among other things, the questions of who knew about the diversions. Here is an exchange from that press conference.

headline: Action Awaited on U.S. Debt Ceiling
abstract: LEAD: The outlook for Treasury financings remains cloudy this week, as securities dealers and investors wait for Congress to pass legislation raising the Federal debt ceiling.

headline: Caesars Bid Is Weighed
abstract: LEAD: Martin T. Sosnoff, the investor who put Caesars World Inc. into play earlier this year, said yesterday that he was still interested in acquiring the casino operator and had made another bid for the company the day after New Jersey's Casino Control Commission rejected Caesar's proposed recapitalization plan.

headline: Sprinkel Expected to Quit Today
abstract: LEAD: Beryl W. Sprinkel, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, plans to announce his resignation Friday, according to White House officials.

headline: Anti-Copying Bill Approved
abstract: LEAD: A House subcommittee, acting to shield the United States recording industry from home taping and commercial piracy, today approved a bill requiring that digital audio tape, or DAT, recorders from Japan contain an anti-copying device for one year.

headline: Market Place; Another Feast In Chip Stocks
abstract: LEAD: SEMICONDUCTOR stocks - notorious on Wall Street for their feast-or-famine behavior - are performing handsomely in response to rising orders, depleted inventories and an economic recovery that seems tailor-made for their products. These companies make the chips that run everything from computers and talking dolls to radar equipment and dishwashers.

headline: Borg Plans to Sell Finance Unit Stake
abstract: LEAD: The Borg-Warner Holdings Corporation disclosed yesterday that it planned to offer 32 million shares, representing roughly 80 percent, of its finance subsidiary to the public for between $19 and $22 a share.

headline: Advertising; Head of Muller Jordan Adds Creative Title
abstract: LEAD: Jane Maas, president of Muller Jordan Weiss, started out in the business as a copywriter and, although she later got into account management, she never really gave up the writing.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * American Isuzu Motors Inc., Whitter, Calif., said it had increased retail prices on cars by 1.5 percent and on trucks by 3.7 percent.

headline: Mixed Ruling On Newmont
abstract: LEAD: A Delaware judge ruled today that Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C. may not use recently purchased shares of the Newmont Mining Corporation to vote on the proposed takeover of Newmont by the Texas investor T. Boone Pickens.

headline: KOREA DISSIDENTS HALT TALKS PENDING RELEASE OF PRISONERS
abstract: LEAD: The country's top opposition leaders toughened their stance on negotiations with the rulling party today, saying that they would not talk until all South Korean political prisoners are released and their civil rights restored.

headline: Car Imports in Germany
abstract: LEAD: Foreign car makers' share of the West German new-car market fell to 31.3 percent in the first seven months of this year, from 32.7 percent in the period a year ago, the Federal Motor Office said today. Foreign producers' sales rose to 85,421 in July, from 78,650 a year before, but were down to 553,752 cars during the seven-month period, from 561,436.

headline: Senate Asserts Its Role On Arms-Control Bid
abstract: LEAD: The Senate tonight approved a nonbinding resolution supporting President Reagan's efforts to reach an arms-control agreement with the Soviet Union, but emphasizing the Senate's role in setting arms-control policy and approving treaties.

headline: LTV Head Speaks
abstract: LEAD: The chairman of the LTV Corporation said today that his company's competitors had successfully lobbied the Federal pension agency that this week returned employee-pension liabilities to LTV. The agency earlier this week gave the $2 billion pension liability back to the big steelmaker. Raymond Hay, LTV chairman, said rival steel companies, including the Bethlehem Steel Corporation and the USX Corporation, had gone to Washington to speak with the Labor Department and had encouraged the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation to ''take the action.

headline: In Noisy Athens, a Quiet Appeal for Silence
abstract: LEAD: The sandwich bar on Skoufa Street has reopened after a long break, and these days there is a chance that a telephone caller might find someone at some office to take a call.

headline: Iranian Assails Saudis Over OPEC Production
abstract: LEAD: Iran's deputy oil minister attacked Saudi Arabia today for not doing more to put pressure on Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates and Iraq to limit overproduction.

headline: Aquino Rebukes Military Leaders For Slowness in Achieving Results
abstract: LEAD: President Corazon C. Aquino called military commanders to her office today to urge faster action in pursuing the leaders of a coup attempt last month.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Chairman Named By Westinghouse
abstract: LEAD: The Westinghouse Corporation's board of directors yesterday named John C. Marous, 62 years old, as the successor to Douglas D. Danforth, the current chairman and chief executive. Mr. Marous is president and chief operating officer.

headline: Farm Bank Tightening Approved
abstract: LEAD: Officials of the financially troubled Farm Credit System, under Congressional pressure to tighten operations, today approved a plan aimed at consolidating and trimming the operations of the nation's largest farm lender.

headline: IRAN AND U.N. MEET ON GULF CEASE-FIRE
abstract: LEAD: Iran's Deputy Foreign Minister met today with Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar to discuss the Security Council's call for a cease-fire in the Persian Gulf, but officials close to the discussions reported little progress.

headline: 150 Argentine Officers Stay In Their Barracks in Protest
abstract: LEAD: At least 150 army officers confined themselves to their barracks in suburban Buenos Aires late tonight to protest the transfer of their commanding officer.

headline: House Panel Votes Subpoena Of 3 in Contra Drug Inquiry
abstract: LEAD: A House subcommittee voted today to subpoena three Miami-based federal prosecutors in a largely secret investigation into whether Reagan Administration officials supported illegal drug and gun smuggling to benefit the Nicaraguan guerrillas.

headline: PATENTS; Test for AIDS Virus
abstract: LEAD: A method for detecting the AIDS virus has been developed for Texas A & M University. Patent No. 4,692,403 was awarded this week to Prof. Luther E. Lindner, head of the department of pathology, and Stephen R. Wechter, a former student. The patent is now assigned to Mr. Wechter, who is offering rights to the pharmaceutical industry.

headline: Witness Says U.S. Turned Its Back on Iran Talks
abstract: LEAD: Senior Reagan Administration officials ignored a real opportunity to pursue a new relationship with Iran because they felt intense political pressure to free the hostages held by pro-Iranian groups, a former White House consultant asserted in testimony before the Iran-contra committees.

headline: Economic Scene; Fear of War And Inflation
abstract: LEAD: THE bloody clashes between Iranian pilgrims and Saudi Arabian police in Mecca and the renewed anti-American threats from Iran -matched by stiffening American determination to keep the Persian Gulf open - have sharply driven up the price of oil.

headline: Indian Force Bolstered
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi sent additional Indian troops and armored vehicles to Sri Lanka today and stepped up his political campaign at home for the Indian-sponsored accord to end Sri Lanka's ethnic conflict.

headline: Talks Held With Coke About Stake in Viacom
abstract: LEAD: Viacom International Inc. said yesterday that it had held preliminary talks with the Coca-Cola Company about the sale of a minority stake in several of its operations.

headline: TV Networks Resume Rotation on Hearings
abstract: LEAD: The Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair will be televised live beginning at 9 A.M. on the ABC television network under the network rotation system. The hearings will also be televised on CNN, the Cable News Network, and on some local affiliates of PBS, the Public Broadcasting Service, including Channel 13 in New

headline: ISRAEL AND U.S. DISCUSS PLANE
abstract: LEAD: Israel's Defense Minister, Yitzhak Rabin, met with Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger and Secretary of State George P. Shultz today to discuss what assistance the United States might provide to Israel if the Lavi jet-fighter project is canceled.

headline: Prices Rise in Mild Session
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury issues did an about-face yesterday and rose in mild trading, especially on instruments with shorter maturities.

headline: Burlington Cuts 525 Jobs
abstract: LEAD: Burlington Industries, in its first major action since undertaking a $2.9 billion leveraged buyout to prevent a hostile takeover, said today it would lay off 525 employees.

headline: Reichhold Rejects Offer by Dainippon
abstract: LEAD: Reichhold Chemicals Inc. yesterday rejected a $473 million hostile takeover bid from Dainippon Ink and Chemicals Inc. and said that it would explore other possible offers for the company.

headline: IN QUOTES
abstract: LEAD: ''I suggest that history will say he was a giant, not only in a physical sense, but in the esteem of all those with whom he came in contact.''

headline: Article 526187 -- No Title
abstract: LEAD: The Aluminum Company of America said today that special charges caused a $91.2 million loss in the second quarter in contrast to a profit of $53.3 million, or 63 cents a share, a year earlier.

headline: BERENTER GREENHOUSE GETS H-O HOT CEREALS
abstract: LEAD: Nutrition Industries of Cresskill, N.J., which specializes in the resuscitation of widely known but not necessarily healthy brands, has turned to the Berenter Greenhouse & Webster agency for help with H-O hot cereals.

headline: Walesa Says Solidarity Will Take U.S. Money
abstract: LEAD: Lech Walesa, leader of the banned Solidarity trade union, said today that the union would accept $1 million appropriated by the United States Congress but would spend the money only on medical care for workers.

headline: Company Subsidies for Staying Well
abstract: LEAD: In each of the past three years, many employees of the King Broadcasting Company in Seattle have received checks for as much as $700.

headline: Greenspan Talent Search
abstract: LEAD: Townsend-Greenspan & Company, the economic consulting firm owned by Alan Greenspan, would be dissolved if a well-known economist is not found by midweek to replace Mr. Greenspan, who has been nominated to be chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

headline: Bush Tours Birkenau and Auschwitz
abstract: LEAD: A grim-faced Vice President Bush toured bleak reminders of the Nazi death camps today and afterward, in a shaken voice, said there was ''no way to express'' his emotions.

headline: SHADOW OF DAWA PRISONERS
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and previous witnesses before the select committees have often referred to ''the Dawa prisoners.'' Here is how they have figured in the Iran-contra story:

headline: Suit Challenges Crazy Eddie
abstract: LEAD: Entertainment Marketing Inc., which has threatened a proxy fight for control of Crazy Eddie Inc., filed a lawsuit in Delaware State Court today asking that Crazy Eddie be forced to hold its annual meeting. A spokesman for Crazy

headline: Gorbachev Says 1987 Could See Arms Pact
abstract: LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, said today that a treaty eliminating medium-range nuclear missiles could still be worked out this year by the superpowers, and that an accord to cut long-range weapons was possible early next year.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA SAYS IT MAY SOON SIGN ATOMIC AGREEMENT
abstract: LEAD: South Africa indicated tonight that it might soon sign a treaty intended to curb the spread of nuclear weapons.

headline: Mixing, Matching and Merging
abstract: LEAD: ''SMALL is beautiful'' could have been the motto of the alternative greeting card business in the decade that ended in 1985. But in the last two years, as Hallmark and American Greetings started turning out alternative cards of their own, many smaller companies decided they had to merge or die.

headline: Schwab Plans Offering Of $14 to $17 a Share
abstract: LEAD: The Charles Schwab Corporation, the nation's largest discount broker, filed today for an initial public stock offering, just six months after it was sold off by the ailing BankAmerica Corporation.

headline: U.S. and Greece Ease Dispute And Open Way to Base Talks
abstract: LEAD: Greek and American officials indicated today that their countries had overcome a crisis that had reportedly jeopardized the future of United States military bases.

headline: The U.N. Today: Aug. 31, 1987
abstract: LEAD: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

headline: Price Rise Set For Diamonds
abstract: LEAD: De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd., which has a virtual monopoly on sales of rough diamonds, said today that its Central Selling Organization would raise its gemstone prices by an overall 10 percent next month.

headline: Manila Assassination Trial Is Barely Moving
abstract: LEAD: ''Hey, boss, we've got a crowd,'' said a defense lawyer the other day as a reporter walked in to the empty courtroom where, for the third time, lawyers were trying to determine who killed Benigno S. Aquino Jr. four years ago.

headline: Electronic Data Official A Key to Navy Contract
abstract: LEAD: Paul J. Chiapparone, senior vice president of the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, is accustomed to overcoming difficult conditions.

headline: A Republican Politician, In Both U.S. and Ulster
abstract: LEAD: The summer patriots are back, and the militants among the Irish are grateful.

headline: Reorganization At TV Retailer
abstract: LEAD: Home Shopping Network Inc. said today that it planned a major reorganization that would make it a diversified holding company. Home Shopping's chairman, Roy M. Speer, said the company's main business would be the retailing of consumer products and services, ''as well as many other diversified products and services through television, direct mail and telemarketing media.

headline: Murdoch Buys British Tabloid
abstract: LEAD: Rupert Murdoch added another newspaper to his international media empire today, buying Britain's financially troubled Today color tabloid for $60.8 million.

headline: Under Aquino, Drive Against Communists Lags
abstract: LEAD: The military campaign against the Communist insurgency in the Philippines has made little progress since the ouster of Ferdinand E. Marcos 19 months ago, in the view of Philippine and foreign military officers, and some say the rebels are gaining ground politically.

headline: Advertising; Richmond Agency Gets Tire Retailer's Account
abstract: LEAD: After a six-way competition, National Tire Wholesale, a tire retailer in Richmond, has chosen Siddall, Matus & Coughter, also based in Richmond, to handle its $6.5 million budget.

headline: Advertising; Hyatt Goes To Hill, Holliday
abstract: LEAD: HILL, HOLLIDAY, CONNORS, COSMOPULOS last week won the $15 million Hyatt Hotels Corporation account, with creative work done by top creative people from both its Boston and New York offices.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: LEAD: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday  None  Tuesday  Construction SpendingJuly  Leading IndicatorsJuly  Wednesday  None  Thursday  None  Friday  None

headline: U.S., a Month After Tripoli Raid, Reportedly Planned to Meet With Libyan
abstract: LEAD: One month after the United States bombed Libya in 1986, a handful of American officials approved plans for a secret meeting with a shadowy Libyan official who wanted better relations with Washington, according to documents and a participant in the dealings.

headline: Pacific Isle Asks U.N. to Help Get Dirt Back
abstract: LEAD: One of the world's smallest countries has appealed to the United Nations to help it redress what the country calls a crime that it says may threaten its existence: the theft of almost all its topsoil by three colonial powers during a 50-year occupation.

headline: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
abstract: LEAD:            Net      Percent       Income      Change                     Net Income   Percent       April-June   Change       1987   From '86       Anheuser-Busch Cos.   $181,800,000   +19.3        ARCO   330,000,000   +120.0        Digital Equipment Corp.   377,300,000   +58.1        Holiday Corp.   74,900,000   +96.6        Johnson & Johnson   224,400,000   +18.2        Loral Corp.

headline: Motorola Expects U.S. Indictment
abstract: LEAD: Motorola Inc. expects to be indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of overpricing and improper billing in two Defense Department contracts for electronics equipment, company officials said. Motorola's vice chairman and chief operating officer, William J. Weisz, said the company was considering a plea agreement on some of the charges.

headline: U.S. Confident on Oil Supply
abstract: LEAD: A senior Energy Department planner said today that rising tension in the Middle East had caused ''increased consciousness'' about a possible cutoff of oil supplies but that the Administration was confident that the United States could cope with any such shortage.

headline: 5 New PC's From Hewlett
abstract: LEAD: The Hewlett-Packard Company announced five new computers today in its HP Vectra line of personal computers, which are compatible with the International Business Machines Corporation's PC. The new machines expand Hewlett-Packard's offerings at both the low and the high end of the market, and include a new entry-level computer, two enhanced versions of its current

headline: E.D.S. Unit Wins Big Navy Job
abstract: LEAD: The Electronic Data Systems Federal Corporation, a unit of the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, has been awarded a military contract estimated by the Navy to be worth $544 million over the 12-year life of the project.

headline: Jack-Up Project Saves Sinking North Sea Rigs
abstract: LEAD: Engineers in Norway's Ekofisk oilfield today completed the last delicate phase of a $600 million operation to raise sinking oil rigs. Six huge platform decks, perched on steel legs driven into the North Sea floor, have been jacked up by 18 feet.

headline: London Seeks Part Of A.D.R. Market
abstract: LEAD: In recent years, London has watched with alarm as much of the equity trading in Britain's flagship companies has crossed the Atlantic to Wall Street, where non-American shares are bought and sold in the convenient, dollar-denominated form of American depositary receipts.

headline: Chrysler Pricing Plans
abstract: LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation said today that in some cases it would keep prices steady on its 1988 model domestic cars and in other cases raise them by as much as 5 percent. The decision is tentative, it said, while it completes its pricing strategy. The company said it would not be able to provide an average price increase until all models were introduced in September.

headline: Support for Contra Aid Continues to Increase
abstract: LEAD: Support for aid to the Nicaraguan contras continued to increase in the last week, but the latest New York York Times/CBS News poll, taken Tuesday and Wednesday, still shows 49 percent of the public opposed and only 40 percent in favor.

headline: Land for Salvador's Poor: To Many, Bitter Victory
abstract: LEAD: When Jose Eleutereo Cruz received a tiny plot of land just below the rocky spine of a mountain ridge here seven years ago, he fulfilled his lifelong dream to own the ground he works. But now that dream is little more than a nightmare and he is thinking of giving up and moving to another area.

headline: An Electronics Pioneer Hunts for Profits
abstract: LEAD: STANFORD R. OVSHINSKY'S moment of truth as a business man is at hand. It has been almost 20 years since he startled physicists by making an electronic switch out of a glass-like amorphous material, thus drawing worldwide attention to his claim that such materials had valuable energy-handling properties they had overlooked during the crystal-based electronics revolution.

headline: Bethlehem Says Chapter 11 Is Possible in Future
abstract: LEAD: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, in an unusually pessimistic public assessment, said yesterday that external conditions could compel it to file for bankruptcy in the future. However, the nation's third-largest steelmaker asserted later that it had no imminent plans to seek protection under the bankruptcy laws.

headline: More Changes in China
abstract: LEAD: China is preparing far-reaching but difficult economic changes to continue its high growth rate, a top World Bank official said today. Moeen Qureshi, a senior vice president, said the changes included increasing the size of land holdings and developing a class of entrepreneurs who would run factories in place of bureaucrats.

headline: Salomon To Sell 12% To Buffett
abstract: LEAD: Warren E. Buffett, known as a sharp investor with an eye for undervalued securities, has agreed to pay $700 million for a 12 percent stake in Salomon Inc., the parent company of Salomon Brothers Inc., Wall Street's largest investment banking house.

headline: The Witness File
abstract: LEAD:  Name: Caspar W. Weinberger  Age: 69  Position: Secretary of Defense since 1981. Mr. Weinberger held several positions in previous Republican administrations, including chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, director of the Office of Management and Budget, counselor to the President and Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

headline: Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Guinness Import Company to Ron Semler Advertising, New York, for its Kronenbourg beer.

headline: Dollar Closes Mixed; Precious Metals Drop
abstract: LEAD: The dollar turned in a mixed performance yesterday, firming against the Japanese yen but setting new three-month lows against the West German mark in active trading dominated by rumors.

headline: BACHE BRAVES A NEW WORLD
abstract: LEAD: Prudential-Bache Securities has never before been a pioneer, but these days its energetic chairman, George L. Ball, is leading the brokerage firm on what he calls an expedition into Wall Street's most inviting frontier.

headline: 6 Americans Killed in Salvador
abstract: LEAD: Six Americans were killed Wednesday night when their helicopter crashed on a mission to evacuate a wounded American military adviser, an American Embassy spokesman said today.

headline: Peronists Make a Comeback in Argentine Election
abstract: LEAD: President Raul Alfonsin suffered a worse reverse in elections Sunday than anyone had predicted, with the political descendants of Juan Domingo Peron, his chief opposition, making an impressive comeback.

headline: Occidental to Get Nearly $1 Billion
abstract: LEAD: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation will receive nearly $1 billion in a complicated transaction involving the sale of 49 percent of its meatpacking subsidiary, IBP Inc. The company said it would sell 23.5 million shares for $19 to $22 a share, which could raise up to $517 million for IBP. Before the public offering, IBP would pay a $960 million dividend to Occidental, borrowing the money to do so.

headline: English Riot Training Sends 20 to Hospital
abstract: LEAD: An exercise designed to train the police in riot control here turned out to be too realistic. Twenty officers ended up in the hospital with sprains, cuts and bruises.

headline: Shareholders Clear VW Management
abstract: LEAD: At a packed and sometimes heated annual meeting, Volkswagen A.G.'s stockholders voted approval today of the auto maker's senior managers, effectively absolving them of the foreign-exchange swindle that cost the company almost $260 million in losses.

headline: WHITES BACK MOVE TO END APARTHEID
abstract: LEAD: The first nationwide meeting of South African white groups opposed to apartheid expressed support today for a future initiative to end the practice and usher in a nonracial democracy.

headline: IN QUOTES
abstract: LEAD: ''This kind of downward volatility is reminiscent of the worst bear markets I have seen in the last 15 years.''

headline: HBO Buying Rights To Paramount Films
abstract: LEAD: Home Box Office has signed an exclusive agreement for the pay-television rights to Paramount Pictures films released after mid-1988. The deal, which includes 85 films, is expected to last at least five years.

headline: Newmont Stock Falls On Doubts
abstract: LEAD: Shares of the Newmont Mining Corporation today lost more than a third of Monday's $9.50-a-share gain as traders questioned whether Ivanhoe Partners could raise enough money to finance its proposed purchase of Newmont for $5.7 billion.

headline: But Markets Only Seem More Volatile
abstract: LEAD: IT is widely reported that the stock market has become increasingly volatile. Analysts worry that such volatility may scare away equity investors and reduce capital formation. Anecdotal evidence of increased volatility abounds. The market, as measured by the Dow Jones average, dropped 120 points in two days during September 1986.

headline: Late Rally Lifts Bond Prices
abstract: LEAD: A late rally raised prices of Treasury securities yesterday after the bond market was battered early in the session by a Government report of an enormous $15.7 billion trade deficit for June.

headline: Allied-Lyons Sale
abstract: LEAD: Allied-Lyons P.L.C., a major British food and beverage company, said today that it had sold its stake in the Bacardi Corporation for more than $:122 million, or about $197 million. Allied-Lyons acquired a 12 percent interest in Bacardi last year as part of its $:400 million takeover of the liquor division of Hiram Walker Resources Ltd.

headline: Pan Am Unions
abstract: LEAD: The joint labor council of Pan American World Airways said that it had retained Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. to advise the group, which represents most of the major unions at the carrier, on alternatives for restructuring the airline. The council also said that it had directed Drexel to seek investors willing to put large amounts of capital into the company, which has an aging fleet and sold off most of its Pacific routes last year to raise cash.

headline: Stocks Weaken; Dow Gives Up 12.76
abstract: LEAD: Stocks weakened yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average retreated from the record high it set in Wednesday's session.

headline: Dow Off 3.02; Technology Stocks Up
abstract: LEAD: Despite a stunning surge in the technology sector, the stock market weakened yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average, off sharply much of the day, rallied to close only 3.02 points lower, at 2,452.97.

headline: MINISTERS DISCUSS LATIN PEACE PLAN
abstract: LEAD: Central American foreign ministers opened two days of meetings here today in the first formal step toward carrying out a new peace plan for the region.

headline: The U.N. Today: Aug. 6, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  GENERAL ASSEMBLY

headline: U.S. Crude Falls Below $20 a Barrel
abstract: LEAD: Prices of the leading American crude oil dropped sharply yesterday, falling below $20 a barrel for the first time in two months. The market, oil analysts said, is now intent on eroding the high prices of early this summer.

headline: Emery Refinancing
abstract: LEAD: The Emery Air Freight Corporation said it agreed to refinance the $129.9 million of bank debt it took on when it bought the Purolator Courier Corporation. It said it would raise $95 million through asset sales and other means and would get $45 million of pension fund assets by creating an employee stock ownership plan.

headline: Caribbean Trade Bill
abstract: LEAD: A bill to expand and extend the Caribbean Basin Initiative trade incentives and increase sugar import quotas for nations in the area was introduced today by the chairman of the House Trade subcommittee. ''Our hope is that economic prosperity will ensure political stability in the region for years to come,'' said Sam Gibbons, a Florida Democrat.

headline: Poland Sentences 2 Danes
abstract: LEAD: A Polish military court has ordered two Danes imprisoned for spying, the Danish Embassy here said today. The two men - Jens Ellekaer, 36 years old, a businessman, and Niels Hemmingsen, 23, a student - were convicted in the Baltic town of Koszalin. Mr. Ellekaer was sentenced to nine years, Mr. Hemmingsen to seven.

headline: 13 Latin Nations End Meeting on Peace Pact
abstract: LEAD: Foreign ministers from 13 Latin American countries ended their meeting here today after creating a commission to verify compliance with a Central American peace accord.

headline: Capital Holding Selects Chairman's Successor
abstract: LEAD: In a move to strengthen its financial services side, the Capital Holding Corporation, known mainly as a life insurer, yesterday named Irving W. Bailey 2d president and chief operating officer. Mr. Bailey had been executive vice president and chief investment officer. He succeeds Robert T. Rakich, 49, who was president of the company for three years and resigned to pursue other interests, a spokesman said.

headline: U.S. CONVOY BEGINS VOYAGE DOWN GULF
abstract: LEAD: Four re-registered Kuwaiti tankers, including the mine-damaged Bridgeton, slipped away from Kuwait before dawn today under American naval escort, beginning their dangerous voyage back down the Persian Gulf.

headline: Trade Deficit Set Record in 2d Quarter
abstract: LEAD: The nation's trade deficit swelled to a record of $39.5 billion in this year's second quarter as a tide of imports overtook a smaller increase in exports, the Commerce Department reported today.

headline: Trump's Stake In Golden Nugget
abstract: LEAD: Donald J. Trump, the New York real estate developer, has a 4.9 percent interest in Golden Nugget Inc., the casino operator in Las Vegas. A secretary to Mr. Trump said he authorized her statement after The Wall Street Journal reported yesterday that he owned the stock and might seek control.

headline: Arabs Seized in West Bank
abstract: LEAD: Israeli security forces in the occupied West Bank of Jordan have arrested three groups of Palestinians accused of carrying out 11 attacks for the guerrilla movement Al Fatah in the last two years, security officials said today. They said the groups had planted car bombs and thrown firebombs and a hand grenade.

headline: Pohl on Dollar Reserves
abstract: LEAD: Karl Otto Pohl, the president of the Bundesbank, West Germany's central bank, estimated that central banks bought up to $70 billion between the end of last year and May. Central banks used the intervention to shore up their currency reserves with cheap dollars, he said in an interview in the news magazine Der Spiegel to be published on Monday.

headline: Guinness Peat Stakes Raised
abstract: LEAD: Equiticorp Holdings Ltd. said today that it had raised its stake in Guinness Peat Group P.L.C. to 44.2 percent and felt confident it would win control of the London merchant bank.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: Standard Brands Paint Rejects Bid
abstract: LEAD: The Standard Brands Paint Company, a do-it-yourself home-decorator retail chain, has rejected an unsolicited $300 million takeover offer from a New Zealand real estate and investment concern. The offer of $21 a share in cash, plus a $7 note from a unit of the Chase Corporation of Auckland, would not be in the best interests of shareholders, said Stuart D.

headline: Walters Hopeful on Hostages
abstract: LEAD: Vernon A. Walters, the United States representative at the United Nations, said today that he was optimistic that his recent discussions with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria would result in some movement affecting the fate of hostages held in Lebanon.

headline: Economic Scene; Peering Ahead Through a Fog
abstract: LEAD: PRESIDENT TRUMAN longed for a one-armed economist who would not keep saying ''on the one hand . . . on the other hand.''

headline: Prices of Crude Oil Slip Amid Gulf Uncertainty
abstract: LEAD: Prices of crude oil and petroleum products sagged on world markets yesterday, reacting to a day of inconclusive developments in the Persian Gulf.

headline: Correction
abstract: LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about airline crews involved in a near-collision over the Atlantic last week misstated the number of trans-Atlantic air routes between Britain and Ireland and Canada. There are six, as shown in an accompanying map on Saturday, not five.

headline: Plessey Bid For Harris Is Reported
abstract: LEAD: The Plessey Company, a British electronics concern, has apparently expressed an interest in buying all or part of the Harris Corporation, an American maker of classified communications equipment. But the Pentagon opposes a possible deal for national security reasons, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Company News; Holmes a Court Seeks 15% of Texaco
abstract: LEAD: Robert Holmes a Court yesterday asked for Federal clearance to increase his stake in Texaco Inc. to 15 percent.

headline: Correction
abstract: LEAD: The selective guide to classical music last Sunday in The New Season, part 2 of The Times Magazine, incorrectly identified the stage director of the Minnesota Opera's production of ''Die Fledermaus.'' The director will be Dorothy Danner. Also, John Cage's first opera was misidentified in the guide.

headline: Shareholders Fight Jim Walter Buyout
abstract: LEAD: The Jim Walter Corporation said a shareholder suit in Florida charges that its directors and officers violated their fiduciary duties in accepting a $60-a-share, or $2.43 billion, friendly offer from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Jim Walter said the suit charged that its board ''unfairly favored Kohlberg, Kravis over the other bidders for reasons other than the objective merits of the offer.

headline: Iranian Says Arms Affair Guides U.S. Actions
abstract: LEAD: Hojatolislam Ali Khamenei, the President of Iran, asserted yesterday that the United States was deliberately ''dragging the Persian Gulf to war'' in response to domestic political pressures, including President Reagan's need ''to project himself as a powerful and decisive person'' after the Iran-contra affair.

headline: Canada Examines 174 Said to Be Refugees
abstract: LEAD: A group of 174 people who claim to be refugees from India arrived at a tiny fishing village in Nova Scotia off Canada's east coast today, Federal Immigration Minister Benoit Bouchard said.

headline: Afghan-Pakistani Talks Set
abstract: LEAD: United Nations-sponsored talks between Afghanistan and Pakistan will resume Sept. 7 in Geneva for three days, at Afghanistan's request, United Nations officials said today. The last round of talks was held in February.

headline: New Soviet Interest in U.N. Broadens
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union's call for a United Nations naval force in the Persian Gulf is the latest sign of a new interest by Moscow in using the organization's peacekeeping machinery to advance Soviet interests, diplomats say.

headline: House Votes Toshiba Curb
abstract: LEAD: The House of Representatives voted today to ban sales of Toshiba products from stores on American military bases in retaliation for illegal sales of advanced technology by a Toshiba subsidiary to the Soviet Union.

headline: A Speedy Way to Encode Material
abstract: LEAD: MOST people even vaguely familiar with computers are aware of two varieties of disks, hard and floppy, on which programs and data are stored. But the lesser-known cartridge disk has lately been gaining popularity with computer users.

headline: Glasnost Tested in Victorian Setting
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet general beamed as an audience of about 3,000 booed at a spokesman for the Reagan Administration who was defending Government policy on Nicaragua.

headline: June Spending Up 0.7% As Incomes Gained 0.4%
abstract: LEAD: Consumer spending climbed seven-tenths of 1 percent in June, the best showing in two months, even though Americans' incomes rose a much more modest four-tenths of 1 percent in the month, the Government reported today.

headline: For Texas Bank, a Maverick With a Plan
abstract: LEAD: A. Robert Abboud, whose career as a banker and financier has been long and stormy, is getting another chance to prove himself as he takes over the First City Bancorporation of Texas.

headline: ARCO Rating Rise Studied
abstract: LEAD: The long-term rating on about $6.8 billion of debt issued by ARCO is under review for possible upgrading, Moody's Investors Service said yesterday.

headline: DOW JUMPS 25.83 POINTS, TO 2,519.77
abstract: LEAD: The Dow Jones industrial average, propelled by news events affecting several of its component companies, soared 25.83 points yesterday, to a new high of 2,519.77.

headline: Copenhagen Airport Struck
abstract: LEAD: A strike by fuel transport workers at Kastrup Airport in Copenhagen today caused delays and cancellation of some flights, airport officials said. About 70 fuel truck drivers refused to work to protest a reduction of their hourly Sunday wage, which is higher than the weekday wage.

headline: Honda Raises Prices on Cars
abstract: LEAD: The Honda Motor Company said today that it had raised suggested retail prices an average of 2.9 percent, or $307, on 1988 models of its Civic and Accord cars over comparable 1987 models.

headline: Late Rally Lifts Dow To 2,665.82
abstract: LEAD: The stock market snapped back yesterday in late trading on a wave of buying by bargain hunters and by investors who had been selling short.

headline: Minority Business
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Top Fund Manager Overcame '81 Loss
abstract: LEAD: George Soros, the New York investor who took a seat last week on the board of Fairchild Industries, the military contractor, is a superstar among money managers.

headline: Great Northern
abstract: LEAD: The Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation said it had completed its previously announced acquisition of the forest-products unit of the Owens-Illinois Corporation for $1.15 billion. Great Northern said the newly acquired business would be renamed Nekoosa Packaging and would be operated as a separate division.

headline: U.S. Threatens Japan in Talks
abstract: LEAD: Washington may restrain Japanese construction companies from doing business in the United States if talks this week fail to find a way to open the giant Kansai International Airport project to foreign companies, an American official said. J. Michael Farren, the

headline: 5-Year Stock Rally: The Far-Reaching Impact
abstract: LEAD: The bull market in stocks, which five years ago began a climb that is still breaking records, has changed the face of corporate America.

headline: ZAYRE TO TAKE BIG WRITE-OFF
abstract: LEAD: In an unusual move, the Zayre Corporation, one of the nation's largest discounters, said it would take a $40 million write-off in the current quarter to cover markdowns and ''competitive repricing'' planned for its major division, the 340 Zayre discount stores.

headline: Another Bid For Storehouse
abstract: LEAD: A small British engineering concern, Benlox Holdings P.L.C., has started a $3.35 billion bid for Storehouse P.L.C., a huge British retailing group that owns the Conran household-goods chain.

headline: Guarantees At Newmont
abstract: LEAD: The Newmont Mining Corporation, the latest target of the investor T. Boone Pickens, disclosed today that its board had recently approved employment contracts for 25 executives in an apparent move to discourage a takeover.

headline: Advertising; New Publisher For The Nation
abstract: LEAD: After a decade as publisher of The Nation, Hamilton Fish 3d is turning over the job to Arthur L. Carter, the former investment banker who is also major owner of the venerable magazine.

headline: Campbell Pursues Dry-Soup Market
abstract: LEAD: The Campbell Soup Company has introduced a line of instant dry soups called Campbell's Cup to compete directly with Thomas J. Lipton Inc.'s best-selling Cup-a-Soup. The new product is an important step for Campbell, which dominates the canned-soup market with an 82 percent market share but has been slow to break into the rapidly growing dry-soup market.

headline: Tempo Antacid
abstract: LEAD: The Thompson Medical Company, which acquired Tempo Antacid from Procter & Gamble two weeks ago, has consolidated the advertising at Rosenfeld, Sirowitz, Humphrey & Strauss, which already handles three other Thompson brands. The budget, which is $4 million, will be spent on network television advertising.

headline: UIS Bid Seeks Most of Walbro
abstract: LEAD: UIS Inc. made an unsolicited offer of $57 million today for more than half of the stock of the Walbro Corporation, a manufacturer of engine fuel systems in Cass City, Mich.

headline: Allegis Expected To Lay Off 250
abstract: LEAD: The Allegis Corporation will soon announce the layoff of about 250 executives in a drive to cut costs, company sources said. The sources also said that some top Allegis executives would be given more responsibility while others would be reassigned. The sources did not give details. The move is part of the new management structure being put in place by Frank A.

headline: Allegheny Secures New Credit Line
abstract: LEAD: Allegheny International Inc., the troubled industrial and consumer products company, said it had reached a new revolving-credit agreement with a consortium of banks. The company said the agreement prohibits payments of dividends and requires it to maintain certain levels of net worth.

headline: A Haiti Vacation Ends in Plane Crash at Sea for 4 Americans
abstract: LEAD: Francis Randall, a 55-year-old history professor at Sarah Lawrence College, remembers that the light plane crashed into the darkened ocean with a ''terrific jolt.''

headline: CHINESE PARTY EXPELS PLAYWRIGHT
abstract: LEAD: A leading Chinese playwright said today that he had been pressed to quit the Communist Party, suggesting that he had become the latest target of hard-line dissatisfaction against those who have spoken out against party policy.

headline: Pick a Country, Buy a Mutual Fund
abstract: LEAD: MUTUAL fund investors who want to venture into international waters typically consider two routes. They either buy a global fund, which invests in both American and foreign markets, or an international fund, which invests solely in foreign markets.

headline: Northwest Seeks Complaint Records
abstract: LEAD: Northwest Airlines said it had filed a Freedom of Information request asking the United States Department of Transportation to release the records of passenger complaints it has been seeking. Northwest, which was second only to Continental Airlines in the number of passenger complaints during the first six months of 1987, said it needed to know what the complaints were so that it could act on them.

headline: Advertising; Foote, Cone to Acquire Direct Response Shop
abstract: LEAD: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications has reached an agreement in principle to acquire Krupp/Taylor U.S.A., one of the largest direct response agencies in the country. The Los Angeles agency, which has annual revenues of $40 million has offices in eight cities. Details of the transaction were not disclosed.

headline: Computerland Sets Refranchise Plan
abstract: LEAD: The Computerland Corporation said it would refranchise its 41 company-operated stores as soon as possible, with those stores that are not refranchised to operate under a new decentralized management structure. Computerland is based in Oakland, Calif., and has 800 stores worldwide. It set up the company-operated stores in 1986 to maintain market presence in key areas where it was unable to maintain franchises.

headline: Bond Prices Up for Third Day
abstract: LEAD: Bond prices rose yesterday for the third consecutive session as the financial markets shrugged off the announcement of a record United States trade deficit for July.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN HONEYMOONS
abstract: LEAD: LAST year, in the clear skies above California's Napa Valley, some 75 couples exchanged vows aboard hot-air balloons, beginning their honeymoons with a flight over lush vineyards and rolling hills. ''Two of our pilots are ministers, and we can also provide a witness if needed,'' said Kenneth Custis, director of ground operations for Napa-based Balloon Aviation

headline: British Airways Shifts Agencies
abstract: LEAD: British Airways is assigning the United States portion of its advertising account to Backer & Spielvogel. The budget should be between $16 million and $18 million. The agency is a subsidiary of

headline: Treasury Prices Decline a Bit
abstract: LEAD: Treasury bond prices fell a bit further yesterday as lingering fears of inflation, underscored by the recent rise in oil prices, continued to cause nervousness in the credit markets.

headline: Costa Rica Journal; In the War on Want, Is There a Military Front?
abstract: LEAD: The red clay roads, newly cut into the jungle, are still being smoothed by bulldozers. Logging trucks and farmers with their herds of cattle will not be far behind.

headline: Telling the Truth?
abstract: LEAD:  NORTH

headline: FOR BANGLADESHI OPPOSITION, A CRICIAL PERIOD
abstract: LEAD: The monsoon rains are at their most pitiless now in Bangladesh, a country regularly victimized by wind and water.

headline: When the Password is a Passkey
abstract: LEAD: THE password for today is ''computer security.'' Members of a West German computer club disclosed earlier this month that they had successfully thwarted the security systems of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's computer network in Europe. For three months this summer the young computer enthusiasts, or hackers, had virtually unrestricted access to the agency's scientific data.

headline: Dome in Default On Most Loans
abstract: LEAD: Dome Petroleum Ltd. said it had defaulted on nearly all of its loans because some of its lenders were unwilling to extend an interim borrowing arrangement on terms acceptable to the company. Dome said that the default would not affect its daily operations and that it intended to continue making payments to lenders based on the provisions of an interim plan that is no longer in effect.

headline: F.T.C. to Fight Sale by Shell
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Trade Commission said today that it would seek a court order blocking the Pacific Resources Company from buying the Hawaiian petroleum-products assets of the Shell Oil Company.

headline: De Laurentiis
abstract: LEAD: The De Laurentiis Entertainment Group Inc., an independent film maker, said it was exploring financing alternatives that include a restructuring or combination with a third party. The company, headed by the Italian-born producer Dino De Laurentiis, said it had also amended its credit agreement with lender banks to avoid a possible default on its $52 million of bank debt.

headline: Progress Seen On Pasta
abstract: LEAD: American and European Community negotiators adjourned talks late today amid signs that prospects had improved for a settlement of the dispute over European subsidies of pasta exports.

headline: France Breaks Iran Ties and Isolates Embassy
abstract: LEAD: France severed relations with Iran today, and each country prohibited the other's diplomats from leaving.

headline: Casey Had 'Fall Guy' Plan As Early as '84, North Says
abstract: LEAD: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North said today that the plan to make him the ''fall guy'' for the Iran-contra operations was first suggested by William J. Casey as early as 1984 when the White House began its secret support for the Nicaraguan rebels.

headline: Stop Smoking, Earn More Money
abstract: LEAD: Richard Cullen, a packaging supervisor at the Adolph Coors Company, agreed to let his employer test him for health problems and then provide nutrition counseling to help him lose weight. His incentive? Coors will pay a higher percentage of his health claims than it will for his colleagues who refuse to participate in the company's ''wellness'' program.

headline: In Argentina, 2 Lost Instruments and Discord
abstract: LEAD: Two missing instruments, a cello and a double bass, stumped the mighty of culture and business Thursday night in their efforts to present great music within sight of these awesome jungle waterfalls.

headline: Proxy War Looms At Cleveland-Cliffs
abstract: LEAD: D. S. Kennedy & Company, a San Francisco-based investment firm, said that it might wage a proxy fight for seats on the board of the embattled Cleveland-Cliffs Inc. In a letter to Samuel K. Scovil, chairman of Cleveland-Cliffs, D. S. Kennedy said it was frustrated because it had been unable to dissuade Cleveland

headline: France Refuses to Back Chad Offensive
abstract: LEAD: France distanced itself today from the Chadian Government's campaign to retake a disputed border area from Libya. It called instead for the matter to be submitted to international arbitration.

headline: Zimbabwe to Drop White-Only Posts
abstract: LEAD: The lower house of Parliament voted today to abolish the practice of reserving seats for the country's tiny white minority.

headline: Minehead Journal; A Stately Home for Britain's Wards of the State
abstract: LEAD: Up from skid row, Freddie Hooper is living like a lord now - one of the ''dossers,'' or welfare recipients, newly ensconced in a 14th-century manor house purchased by an iconoclastic millionaire with a name and attitude straight from Dickens: Philip Stubbs.

headline: Japan's Global Surplus Down
abstract: LEAD: Japan's trade surplus with the United States rose 6 percent in July from a year earlier even though its global trade surplus fell almost 15 percent, the Government said today.

headline: Reebok Forecast Sends Stock Down
abstract: LEAD: The stock of Reebok International Ltd. dropped sharply today after the athletic shoemaker said it would post only marginal profit increases in the third quarter because of production delays in South Korea. Reebok's shares closed down $1.375, to $21, on the New York Stock Exchange. Reebook said that about two-thirds of its shoe production comes from South Korea.

headline: Ex-Chief of Intelsat Admits Fraud Guilt
abstract: LEAD: A former top official of Intelsat pleaded guilty today, along with two brokers, to charges that they participated in a scheme to obtain $4.8 million in connection with rigging construction and financing contracts for the satellite consortium's new headquarters.

headline: CBS SAYS SONY SEEKS RECORD UNIT
abstract: LEAD: CBS Inc. said yesterday that the Sony Corporation had inquired about buying all or part of the CBS records unit and added that it would ''consider and respond to Sony's inquiry in due course.''

headline: For Lower-Wage Tier, the Squeeze Is Tighter
abstract: LEAD: They sleep in bunk beds and on futons. Some use corners of rooms for storage. There is often a line to use the one bathroom.

headline: Dow Posts 3.75 Rise in Light Day
abstract: LEAD: The stock market was mixed in tentative, light trading yesterday, but the Dow Jones industrial average edged 3.75 points higher, to 2,570.17.

headline: U.S. Tentatively Decides to Raze Most of New Embassy in Moscow
abstract: LEAD: After months of discussion, the Reagan Administration has tentatively decided to raze and rebuild at least five floors of the new eight-story embassy building in Moscow at a cost of at least $92 million, according to senior Administration officials.

headline: TENSE GULF SEAMAN WATCH FOR THE TANKER WAR, IN VAIN
abstract: LEAD: Even the seamen caught up in the nocturnal ''tanker war'' have trouble finding it out there beyond the serene horizon.

headline: Angels
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor: No discussion about fashion designers and matching investors (''In Search of the Perfect Angel,'' Aug. 30) should pass over one of the most phenomenal successes in the industry, Liz Claiborne. Ms. Claiborne found her handful of investors - among them her husband, Arthur Ortenberg, his long-standing friend and University of Wisconsin roommate, Jerry Chazen, and a half-dozen relatives and friends - who altogether put $250,000 into forming Liz's business.

headline: Bonds Marketed By Florida Utility
abstract: LEAD: The Florida Power and Light Company is offering $100 million of 30-year bonds through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

headline: Ulster Soldier Killed
abstract: LEAD: Gunmen killed a part-time soldier with the Ulster Defense Regiment today as his family watched, the police said. They said the victim was the 70th victim of sectarian strife in Northern Ireland this year.

headline: Murdoch Backed
abstract: LEAD: The British Government gave the publisher Rupert Murdoch permission to buy the loss-ridden Today newspaper from Lonrho P.L.C. for $:38 million, or about $61 million. Mr. Murdoch's News International P.L.C. announced the proposed acquisition on Tuesday, noting that it required the approval of Lord Young, the Trade and Industry secretary.

headline: Wright Says Third Party Could Speak for Contras
abstract: LEAD: Jim Wright, the House Speaker, said today that the dispute over the role of the Nicaraguan rebels in peace negotiations might be resolved by having the rebels represented by third parties.

headline: Europe Technology Plan
abstract: LEAD: Ministers of 19 nations agreed today to include 58 new projects in Europe's Eureka program, which fosters cooperation on developing high technology to rival that of the United States and Japan. The decision raised the total value of approved Eureka ventures to $4.6 billion. The new ventures agreed to today will cost $820 million.

headline: UNMALLING AMERICA: W. Scott Toombs Building a Cozy 'Village' for Suburban Shoppers
abstract: LEAD: A FEW weeks before the opening of Princeton Forrestal Village, W. Scott Toombs, its developer, is puttering along Main Street in a golf cart, inspecting the storefronts that are the heart of his ''village'' - a hotel, office and shopping combine. The signs reflect a most up-to-date assemblage of retailers - Polo, Esprit, Cacharel - but the goal is for the overall development to give off the warm glow of a seasoned New England town.

headline: U.S. and Soviet Protest to Libya Over Iran Mines
abstract: LEAD: The United States and the Soviet Union sent separate messages of concern to Libya several days ago in an effort to stop the Libyans from sending Soviet-made mines to Iran, Administration officials said today.

headline: Commerce Choice Tells Of Doubt on Trade Law
abstract: LEAD: C. William Verity Jr., President Reagan's nominee for Commerce Secretary, said today that he would uphold the 1974 law linking American trade with the Soviet Union to the Kremlin's progress on permitting emigration, even though he believed the law was counterproductive.

headline: Orders Down 3.1% For Durable Goods
abstract: LEAD: Orders to the nation's factories for ''big ticket'' durable goods dropped in August, the first decline in seven months, as demand for military hardware and aircraft slumped.

headline: Dutch Sending 2 Ships To Hunt Mines in Gulf
abstract: LEAD: The Netherlands will send two mine-hunting vessels to the Persian Gulf to join Western efforts to keep the waterway open for international shipping, the Dutch Defense Minister said today.

headline: A President And Glasnost; His Speech on Soviet Reflects a Skepticism
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan gave a speech without a punch line today - a speech that seemed to be building up to the disclosure of some important new initiative or development in relations between the United States and the Soviet Union, but wasn't. Mr. Reagan's review of

headline: JURY SETS POLAROID DAMAGES
abstract: LEAD: A Federal District Court jury late today set damages in a class action suit against the Polaroid Corporation.

headline: GREECE UNVAILS U.S. LETTER ENDING RIFT OVER TERROR
abstract: LEAD: The Greek Government made public a letter from the United States Government today that was intended to end the friction over accusations that Greek officials had contacts with representatives of an Arab terrorist group.

headline: Non-Utility Electricity Rising
abstract: LEAD: As part of an effort to increase its profits, the Procter & Gamble Company recently announced that it would close a soap and detergent factory in Long Beach, Calif. The factory had been generating its own electricity and selling the excess to the local utility. Now, unless the company finds a buyer for the plant, that electricity will no longer be available.

headline: Chinese Leader Shuns Top Party Post
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang expressed reluctance today to assume permanent leadership of China's 44-million-member Communist Party, despite indications that he will be formally named its General Secretary next month.

headline: New World in Bid For Kenner Parker
abstract: LEAD: The makers of Monopoly today found themselves in a real-life battle of high finance.

headline: SOVIET PLANNING BIG LABOR SHIFT OUT OF INDUSTRY
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union plans to shift up to 20 million people from its industrial and agricultural work forces by the end of the century, using layoffs, mergers and a program of intense retraining, according to a leading Government economist.

headline: Montleigh Group
abstract: LEAD: Montleigh Group P.L.C. said it had agreed to acquire Pension Fund Property Unit Trust for $:271 million, or about $445 million. Montleigh is a British investment and development group.

headline: Tiffany in Munich
abstract: LEAD: Tiffany & Company, the 150-year-old jewelry retailer, said that it would open its second European shop later this year in Munich, West Germany. Tiffany, with eight stores in the United States, opened a shop in London in September 1986 and plans more stores in major European cities.

headline: Taiwan Shift On Exporters
abstract: LEAD: The Cabinet decided today to lift Taiwan's 38-year-old foreign exchange controls, removing a barrier that has kept the nation's massive foreign reserves from flowing to other countries.

headline: MCI Agrees to Acquire RCA Global From G.E.
abstract: LEAD: The General Electric Company has agreed to sell RCA Global Communications Inc., an international telex and data transmission business, to the MCI Communications Corporation.

headline: Kohl and Waldheim Meet Privately
abstract: LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who is vacationing in Austria, had an unannounced private meeting there Thursday with President Kurt Waldheim of Austria, spokesmen for the two leaders said today.

headline: Pension Deal Is Called Illegal
abstract: LEAD: The head of the Federal agency that guarantees pension plans asserted today that an agreement between the bankrupt LTV Corporation and its unions to enhance pension benefits for 100,000 workers was illegal and threatened the pension protection program for the entire nation.

headline: CRAZY EDDIE GROUP ENDS PARTNERSHIP
abstract: LEAD: Eddie Antar, the founder and chairman of Crazy Eddie Inc., and the First City Capital Corporation said yesterday that they had ended the partnership they formed to acquire the New York-based electronics retailer.

headline: SSC&B: Methodical Hunter
abstract: LEAD: MANY agency chief executives tell their people that the pursuit of new business is everybody's job. To which Spencer Plavoukos, chairman and chief executive of SSC&B, United States division, says, ''When you say that new business is everybody's business, it ends up nobody's business.''

headline: When Main Street Belongs to the Japanese
abstract: LEAD: FROM the surge of Japanese buying on Wall Street, to Fujitsu's attempts to buy Fairchild, to Mitsui Real Estate's purchase of the Exxon headquarters in New York City, it appears that something extraordinary is going on. There is. A Japanese ''investment wave'' is breaking across the United States, bringing the possibility of greater cooperation but also the threat of a further heightening of tensions.

headline: Perelman Seeks Stake in Salomon
abstract: LEAD: Ronald O. Perelman, the chairman of Revlon Inc., offered yesterday to outbid Warren Buffett, the Omaha billionaire, for a substantial minority stake in Salomon Inc., the parent company of Salomon Brothers, Wall Street's biggest investment banking house.
