headline: Contras Hint at New Tactics Under Pact
abstract: LEAD: Nicaraguan rebel leaders say they may suggest that President Reagan suspend their military aid on the condition that the Nicaraguan Government move to open the political process in accord with a Central American peace agreement.

headline: U.S. Clears 2 Kuwaiti Ships
abstract: LEAD: The United States Coast Guard today cleared the first two Kuwaiti oil tankers to fly American flags and be protected by American naval forces in the Persian Gulf. The White House said all that remained was for President Reagan to approve a date for beginning the convoy operations. The Administration has vowed to protect 11 Kuwaiti tankers from attack by Iranian forces.

headline: American Tells of Mozambique Raid
abstract: LEAD: An American, Mark van Koevering, gave a vivid account today of a massacre in Mozambique as anti-Government rebels and the South African Government repeated denials that they had been involved in the killing of 386 civilians in the town of Homoine.

headline: Brazil Softens I.M.F. Stance
abstract: LEAD: President Jose Sarney, signaling a more conciliatory tone toward Brazil's foreign creditors, has indicated his country could return to a formal agreement with the International Monetary Fund.

headline: U.S. Stole Software, Judge Rules
abstract: LEAD: Justice Department officials used ''trickery, fraud and deceit'' to steal computer programs from a company that devised a case management system for Federal prosecutors, a bankruptcy judge ruled today.

headline: 6 Dissident Jews Get Permission To Leave Soviet
abstract: LEAD: Several prominent Jewish campaigners who had been refused exit visas for many years on the ground they knew state secrets were told today that they would be allowed to leave the Soviet Union.

headline: Manufacturers Hanover Files for Stock Offering
abstract: LEAD: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation announced yesterday that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a public offering of six million shares of common stock. At yesterday's closing stock price of $40.75, off $1.375, the financing would be worth more than $240 million.

headline: A 15-Yard Span Over a Great Divide
abstract: LEAD: Every morning around 9:30 a Jordanian soldier in a powder blue uniform carrying a small bundle under his arm walks to the middle of the Allenby Bridge, which spans the Jordan River.

headline: High-Level Shift at Northrop
abstract: LEAD: In a move indicating the Stealth bomber is nearing production, the Northrop Corporation today named a high-level corporate official to the No. 2 spot in its secret Advanced Systems division.

headline: Advertising; Katsoff Is Publisher Of Psychology Today
abstract: LEAD: Sherwood (Woody) Katsoff, one-time publisher of Hearst's Science Digest, has become publisher of Psychology Today, now published by the American Psychological Association.

headline: Record Corn Yield Seen
abstract: LEAD: A survey of nine Middle West states released today suggests that the 1987 corn crop could produce record yields this autumn. Agrivisor Services Inc., an arm of the Illinois Farm Bureau, predicted an average American corn yield of 120 bushels an acre. That would break last year's record of 119 bushels an acre, Jim Quinton, grain market analyst with Agrivisor, said.

headline: Transamerica Active Again
abstract: LEAD: TAKEOVER rumors are again circulating around the Transamerica Corporation, with shares in the big insurance company jumping $3.625 yesterday to close at $44.25 in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Advertising; Lowe Marschalk Gets Antonovich Furs Work
abstract: LEAD: Antonovich Furs announced yesterday afternoon that it was assigning its advertising creative work to Lowe Marschalk. Earlier in the day Jerry Della Femina, chairman of Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, reported that the agency had resigned the Antonovich Furs account that was being handled by the Della Femina,

headline: HAITI PROTEST LEADERS REJECT CONCESSIONS
abstract: LEAD: The leaders of the protests that racked Haiti this week said today that ''too much blood has flowed'' for them to accept concessions, and they vowed to redouble their efforts to topple the Government.

headline: U.S. ACTS TO RUSH COPTERS TO SWEEP MINES IN THE GULF
abstract: LEAD: The Pentagon has ordered eight minesweeping helicopters to be flown immediately to the Persian Gulf to assist American naval forces in searching for mines in shipping channels and destroying them, officials said today.

headline: Toyota to Offer A Luxury Line
abstract: LEAD: Toyota Motor Sales Inc., trying to shed its economy-car image and lure more affluent buyers, said today that it planned to set up a new dealer network called Lexus to sell a luxury car line in the United States by 1989.

headline: Demjanjuk Trial Delayed
abstract: LEAD: The trial of John Demjanjuk, held up when one of his judges had a heart attack, will resume on Oct. 26, the Israeli radio reported today. Mr. Demjanjuk, a 67-year-old former Ohio autoworker accused of being a sadistic guard at the Nazi death camp at Treblinka during World War II, went on trial before a three-judge Jerusalem court in February.

headline: VCR Dumping Inquiry
abstract: LEAD: The European Community said today that it had begun an inquiry into charges of dumping of video cassette recorders at unfairly low prices by South Korean and Japanese makers.

headline: A FRONT-RUNNER FOR COMMERCE POST
abstract: LEAD: Joe M. Rodgers, the United States Ambassador to France, emerged today as a leading candidate to head the Department of Commerce.

headline: Truce Unit Urged in Chad War
abstract: LEAD: Nigeria proposed creation of an observer force today to supervise a cease-fire between Chad and Libya and said their border dispute should be referred to the International Court of Justice.

headline: Sidewalk Franks
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor: ''Selling the Sidewalk Frank'' (July 26) focused on Wall Street offices, and why the level of the stock market influences the number of hot dogs being sold during the lunch hour. Unfortunately, the article overlooked the importance of blue-collar workers. Construction workers, postal workers, maintenance people and the like all have hearty appetites and provide the vendor with plenty of business, forming a line the length of a city block.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Dawn Sibley has been promoted to executive vice president-director of media and communications services at Ally Gargano/MCA Advertising.

headline: Advertising; Sugar Account to Grey
abstract: LEAD: Grey Advertising won the American advertising for the Sugar Association after a seven-way competition. The budget, close to $5 million, will include a consumer print and television campaign and is expected to break by the end of the year. The Washington-based association represents 24 major processors and producers of beet and cane sugar in this country.

headline: INQUIRY SHORTENS LIST OF WITNESSES STILL TO TESTIFY
abstract: LEAD: After Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter finishes testifying before the Iran-contra committees early next week, only five more witnesses are scheduled to appear before the hearings end, probably in early August.

headline: Doctor's Dismissal Spurs Israel Clash
abstract: LEAD: The abso lute truth about the fight that took place in the lobby of Jerusalem's Hadassah Hospital on the morning of Aug. 26 will probably never be known.

headline: North's View Is That of a Band of Patriots Opposed by a Hostile and Unreliable World
abstract: LEAD: To the White House that Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North has pictured this week, the world was an arena of unrelenting ideological struggle. The White House itself, mesmerized by the struggle, was a place where major questions went unasked and where much of the rest of official Washington was dismissed as thoroughly untrustworthy.

headline: Bolivia's Struggle to Revive Economy
abstract: LEAD: Every month, Bolivia's teachers go on strike for a few days because their paychecks are late. July's strike, in the middle of winter in Bolivia, lasted longer than usual because the teachers were also demanding pay increases.

headline: RAGE IN SEOUL COURT OVER THE SENTENCES FOR POLICE
abstract: LEAD: A wall of guards stood between Park Jong Ki and the policemen who tortured his son to death. As a court pronounced the policemen guilty on Saturday, Mr. Park lunged at the guards in a futile, frantic effort to reach his son's killers. Behind him, screams of rage and grief echoed in the crowded courtroom.

headline: Hunts Drop a Bank Lawsuit
abstract: LEAD: Lawyers for the Hunt brothers said today that the Hunts would drop their $10.2 billion conspiracy and antitrust case against their bank lenders.

headline: Affordability Of Homes Falls
abstract: LEAD: An index measuring the ability of the typical family to afford to buy a home edged down slightly in July because of small increases in prices and mortgage interest rates, a real estate trade group said today. The National Association of

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: IMMIGRATION RULES ARE EASED FOR NICARAGUAN EXILES IN U.S.
abstract: LEAD: The Reagan Administration announced today that it was easing immigration standards for the 200,000 Nicaraguan exiles in the United States, including those whose requests for asylum were turned down and who face deportation.

headline: Mitsubishi C.D.'s
abstract: LEAD: The Mitsubishi Bank Ltd.'s New York branch is offering $50 million of 8 5/8 percent certificates of deposit due in 1990 at various prices through Morgan Stanley & Company. The notes are rated Aaa by Moody's and AA+ by S.&P.

headline: SAUDIS DENOUNCE IRAN 'CONSPIRACY'
abstract: LEAD: The Saudi monarchy sought the offensive in the war of invective with Iran today, opening its borders to the world press to issue a denunciation of ''criminal gangs'' and Iranian ''conspiracy'' in rioting last month in Mecca.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 29, 1987
abstract: LEAD: The Economy

headline: Japan's Export Stance Queried
abstract: LEAD: The United States expressed concern today that Japan had too few inspectors checking for illegal strategic exports to Communist countries, the International Trade and Industry Ministry said.

headline: Searle Refunds Set
abstract: LEAD: G. D. Searle & Company said it would make refunds to patients for prescription drugs that do not achieve the desired outcome. ''The refund applies if for any reason the doctor is not satisfied with the results,'' said Dr. Sheldon Gilgore, chief executive of the pharmaceutical company. ''It's unconditional.

headline: Company News; Rainier Bancorp
abstract: LEAD: The Rainier Bancorporation, based in Seattle, said its stockholders had approved the company's merger with the Los Angeles-based Security Pacific Corporation. The agreement provides for the exchange of 1.3 shares of Security Pacific common for each of the 22.3 million currently outstanding shares of Rainier.

headline: Amid Gold Boom, Skittishness
abstract: LEAD: It is hard to find an executive in the gold mining business in North America who does not believe that life right now is too good to be true. But whether that view means it is time to expand or time to bail out depends on whether the executive thinks the current gold boom will bring on the next bust.

headline: U.S. Sending Small Craft
abstract: LEAD: The United States has decided to send some of its smallest naval vessels to the Persian Gulf because it is unable to obtain more suitable minesweeping vessels from its allies, Government officials said today.

headline: JWT Deal Concluded
abstract: LEAD: Britain's WPP Group announced yesterday that it had completed the acquisition of the JWT Group, parent of the J. Walter Thompson agency, having completed its tender offer and receiving 97 percent of the shares outstanding for $55.50 a share.

headline: EX-CONTRA IS EXILED TO FISHING
abstract: LEAD: Having trawled through a revolution and a counterrevolution in the last decade, Eden Pastora Gomez, the former Sandinista and contra commander, is casting a shorter line these days.

headline: Iran's 'Spasm' And Oil Prices
abstract: LEAD: HOW serious are the risks of a war in the Middle East that would close the Persian Gulf and send oil prices spiraling upward? The Iranian leaders have been making threats that have caused the oil market to shiver and shake.

headline: EVEN IN YUGOSLAVIA, A RICH-POOR SPLIT
abstract: LEAD: Slovenes are political realists, so no one here in their capital raises the subject of separating from Yugoslavia except to reject it.

headline: Help Lessens For 3d World
abstract: LEAD: Developing countries received 15 percent less money from the rest of the world in 1986 as a result of a sharp cut in private bank lending and a drop in net export credits, according to the O.E.C.D.

headline: NEW ON 6:25 FROM LEIPZIG, YOUNG EAST GERMANS
abstract: LEAD: The train from Leipzig that rolls into Cologne's main station at 6:25 P.M. carries a new category of passengers these days - young East Germans who are being allowed to visit relatives and friends in West Germany.

headline: Local Solutions for Local Problems
abstract: LEAD: UNDER the coherent urban policy of the Reagan Administration, which has concentrated on revitalizing the national economy while encouraging local initiative, America's long-depressed urban areas are on the mend.

headline: Group Assails Soviet on Inmates
abstract: LEAD: Soviet political prisoners face harsh treatment and grueling labor in camps and jails despite social changes instituted under Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the international human rights group Amnesty International said in a report issued today.

headline: Pulling Nitrogen From the Air
abstract: LEAD: MANY farmers around the world cannot afford the nitrogen fertilizer they need. The long-term supply outlook for oil and gas, the key source of nitrogen fertilizer, is poor. And many utilities have electricity they cannot sell, at least in the short term.

headline: FACES QUESTIONING TODAY
abstract: LEAD: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North delivered sets of his personal records to the Congressional investigative committees today, a day before he was to be interrogated for the first time about his central role in the Iran-contra affair.

headline: Dainippon May Lift Bid for Reichhold
abstract: LEAD: Dainippon Ink and Chemicals Inc. said today that it might increase its $52.50-a-share takeover offer for Reichhold Chemicals Inc.

headline: PPG Selling Potash Unit
abstract: LEAD: PPG Industries said it would sell its potash business to Sullivan & Proops of Chicago. Terms were not disclosed. PPG Industries said that potash, a key ingredient in fertilizer, accounted for less than $100 million of its 1986 total sales of $4.7 billion. PPG Industries is based in Pittsburgh.

headline: Market Place; Tax Maneuver By Japanese
abstract: LEAD: ON the face of it, Northeast Utilites had a busy day on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, with almost 17.9 million of the big utility holding company's shares changing hands. But the figures did not tell the whole story, just as when Houston Industries, another utility, traded 24.5 million shares, or 10 percent of the Big Board's total volume, on Aug.

headline: Washington Weighs Policy
abstract: LEAD: Important decisions for fiscal and monetary policy are expected this week as Congress works on an agreement to reduce budget deficits in future years while Federal Reserve officials meet today and tomorrow to set the course for monetary policy.

headline: IN THE ARCTIC TUNDRA, THUNDER OF OTTAWA'S MILITARY BUILDUP
abstract: LEAD: More than four centuries after the English adventurer Sir Martin Frobisher found this place, new intruders are disturbhg the Arctic peace.

headline: Africans Say Spanish Show Racist Views
abstract: LEAD: They are few in number and speak quietly so as not to draw attention to their often-illegal status, yet they always stand out because of the color of their skin.

headline: Robert Bosch
abstract: LEAD: The Robert Bosch Corporation, of Broadview, Ill., said it would invest about $170 million by 1990 to produce antilock braking systems in its South Carolina plants. The company, a subsidiary of Robert Bosch G.m.b.H., of Stuttgart, West Germany, has previously imported the systems.

headline: IRAQ SAYS TROOPS REPELLED IRAN RAID
abstract: LEAD: Iraq said its forces repulsed an Iranian attack in an 18-hour battle today, and Iran said it bombarded Iraqi cities in reprisal for Iraqi air strikes on shipping, oil centers and factories.

headline: Advertising; Ayer Promotion
abstract: LEAD: N.W. Ayer has put James P. Foley, 54, in charge of its Latin American and Asia/Pacific divisions. He will assume posts vacated two months ago by David J. Dodd, who went to Paris to look after the Ayer agencies in France, Italy and Spain.

headline: Little Progress In Japan Talks
abstract: LEAD: Talks between the United States and Japan this week resulted in few achievements likely to dampen protectionist sentiment in Congress, trade officials said.

headline: Syria Delivers American Who Fled Beirut Captors
abstract: LEAD: An American journalist who got away from his kidnappers on the outskirts of Beirut was turned over to United States officials in Syria today.

headline: Nicaraguan Hope Rises For Independent Press
abstract: LEAD: Mechanics are oiling idle presses at La Prensa, the opposition newspaper, reflecting hopes that press freedom will soon be restored here under terms of a new Central American peace accord.

headline: Exemptions On Notification
abstract: LEAD: The Senate measure on plant closings includes a number of exemptions to the requirement for advance notice.

headline: Japan Surplus Outlook
abstract: LEAD: The Ministry of International Trade and Industry forecast on Friday that Japan's global trade surplus would decline about $18 billion in the 1987 fiscal year, which ends in March, from the 1986 surplus of $101.6 billion. Imports were expected to rise by $25 billion and exports by $7 billion. Private economists have said that a strong yen has lowered the price of imports, making them more attractive.

headline: Once Prussian Baroque, Now Polish
abstract: LEAD: The banner stretching across the blackened stone gate says, ''Western Pomerania -Forever Polish.''

headline: Taiwanese-Korean Pact
abstract: LEAD: Industrial leaders from Taiwan and South Korea agreed today to buy more from each other and less from Japan to help reduce their trade deficits with Tokyo. Delegates to a conference on Taiwanese-Korean economic cooperation said the strong yen had increased the two countries' deficits with Japan. South Korea's trade deficit with Japan was more than $3 billion in the first half, and Taiwan's was $2.54 billion.

headline: Bethlehem Order
abstract: LEAD: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said its freight car division had received an order from the Norfolk Southern Corporation for 500 covered hopper railroad cars, used for the shipment of cement. The division said it was the largest single order received since it was formed in August 1983. Each steel hopper car would hold 3,000 cubic feet.

headline: U.S. Ruling on Granite
abstract: LEAD: The United States International Trade Commission said today in a preliminary ruling that American granite producers were being injured by imports from Italy and Spain. A group of American granite producers and fabricators have charged that imports were being sold below cost. They have asked for duties ranging up to 241 percent of the imports' value.

headline: Wiesel, Critic on Waldheim, To Have Visit With the Pope
abstract: LEAD: Elie Wiesel, the Nobel laureate who severely criticized Pope John Paul II for meeting with President Kurt Waldheim of Austria, will visit with the Pope this month, American Jewish and Catholic officials said yesterday.

headline: The President As Avid Reader
abstract: LEAD: During Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter's testimony, the former national security adviser was asked about access to the President and Mr. Reagan's reading habits.

headline: Hirohito Is Said to Recover
abstract: LEAD: Emperor Hirohito was recovering satisfactorily following surgery Tuesday to alleviate an intestinal blockage, a Government official said today. The 86-year-old Emperor's vital signs were said to be normal. News reports said the Crown Prince Akihito, who is in charge of state matters during the Emperor's convalescence, and the Crown Princess Michiko will shorten their planned visit to the United States.

headline: Advertising; Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Nyack Hospital, a health care facility in Rockland County, to I. Goldberg & Partners.

headline: MGM Grand Air's Chief Is Starting a New Battle
abstract: LEAD: F. Michael Rogers, a former fighter pilot who shot down 12 enemy planes during World War II, will begin another aerial battle this week. The inaugural flight tomorrow of MGM Grand Air from Los Angeles to New York will open the latest effort by a wealthy investor to build a luxury airline by luring business travelers from the big commercial airlines.

headline: Israelis Decide Not to Construct Lavi Jet Fighter
abstract: LEAD: After months of wrenching debate, the Israeli Cabinet voted today to halt development of the Lavi fighter jet, which was to be Israel's main advanced combat aircraft for the 1990's.

headline: Plan to End Partnerships' Tax Break Is Opposed
abstract: LEAD: A Treasury proposal announced this week to end a special tax break for corporations that set themselves as up as master limited partnerships and sell their shares on stock exchanges met predictable resistance today from representatives of Wall Street and the partnerships.

headline: Alcatel Gets Bulk Of Belgian Orders
abstract: LEAD: Alcatel N.V., a joint venture of the ITT Corporation and the French concern Compagnie Generale d'Electricite, has won the bulk of a huge contract to modernize Belgium's telephone system, the telecommunications ministry said. Industry sources said the modernization would cost around 50 billion francs, or $1.3 billion, over five years, with 1.5 million new lines to be installed.

headline: Ford Tractor Plant
abstract: LEAD: The Ford Motor Company plans to retool its tractor plant in Romeo, Mich., to produce new engines by mid-1990. Ford has completed feasibility studies on the project, expected to cost more than $900 million, and will begin conversion of the 1.4-million-square-foot plant in mid-1988, a Ford executive said.

headline: In Iran, Food Is Better Gift Than Gold
abstract: LEAD: On the first day of the Persian New Year, the Government usually gives its employees a small gift of gold. This year, according to a longtime resident, the bonus was granted in food rations instead of precious metal.

headline: Paper in Britain Defies Ban on Spy Memoirs
abstract: LEAD: The Guardian defied a legal ban today and reported about the Government's battle in an Australian appeals court to stop the publication of a former British spy's memoirs in Australia.

headline: Europe, U.S. Agree on Pasta Subsidy
abstract: LEAD: The United States and the European Community said today that they had tentatively agreed on a plan to end the six-year-old dispute over the community's exports of subsidized pasta to the United States.

headline: B.P. to Build Pipeline
abstract: LEAD: Britain's Energy Department said today that it would authorize the British Petroleum Company to build a pipeline from its Wytch Farm oilfield in Dorset, which could help it to become one of Europe's most productive onshore fields.

headline: Odometer Shift Cited at G.M.
abstract: LEAD: As many as 2,000 odometers on General Motors Corporation trucks and utility vehicles were replaced or turned back during the last four years to conceal mileage accumulated on the vehicles by managers, The Oakland Press reported today.

headline: Patents; A Generating System To Reduce Acid Rain
abstract: LEAD: A power generation system patented this week by E. Stephen Miliaras, managing director of the Energotechnology Corporation of Cambridge, Mass., is expected to reduce acid rain and the emission of sulfur dioxide from coal-fired power plants.

headline: A Crucial Test for Thiokol
abstract: LEAD: Early Thursday afternoon a scrubby desert valley 22 miles west of here will erupt in a two-minute stream of fire that Morton Thiokol Inc., maker of the space shuttle's solid rocket boosters, hopes will begin to erase memories of the last 19 months.

headline: Intergraph to Buy Rights to Clipper
abstract: LEAD: The National Semiconductor Corporation has agreed to sell the rights to the Clipper microprocessor product line to the Intergraph Corporation. The sale, for what industry officials said was about $10 million, indicates that National is quickly moving to sell parts of the Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation, which it agreed to acquire from Schlumberger Ltd.

headline: Market Adds to Gains; Dow Up 8.61
abstract: LEAD: The stock market continued to regain the ground it lost early last week, and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 8.61 points, to 2,493.94.

headline: Mark IV: The Making of a Miniconglomerate
abstract: LEAD: SAL H. ALFIERO spends most of his time reading financial reports, or speaking softly into his phone, hidden behind a paper-laden desk that his secretary says he cleans twice a year with a garbage bag or two. The chairman of Mark IV Industries is, according to one associate, ''almost in the background, letting other people direct the traffic.

headline: In Talk With Polish Officials, Catholics Ask More Freedom
abstract: LEAD: Catholic intellectuals urged Communist officials at a meeting to grant more political freedoms and hold talks with Lech Walesa, participants said today.

headline: North's Legal Defense Fund Tops $1.4 Million After Panel
abstract: LEAD: More than $1.4 million in public contributions have poured in to the Oliver North Legal Assistance Fund since the former White House aide took the witness chair at the televised Iran-Contra hearings, fund officials say.

headline: DATA BANK: September 6, 1987
abstract: LEAD:           THE ECONOMY               Gross National Product   II Q'87   I Q'87   Year Ago        Annual rate, 1982 dollars, in billions    $3,796.0   $3,735.2   $3,665.7               Real G.N.P. Growth        Annual rate, 1982 dollars, in percent    2.6   4.4   1.1               Corporate After-Tax Profits   II Q'87   I Q'87   Year Ago        In billions, annual rate     $134.4   $136.6   $138.0

headline: RUSSIAN OPTIMISTIC ON MISSILE ACCORD
abstract: LEAD: A Soviet arms negotiator said today that an accord on medium- and short-range missiles could be concluded within two months, but he reaffirmed Moscow's insistence that American warheads designed to fit West German missiles must be eliminated.

headline: DiGiorgio Rejects Gabelli Proposal
abstract: LEAD: The DiGiorgio Corporation said its board had voted to reject as inadequate a recapitalization proposal made June 29 by an investment group led by Mario Gabelli of New York. The Gabelli group, which holds 28.6 percent of DiGiorgio, had proposed a plan under which shareholders would receive $20 in cash plus $8 in securities including new common stock.

headline: BRIEF WORDS ON BEING 'GENERALLY AWARE'
abstract: LEAD: Admiral Poindexter was questioned during yesterday's session about his conversations with high Administration officials in the period leading up to his resignation Nov. 25, 1986.

headline: Advertising; A Family Production For Revlon Shampoo
abstract: LEAD: Joan Lunden, the co-host of ABC-TV's ''Good Morning America'' who is about to take her third maternity leave, has contracted to make a commercial after the baby comes for a new Revlon product called Care For Kids Mousse Baby Shampoo.

headline: Economic Scene; The U.S. Role In Foreign Aid
abstract: LEAD: ON the eve of the annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, the United States is trying to make up for lost time by demonstrating that it is ready to tackle the world's serious economic and financial problems. At the head of the list is the inability of the developing countries to service their debts, which now exceed $1 trillion.

headline: Trade Plea From Japan
abstract: LEAD: Japan's trade minister, Hajime Tamura, plans to visit Washington for the second time in three months to try to head off protectionist legislation in Congress. He will leave Tuesday if Japan's Parliament approves, a ministry official said.

headline: New-Home Sales Up 0.5% in July
abstract: LEAD: Sales of new homes rose a modest five-tenths of 1 percent in July, the Government reported today. But recent increases in mortgage rates have analysts worried that the two-month upturn in sales will be short-lived.

headline: Market Place; A Busy Sector: Office Supplies
abstract: LEAD: THE computer's failure to bring about the much-promised paperless office and the strength of the national economy's service sector are proving a boon to companies that make paper, staples and other office supplies.

headline: Networks Take Turns In Covering Hearings
abstract: LEAD: The Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair will be televised live beginning at 9 A.M. on the ABC television network under the network rotation system. The hearings will also be televised on CNN, the Cable News Network, and on some local affiliates of PBS, the Public Broadcasting Service, including Channel 13 in New York.

headline: Venetian Gondoliers Protest
abstract: LEAD: Venice's gondoliers boycotted the city's annual Historic Regatta today and instead staged a demonstration against pollution, decay and an absence of traffic controls. More than 300 gondoliers took part in the demonstration, which followed the same route as the regatta, held every year on the first Sunday in September.

headline: Economic Scene
abstract: LEAD: AS Congress assembles today, the most pressing business it faces is enacting a budget for the 1988 fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1, and revising the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law to set new budget targets and establish new and constitutionally legal procedures for enforcing spending cuts to meet those targets.

headline: DOCTORS' DILEMMA: UNIONIZING
abstract: LEAD: Complaining of inadequate wages, poor working conditions and callous management, an unlikely group of workers in Minnesota is threatening to unionize: doctors.

headline: DOW RISES BY 75.23 FOR LARGEST GAIN IN A SINGLE SESSION
abstract: LEAD: The stock market surged higher yesterday, propelling the Dow Jones industrial average to its biggest single-day point gain ever.

headline: ESTONIAN SENT TO FACE DEATH IN SOVIET DIES IN A HOSPITAL
abstract: LEAD: Karl Linnas, who was deported from the United States in April to face a death sentence in the Soviet Union as a Nazi war criminal, died today of heart and kidney disease in a Leningrad hospital, the official Soviet press agency Tass reported.

headline: IRAN'S GUARDS TAKE THE LEAD IN THE MILITARY
abstract: LEAD: Iran's Revolutionary Guards, once regarded as an undisciplined group that used suicide tactics and terrorism to supplement conventional military forces, are gaining such new power in the military establishment that they may now be its dominant component, diplomats from several nations here say.

headline: British Developer Turns Attention to East Coast
abstract: LEAD: Tony Grant is coming to New York to develop property with the benefit of having the deep pockets of the Ladbroke Group P.L.C., a big diversified British company, to dig into.

headline: Havana Building Collapses
abstract: LEAD: Four people were killed and 15 were injured when a four-story apartment building partly collapsed in central Havana, the national news agency AIN reported today. President Fidel Castro went to the scene of the accident, which occurred Wednesday night in the old colonial part of the city. About 30 people lived in the building.

headline: VISIT BY SWEDE TO UNDERLINE BETTER U.S. TIES
abstract: LEAD: A recent improvement in Sweden's political relations with the United States will be formally underlined early next month when Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson goes to Washington for the first state visit there by a Swedish Prime Minister in 26 years.

headline: CPC Set Back in Lawsuit
abstract: LEAD: New York's highest court ruled yesterday that the state's key securities law does not allow a lawsuit to be brought by private parties against companies for violations of those laws.

headline: Five Foreigners Indicted In Illegal Export 'Sting'
abstract: LEAD: Federal law enforcement officials announced today that a Denver-based ''sting'' operation had resulted in the arrest of four West Germans and an Austrian on charges of illegally exporting technology to Cuba, North Korea and Bulgaria.

headline: Building Outlays Off A 2d Month
abstract: LEAD: Construction spending slipped by two-tenths of 1 percent in July, the second consecutive monthly decline, as weakness in apartment building and many nonresidential sectors continued to depress building activity, the Government reported today.

headline: Correction
abstract: LEAD: An obituary yesterday of Peter Fingesten, a Surrealist artist who founded the art department at Pace University, listed his survivors incompletely. He is also survived by a daughter, Alexandra.

headline: 4,000 Back at G.M.
abstract: LEAD: Two thousand workers out of work since the General Motors Corporation canceled the second shift at its Arlington plant in April 1986 are back on the job, along with 2,000 others out for the summer while the plant was being retooled. G.M. decided to recall most of the second-shift workers and give the plant new business after union officials agreed to a new local contract last year.

headline: President Resigns At Allied Stores
abstract: LEAD: Howard E. Hassler, who became president of the Allied Stores Corporation shortly after its merger with the Campeau Corporation last November, resigned that post yesterday to pursue personal interests.

headline: To Naval Officers, Poindexter Performance Is a Puzzlement
abstract: LEAD: When Navy officers are asked their impressions of Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter's performance before the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair, the response is slow in coming and usually accompanied by perplexed expressions.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, AUGUST 3, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  Markets

headline: Treasury Bond Prices Off Sharply
abstract: LEAD: Treasury bond prices fell sharply yesterday, raising yields to the highest level since December 1985, as traders and investors were discouraged by a worldwide move to higher interest rates and a heavy supply of Government securities.

headline: Patents; A Way To Treat Myopia
abstract: LEAD: DR. DONALD PRAEGER of New York, who practices and teaches ophthalmic surgery, was granted a patent this week for a method and lens to be used in treating myopia, or nearsightedness.

headline: Israel Delays Plane Decision
abstract: LEAD: Israel today delayed for a week a decision on whether to drop Israel's Lavi fighter plane project, officials said. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and Foreign Minister Shimon Peres agreed to ask the Cabinet to decide the Lavi's fate Aug. 30, aides to Mr. Peres said. The American Ambassador, Thomas Pickering, met Mr.

headline: Advertising; Lorimar Publishing Bought by President
abstract: LEAD: Donald E. Welch, 43 years old, who has been president of the Lorimar Publishing Group during the last five years, announced yesterday that he would be acquiring the children's publishing group from Lorimar Telepictures for an undisclosed amount of cash.

headline: Ex-Executive Loses Suit Against Thompson
abstract: LEAD: Marie Luisi, whose dismissal by the J. Walter Thompson Company in 1982 was the first inkling of a major scandal brewing at the company, last Tuesday lost her libel case against J.W.T. and Don Johnston, its former chief executive.

headline: Rig Count Up to 1,012
abstract: LEAD: The number of oil rigs drilling in the United States jumped above 1,000 last week for the first time in 17 months, despite new volatility in world markets that has sent crude oil prices skidding nearly $4 a barrel in the last month. The latest weekly count, released today by Baker Hughes Inc., the Houston-based oilfield services company, showed 1,012 rigs were operating, up 14 from the previous week.

headline: Company News; Women's Bank Is Recapitalized
abstract: LEAD: The First Women's Bank, a 12-year-old institution with a rocky financial history, said yesterday that contributions from 70 prominent New York entrepreneurs have raised its capitalization to more than $35 million, from less than $4 million.

headline: Patents; Chips 'Spray Painted'
abstract: LEAD: Semiconductor wafers used in electronic circuitry can be ''spray painted'' with an apparatus patented this week for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. As many as 15 wafers can be sprayed at once with layers of silicon or other materials that do not vary by more than one atom in depth.

headline: Business and the Law; Insurers Sued On Waste Sites
abstract: LEAD: IN a major battle with its insurance companies, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation has fired the first volley in a legal contest that is expected to last years and determine who must pay to clean up some of the most dangerous waste sites across the country.

headline: High OPEC Output Reduces Price of Oil To Four-Month Low
abstract: LEAD: Crude oil prices tumbled yesterday to their lowest levels since April.

headline: Oslo Widens Export Case
abstract: LEAD: Norway's state arms company, already embroiled in a dispute with Washington over high-technology exports to the Soviet Union, may also have sold equipment to China in violation of Western rules, the police said today.

headline: U.S. Attacks Israeli's Plan
abstract: LEAD: The State Department expressed strong opposition today to a proposal by an Israeli official that all Palestinians in the West Bank be expelled to Jordan. ''We utterly reject any notion that Palestinian residents of the occupied territories including the West Bank and Gaza should be encouraged or forced to leave their homes,'' Charles E.

headline: In August, Swedes Go a Little Wild With Louisiana Crayfish
abstract: LEAD: After hours of drinking, eating and revelry, Swedish sobriety is long gone. Those who can walk unassisted will be bragging about it tomorrow. One celebrant, a high-ranking corporate executive, is temporarily missing, having wandered off into the woods in a muddled haze.

headline: Business and Health; Retiree Benefits Cast a Shadow
abstract: LEAD: MOST large employers offer retirees continued health insurance benefits - but few have put aside funds to pay for them.

headline: Zambia's Economy
abstract: LEAD: President Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia pledged today to continue restructuring Zambia's rundown economy, despite his break with the International Monetary Fund three months ago. He told a news conference that details of the Government's new economic program would not be released until they have been approved by the Cabinet and leaders of the ruling United National Independence Party next week.

headline: Britain to Review Citizenship in War-Crimes Case
abstract: LEAD: The Home Office plans to review the citizenship status of a man reported to be a Nazi war criminal who lives in Scotland, according to a Government spokesman and representatives of a Los Angeles-based organization that investigates war crimes.

headline: INVESTING; A New Way to Bet on the Dollar
abstract: LEAD: Investors who want to speculate on the dollar can now buy foreign currency warrants on the American Stock Exchange. The warrants, which made their debut in June as part of a debt offering by the General Electric Credit Corporation, caught on quickly; Emerson Electric, Ford Credit, Sallie Mae and Xerox

headline: Advertising; Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Corbin Ltd., a maker of men's and women's apparel, to FCB/Leber Katz Partners.

headline: Dow Up 2.39 After Seesaw Session
abstract: LEAD: A stock market made nervous by disturbing news about the trade situation and oil prices had a seesaw session yesterday before closing mixed. While the Dow Jones industrial average managed to hit another record, broader market indexes retreated and more stocks fell than gained on the New York Stock

headline: House Reception Mixed To Accounting Report
abstract: LEAD: In a move to head off possible Federal regulations, a panel of accountants and other experts in financial reporting presented a series of recommendations today that they said would greatly reduce the incidence of undetected fraud in company reports.

headline: A Professor Is Seeking Duro-Test
abstract: LEAD: A member of the Yale University faculty who teaches business students how to spot undervalued companies has made an unsolicited $82 million takeover offer for the Duro-Test Corporation, a maker of long-lasting light bulbs.

headline: Foreign Concerns Cope With a Lower Dollar
abstract: LEAD: Volvo, the Swedish auto maker, continues to attract growing numbers of upwardly mobile buyers. The company sold 3 percent more cars in the first half of the year than it did in the comparable 1986 period. But Volvo probably does not feel much like celebrating.

headline: Advertising; People
abstract: LEAD: * Jerry Hostetter appointed vice president, corporate communications, at Triangle Industries.

headline: Filipino Mutiny Termed a Protest
abstract: LEAD: The colonel who led last month's abortive uprising in the Philippines says the mutiny was not an attempt at a military coup, but ''a gathering in the street of the military - some acoustic effects'' intended to protest the leadership of President Corazon C. Aquino.

headline: MAJOR CONFLICTS SEEN IN TESTIMONY OVER IRAN AFFAIR
abstract: LEAD: When the Iran-contra committees finish their public hearings next week and begin to prepare a final report, they will confront a hearing record riddled with conflicting and contradictory testimony.

headline: A Star of Iran Finds Destiny Against Him
abstract: LEAD: If Hojatolislam Ali Khamenei had his way, his first visit to the United States would have also been his first foray into international public relations. Using the United Nations for his pulpit, the Iranian President intended to portray his country as a victim of Iraqi aggression and to appeal to Americans' sense of fair play.

headline: Navistar Pact Extended
abstract: LEAD: The Navistar International Transportation Corporation and the United Automobile Workers union have agreed to an indefinite extension of contracts covering union workers in three states. The agreements had been set to expire at midnight on Sept. 30.

headline: Warburg Pincus
abstract: LEAD: An investment group led by Warburg Pincus Capital Partners, a New-York based investment firm, has raised its stake in Mattel Inc. to the equivalent of 20.1 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Warburg Pincus group said that it ''may from time to time acquire additional shares'' of the toy company, which is based in Hawthorne, Calif.

headline: NEWS SUMMAARY: SATURDAY, AUGUST 22, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL/2-5  Sgt. Clayton Lonetree was convicted on all 13 counts of espionage by a court-martial jury after a trial that had lasted two weeks. He is the first United States marine to be tried for spying. Page 1  A U.N. meeting will be boycotted by the United States. The conference will discuss how money saved under future disarmament agreements could be used to stimulate economic development.

headline: Reagan Latin Plan: Hole Gets Deeper
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan's Central America peace plan, proposed in part to demonstrate that the Administration was moving forward after the Iran-contra hearings, is instead causing the White House nothing but difficulty.

headline: Texas Air Bid Is Extended
abstract: LEAD: The Texas Air Corporation said it has extended its controversial tender offer for certain preferred stock held by employees of its Eastern Air Lines subsidiary. Texas Air said on Friday that the $16-a-share tender offer, which had been limited to 1,600,000 shares, has been extended to any and all shares tendered.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Casey's General Stores Inc., Des Moines, which operates 610 convenience stores in eight states, named Ronald M. Lamb chief operating officer.

headline: Dow Drops 2.23 Points, To 2,592.00
abstract: LEAD: The stock market closed mixed yesterday, with broader market gauges outperforming the blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average for a change.

headline: THE TESTIMONY: 'COULDN'T SEEM TO GET THEIR ACT TOGETHER
abstract: LEAD: Following are excerpts from the testimony of Donald T. Regan, the former White House chief of staff, before the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair, as recorded by The New York Times:

headline: Concern Reported in U.S. Military on Gulf Command Structure
abstract: LEAD: Some senior Navy officers have criticized command arrangements for operations in the Persian Gulf because responsibility is divided, officers said today.

headline: North Loses Walsh Appeal
abstract: LEAD: A Federal appeals court today rejected Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's argument that the independent counsel investigating the Iran-contra affair is operating under an invalid Justice Department regulation.

headline: Jaffna Journal; Fight Is Over for Tigers, and the Dream Recedes
abstract: LEAD: The downtown street bazaars here are teeming nowadays with crowds of shoppers, and the air rings constantly with loud bangs. For the first time in years, nobody jumps at the noise.

headline: War Stocks and the Weapons Pact
abstract: LEAD: IF Wall Street abhors uncertainty, it ought to be looking with particular unease at the prospects of the military contractors that make billions of dollars from the production of nuclear weapons.

headline: New Criticism Of Chip Policy
abstract: LEAD: After winning anti-dumping sanctions against Japanese computer chip makers for pricing their products too low, the Semiconductor Trade Association today assailed them for limiting production to raise prices artificially.

headline: For Nicaragua, Soviet Frugality Starts to Pinch
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union's refusal to increase aid to Nicaragua has produced an economic crisis here.

headline: Honeymoon at Bank Board
abstract: LEAD: Danny Wall, the new chief regulator of the $900 billion savings and loan industry, is enjoying his honeymoon while he can.

headline: Questions On Municipals
abstract: LEAD: An investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission into the legal status of dozens of tax-exempt bond offerings has revived questions about whether local government financings should be more strictly regulated by some Federal authority.

headline: Flurry of U.S. Issues Expected
abstract: LEAD: The logjam in Government security auctions that has disrupted the credit markets the last two weeks will soon begin to break up, the Treasury announced yesterday after Congress temporarily raised the Federal debt ceiling.

headline: Fed Is Said to Rebuff Treasury Pleas
abstract: LEAD: When the Federal Reserve Board raised interest rates earlier this month, Alan Greenspan, the Fed's new chairman, rebuffed appeals from the Treasury Department to ask West Germany and Japan to lower their rates at the same time, according to Administration officials.

headline: Meese Cautions China on Laws
abstract: LEAD: United States Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d reminded China today that it must provide attractive conditions to entice American investors, who have grown wary of what some call the inconsistency and unpredictability of the Chinese system.

headline: Top New York Official Resigns From S.E.C.
abstract: LEAD: Facing low morale in the New York office of the Securities and Exchange Commission and a threat of mass resignations, Kathleen A. Warwick, head of the office, resigned yesterday. She had been the agency's top regional official for less than a year.

headline: Advertising; Rise Seen In Ads for USA Today
abstract: LEAD: THE Gannett Company expects USA Today to round out 1987 with advertising revenues of more than $100 million, 40 percent higher than last year's total.

headline: West Germany Top Exporter
abstract: LEAD: West Germany has overtaken the United States as the world's top exporting nation, and Japan is close behind, according to figures compiled by the International Monetary Fund.

headline: NIELSEN ACQUIRES KEY RIVAL
abstract: LEAD: The Dun & Bradstreet Corporation said yesterday that it was expanding its A.C. Nielsen market-research operations by acquiring Information Resources Inc., a test-marketing company.

headline: Iranian Says Saudis Provoked Riots
abstract: LEAD: Iran's representative to the United Nations charged today that official Saudi provocateurs had prompted clashes in Mecca Friday in which hundreds were killed.

headline: Simon Investors To Buy Thrift Unit
abstract: LEAD: An investor group headed by William E. Simon, the former Treasury Secretary, said today that it had agreed to acquire the Western Federal Savings and Loan Association for $145 million - its largest acquisition yet in the savings industry.

headline: Stocks Fall Broadly; Dow Off 19.77
abstract: LEAD: Stocks fell broadly yesterday amid worries about inflation and Middle Eastern hostilities. Late selling in the credit markets also contributed to the decline.

headline: Advertising; Wall St. Still Sees Takeovers
abstract: LEAD: THE price activity in advertising stocks has settled down, but takeover rumors seem to have a life of their own.

headline: McDonnell Net Is Up 19.6%
abstract: LEAD: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, helped by strong gains from its space and missile systems operations, said yesterday that second-quarter earnings rose 19.6 percent on a 9.7 percent increase in revenues.

headline: Investor Disputes View About Cleveland-Cliffs
abstract: LEAD: The contrarian school of investing has taken its toll on many financial professionals in recent years, but David F. Bolger, who runs his own investment bank in Ridgewood, N.J., is not one of them.

headline: Market Place; 'Scores' Profit May Be Voided
abstract: LEAD: WARREN KORNFELD had made what he thought was one of his best investments.

headline: In India, 40 Years Free, Pride Turns to Bitterness
abstract: LEAD: Forty years ago, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru unfurled the flag of a new nation and spoke with hope of its ''tryst with destiny.'' Today, Nehru's grandson, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, governs an India shaken by violence and scandal, uncertain whether the years since independence have brought more problems than progress.

headline: 32 People Found Dead In South Korean Plant
abstract: LEAD: Thirty-two people, some of them children and most of them bound and gagged, were found dead in a factory today, news reports said.

headline: TOUGH QUESTIONING IS AWAITING MEESE
abstract: LEAD: When Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d made his startling announcement last November that profits from the Iran arms sale had been diverted to Nicaraguan rebels, he drew praise from even longtime detractors.

headline: Kerkorian to Buy 2 Las Vegas Hotels
abstract: LEAD: The financier Kirk Kerkorian said today that he would re-enter the gaming business by buying the Desert Inn Hotel and Casino and the Sands Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas from a company controlled by the estate of the late billionaire Howard Hughes.

headline: SOVIET ANSWER ON ARMS PLAN IS WELCOMED IN WASHINGTON
abstract: LEAD: The White House today welcomed Mikhail S. Gorbachev's statement that Moscow was prepared to agree to a worldwide ban on American and Soviet medium-range and short-range missiles.

headline: LEBANON FOOD PROTESTS SPREAD
abstract: LEAD: Protests over food prices spread today from the capital to other Lebanese towns as steel-helmeted Syrian soldiers with heavy machine guns continued to patrol the main shopping centers in mainly Moslem West Beirut to prevent further disturbances.

headline: NETWORKS TO GET MORE FOR ADS
abstract: LEAD: Despite people meters and increased competition from cable and syndicated television, the three major television networks are expected to get healthy price increases for advertising spots now being sold for this fall's prime-time season.

headline: Stake in Pan Am Is Sold by Resorts
abstract: LEAD: Resorts International Inc., the Atlantic City hotel and casino operator, said yesterday that it had sold its entire 12.2-million-share investment in the Pan Am Corporation.

headline: U.S. Won't Halt Military Aid to Haiti
abstract: LEAD: The State Department has decided to continue military aid to the army-dominated provisional Government in Haiti despite the killing of more than 35 demonstrators by soldiers this summer.

headline: Soviet Police Shadow Unofficial Publication
abstract: LEAD: Policemen showed up today at an apartment where several dissidents were typing copies of an unofficial magazine, Glasnost, and made arrangements to take the dissidents to the police station, the magazine's editor said.

headline: Reporter's Notebook; Panama Press
abstract: LEAD: In its campaign to break the momentum built up by eight weeks of protest rallies and demonstrations, the Government has found press censorship one of its most potent weapons.

headline: Third World's Prices Rising
abstract: LEAD: Prices paid by third world consumers are rising again, with inflation in Argentina hitting an annual rate of 98.3 percent in the first three months of this year, up from 78.5 percent in the last quarter of 1986, the International Monetary Fund said today.

headline: Group to Seek Crazy Eddie
abstract: LEAD: Entertainment Marketing Inc. said today that it had formed a partnership to wage a proxy fight for control of Crazy Eddie Inc., the New York-based electronics retailer. The group now controls more than 11 percent of Crazy Eddie.

headline: No Arms Sales to Iran, Soviet Reassures Arabs
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union has assured the Arab countries that it would not sell arms to Iran, Iraq's foe in the Persian Gulf war.

headline: In Canada's North, Spread of AIDS Is Feared
abstract: LEAD: If the uninhibited sexual mores of young Eskimos lead to an AIDS epidemic in Canada's far north, it will not be because Nader Barsoum didn't try to prevent it.

headline: Reagan Holds Talk With Key Politician From South Korea
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan talked today with Roh Tae Woo, the presidential candidate of the South Korean ruling party, and White House officials were quick to emphasize that the meeting was not an endorsement of Mr. Roh's candidacy.

headline: Patents; Process for Clinical Use Of Magnetic Bacteria
abstract: LEAD: Dr. Brian B. Schwartz, professor of physics at Brooklyn College, and Nancy Blakemore, a member of the technical staff at the Biomagnetech Corporation in Durham, N.H., were awarded a patent this week on the clinical use of magnetic bacteria. Patent 4,677,067 was assigned to the company.

headline: Chopped Liver and Yiddish, but Where's the Soul?
abstract: LEAD: The single synagogue in this city, the capital of the Jewish Autonomous Region, is a small log building with a rocky front yard that lies 100 yards down an unpaved street.

headline: RUSSIANS FAULTED IN AFRICAN CRASH
abstract: LEAD: A Soviet flight crew that ignored an alarm and descended in darkness caused the crash that killed President Samora M. Machel of Mozambique and 34 others, an international board of inquiry said today.

headline: Advertising; Rosenfeld, Sirowitz Loses Fragrance Lines
abstract: LEAD: Rosenfeld, Sirowitz, Humphrey & Strauss lost $6 million in business as a result of Revlon's acquisition of the Charles of the Ritz fragrance brands. Revlon decided go in-house with the Dynasty Collection, Jean Nate and Enjoli lines to save money and consolidate advertising. The agency handled the account for four years.

headline: The Iran-Contra Hearings at a Glance
abstract: LEAD:  Richard V. Secord: Retired Air Force major general and an associate of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North

headline: Advertising; People
abstract: LEAD: * Richard W. Stevenson has joined Edwin Bird Wilson Inc. as executive vice president and executive creative director.

headline: South Korea Struggles to Find Its Future
abstract: LEAD: FOR the moment, the streets of Seoul are quiet. The student and church radicals who led the demonstrations last month are on vacation or regrouping after winning major concessions. And economic growth, always a point of national pride, is still as lusty as ever.

headline: Lebanese Editor Shot As He Drives in Beirut
abstract: LEAD: The Lebanese editor who disclosed the secret sale of American arms to Iran was shot and seriously wounded today in West Beirut.

headline: Bundy to Be Sold
abstract: LEAD: The Bundy Corporation, a Warren, Mich., manufacturer of precision tubing, said it had agreed to be acquired by TI Group P.L.C. of London, a diversified maker of tubes and appliances, for about $144 million in cash. TI has formed a subsidiary to conduct the $40-a-share tender for Bundy's 3.5 million publicly held shares and has already locked up about 47.5 percent of the stock.

headline: Israeli, at U.N., Outlines Plan For a Mideast Peace Parley
abstract: LEAD: Israel's Foreign Minister, Shimon Peres, today outlined an eight-point proposal for an international peace conference on the Middle East.

headline: British Caledonian To Study Options
abstract: LEAD: Executives of money-losing British Caledonian Airways will meet this weekend to decide on their next move after the Government blocked a merger agreement with British Airways. An airline official said a decision would be announced by Monday.

headline: Pentagon Procedures Criticized
abstract: LEAD: Richard Godwin, who resigned last week as the Pentagon's acquisition chief, told the Senate Armed Services Committee today that the Defense Department ''may have lost ground'' in the last year in its effort to buy weapons efficiently.

headline: Exxon Net Rises 3.6% In Quarter
abstract: LEAD: The Exxon Corporation, the Shell Oil Company and the Occidental Petroleum Company yesterday reported higher second-quarter profits resulting from the gradual rise in crude oil prices. But the Phillips Petroleum Company and the Pennzoil Corporation reported lower profits.

headline: Thai Piracy of Software
abstract: LEAD: The United States computer industry is pressing Thailand for greater protection from computer software piracy. ''Thailand should follow all other nations in the region - Korea, Singapore, Malaysia and Indonesia - in granting copyright protection to software,'' Oliver Smoot, acting president of the Computer and Business Equipment Manufacturers Association, said in a statement.

headline: Chief at Continental Yields to Lorenzo
abstract: LEAD: The resignation of Thomas G. Plaskett, an experienced executive hired last November as president and chief executive of Continental Airlines, was announced today, one day after the carrier reported a larger-than-expected quarterly loss.

headline: British Editor Retires
abstract: LEAD: Lord Hartwell, chairman and editor-in-chief of Britain's Daily Telegraph and Sunday Telegraph newspapers, is retiring after a 30-year career, The Sunday Telegraph announced. He will be succeeded by Conrad Black, a Canadian businessman who owns a majority interest in The Daily Telegraph Ltd. Lord Hartwell, 76 years old, will remain a director of the company.

headline: POLITICAL PRISONERS STILL A CONTENTIOUS ISSUE IN SEOUL
abstract: LEAD: Now that President Chun Doo Hwan has agreed to sweeping democratic changes, Lee Kyong Eun wants her husband back.

headline: Peru Clarifies Banking Policy
abstract: LEAD: The Government will not expropriate foreign bank branches in Lima as part of its plan to nationalize Peru's private banks, the Prime Minister, Guillermo Larco Cox, said today.

headline: Pretoria Plans Tough Laws as Mine Strike Goes On
abstract: LEAD: The South African Government said today that it planned to introduce tougher labor laws giving ''more protection'' to employers.

headline: Soviet Is Reported to Deploy a Rail-Mobile Missile
abstract: LEAD: Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, said on the floor of the Senate today that the Soviet Union had begun to deploy the new SS-24 intercontinental nuclear missile, the first that can be moved on and fired from rail cars.

headline: INVESTING; Bright View of Colonial Life
abstract: LEAD: Life insurers have been getting low marks from investors lately because of concerns that AIDS and proposed changes in accounting rules could depress earnings. But last Monday the shares of the Colonial Life and Accident Insurance Company jumped $2, to $27, in over-the-counter trading.

headline: A Cautious Europe Cheers U.S.-Soviet Moves on Arms
abstract: LEAD: The tentative Soviet-American agreement on medium-range missiles was widely hailed across Europe today, but the cheers were interspersed with notes of caution and anxiety about the preponderance of conventional weapons this would leave the Russians and the effect the agreement would have on the Western alliance.

headline: Becor Might Get A Higher Offer
abstract: LEAD: Bear, Stearns & Company said that it was studying whether to sweeten its $250 million bid for Becor Western Inc. The New York investment firm's $15-a-share offer, made with the Chicago-based ICM Industries, was topped last week by the Lynch Corporation, which offered Becor shareholders $16.50 a share in cash, or bonds and stock with a face value of $27.25 in the new corporation.

headline: 7-ELEVEN OWNER IN $5 BILLION DEAL TO SELL COMPANY
abstract: LEAD: The Southland Corporation, which operates the 7-Eleven stores, said yesterday that it would be taken over by a company owned by Southland's founding Thompson family in a deal valued at about $5.1 billion.

headline: SOVIET GIVES CITIZENS POWER TO APPEAL CIVIL RIGHTS ABUSE
abstract: LEAD: The Supreme Soviet enacted a new law today giving citizens, for the first time, the right of legal appeal against actions of public officials in violation of their rights.

headline: Filipino Communists to Escalate Urban Warfare
abstract: LEAD: Communist rebels say they have recently escalated their struggle against the Government to a new stage of urban warfare and plan to take advantage of what they see as an instability after the coup attempt a week ago.

headline: PIP Rejects Offer From Kane-Miller
abstract: LEAD: Postal Instant Press said that it had rejected as inadequate a takeover offer of $18.50 a share, or $77.3 million, made earlier this month from a group led by the Kane-Miller Corporation. Thomas C. Marotto, president and chief executive of the franchiser of 1,100 instant printing centers, said directors, who met Thursday, concluded that ''now is not the time to sell the company in terms of realizing full value for our shareholders.

headline: Oslo Expels 3 Russians
abstract: LEAD: Norway said today that it had asked three Soviet officials to leave the country, saying they had tried to obtain sensitive submarine technology. It said the Soviet Union, in turn, had expelled a Norwegian diplomat.

headline: Advertising; McDonald's Files Suit Against Alberto-Culver
abstract: LEAD: The Alberto-Culver Company's butter substitute Molly McButter has prompted the McDonald's Corporation to file a suit in Federal District Court in Chicago against Alberto-Culver for trademark infringement.

headline: Resource Fund Strong in '87
abstract: LEAD: MUTUAL funds that invest primarily in natural resource stocks - a traditional hedge against inflation - are gaining in popularity after a generally ho-hum year in 1986.

headline: Sears Profits Rise by 37%
abstract: LEAD: Sears, Roebuck & Company said today that its second-quarter earnings rose 37 percent, largely because of a $58 million after-tax gain from the sale of its Sears Savings Bank branch offices in California and because of record earnings from its Allstate insurance unit.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, JULY 7, 1987
abstract: LEAD: International A2-11

headline: Patents; Processing of Metals For Space Shuttle Use
abstract: LEAD: A method of processing metals and alloys at high temperature and low gravity that was patented this week is planned for use on the space shuttles. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has provided funding for experimental operation.

headline: From Air and Sea, Iran-Iraq 'Tanker War' Heats Up
abstract: LEAD: Iraqi warplanes and Iranian naval vessels hit eight ships in about 36 hours in the Persian Gulf in the most concentrated assault on shipping since the Iran-Iraq war began in 1980, according to reports from the region today and Wednesday.

headline: Crazy Eddie Suitor May Act
abstract: LEAD: Entertainment Marketing Inc., a Houston-based consumer products distributor that has pursued a takeover of Crazy Eddie Inc. in recent months, said today that it may seek permission to acquire more than 25 percent of the company.

headline: New Charges Are Filed On Hijacking Suspect
abstract: LEAD: New charges, including murder and air piracy, were filed today against a Lebanese man arrested in connection with the 1985 hijacking of a Trans World Airlines jet, a justice official reported.

headline: Home Resales Off in August
abstract: LEAD: Rising mortgage rates cut sales of existing homes in August to the lowest level in nearly a year and a half, a trade group said today.

headline: A Cast of Legislators
abstract: LEAD: Members of the Iran-contra committees who had not been able to question Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North had their chance yesterday. Here are some who spoke.  Representative Les Aspin, D-Wis.  His work as chairman of the Armed Services Committee has caused him to be absent during much of the hearings.

headline: Tamils Halt Arms Surrender
abstract: LEAD: The arms surrender by Tamil militants, called for under a peace accord, hit a snag today as Tamils in northern and eastern Sri Lanka staged a strike to protest purported torture killings by security forces.

headline: Harcourt Considers Asset Sale
abstract: LEAD: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., the publishing house that recently repulsed a takeover attempt by Robert Maxwell, the British publisher, has disclosed that it might have to sell assets if its ambitious cost-cutting falls short of its goals.

headline: ANTI-SIKH VIOLENCE IN NORTHERN INDIA
abstract: LEAD: The Indian Army was called out today to halt Hindu reprisals against Sikhs in the northern state of Haryana after Sikh terrorists killed at least 72 people in attacks on Hindu bus passengers, Indian officials said.

headline: Data General Addition
abstract: LEAD: The Data General Corporation, which makes a broad line of computer systems, said today that it added a more powerful model to its MV/7800 series of superminicomputers. The new MV/7800 XP is 40 percent faster than the original MV/7800, according to the company, which also announced the MV/7800 DCX, an office version of the new system.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN HONEYMOONS; Getting the Marriage Off the Ground
abstract: LEAD: AS recently as three years ago, it was unusual to find a honeymooning couple on a rugged safari in Kenya or on a trek through the Himalayas. Not so any more, said Judi Wineland, president and founder of Overseas Adventure Travel, which arranges exotic tours and expeditions.

headline: Xerox Bases Campaign On Documents Theme
abstract: LEAD: Xerox will break its first corporate ad campaign in a couple of years on Saturday, during the coverage of the British Open golf tournament on the ABC-TV network. Then the print phase will start on Tuesday in The Wall Street Journal. The advertising will introduce the new theme line, ''We document the world.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Ames Department Stores, Rocky Hill, Conn., named Paul Reese senior vice president, traffic and distribution.

headline: Oil-Rig Count Climbs
abstract: LEAD: The number of American oil rigs rose by 10 last week, to 983, up sharply from 734 at the same time last year, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. The rig count, considered an important indicator of the health of the oil industry, has been rising in the last year along with crude oil prices.

headline: Dollar Ends Bad Week With Drop
abstract: LEAD: The dollar slipped further yesterday, pushed down by a report of slower economic growth in the United States and a surprising statement by Japan's Minister of Finance.

headline: Moody's Rates Life Insurers
abstract: LEAD: Moody's Investors Service said yesterday that it had started a new rating service for North American life insurance companies and the guaranteed investment contracts they provide. As part of the new service, Moody's announced ratings for 16 life insurance companies in addition to the six it had already rated.

headline: Net at Morgan Stanley Rises
abstract: LEAD: Morgan Stanley & Company said yesterday that it earned $62.4 million in the second quarter, up 37.1 percent from $45.5 million the year earlier, impressive results given the huge bond trading losses that hit some of the firm's competitors in April.

headline: Publisher To Acquire Variety
abstract: LEAD: In a move that likely surprised the entertainment industry, the Cahners Publishing Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Variety, the trade publication known as the bible of the industry.

headline: Foreign Cars Up in Japan
abstract: LEAD: Sales of foreign cars and trucks in Japan jumped 37.9 percent in the first half of 1987, to a record 44,456 vehicles, from 32,244 a year ago, the Japan Automobile Importers Association said today. The increase reflected a narrowed price gap between foreign and Japanese-made cars and lower loan rates provided by foreign car dealers, the association said.

headline: Seagram Names Official
abstract: LEAD: Edward F. McDonnell has been named executive vice president, international, of the Seagram Company, the company said yesterday. Mr. McDonnell, 52 years old, is the president of Seagram International, which has affiliated companies in 25 countries. Since 1981, when the division was created, Seagram's sales have grown to $1.4 billion, from $870 million.

headline: U.S. AND KUWAITIS CLEAR GULF MINES LINKED TO TEHERAN
abstract: LEAD: Naval experts from the United States, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait finished clearing mines today that Iran was thought to have laid in a deep-water channel to Kuwait's main oil terminal, the Kuwaiti Defense Ministry said.

headline: A Bull Market in Stock Splits
abstract: LEAD: A record number of companies are expected to split their stock this year, yet another indication of the bull market's strength.

headline: Council Explores New Path to Truce in Gulf
abstract: LEAD: The Security Council is expected to ask Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar in the next few days to see if Iran and Iraq will accept a cease-fire linked to steps to determine which of them is responsible for their seven-year-old war, informed diplomats said today.

headline: Henry Ford in Hospital
abstract: LEAD: Henry Ford 2d, former chairman of the Ford Motor Company and grandson of the company's founder, was listed in serious condition today with pneumonia at a hospital here, a spokesman said. Mr. Ford, 70 years old, was admitted Saturday to Henry Ford Hospital in Detroit, which was founded by his grandfather.

headline: Mozambique Says Rightist Guerrillas Massacred 380 Civilians
abstract: LEAD: Anti-Government rebels massacred 380 people at a coastal town in Inhambane province last weekend, the official news agency, A.I.M., said today.

headline: Landslide Hits Italian Resort After Heavy Rains, Killing 7
abstract: LEAD: A landslide caused by three days of heavy rain struck a mountain resort hotel today and killed seven people, the news agency Ansa said.

headline: Navy Holds 2 in Gulf Ship Death
abstract: LEAD: Two United States Navy men are being held in the robbery and slaying of a 20-year-old crewman who disappeared late last week from the aircraft carrier Constellation, deployed near the Persian Gulf, Navy officials said today.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, AUGUST 13, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  Companies

headline: The Woes of a Robot Peddler
abstract: LEAD: IT was early March. Jim Repko, the lanky young East Coast manager of sales for Adept Technology Inc., had just finished lunch with three engineers from Grumman Aircraft Systems who he hoped would buy several Adept robots.

headline: Arens Quits Israeli Cabinet Post Over Jet Decision
abstract: LEAD: Moshe Arens, an Israeli Cabinet minister angered by the decision to kill the home-grown Lavi fighter jet, resigned today.

headline: The U.N. Today: Sept. 21, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  GENERAL ASSEMBLY

headline: New World's Bid Blocked by Judge
abstract: LEAD: Judge William Young of United States District Court rejected New World Entertainment Ltd.'s request to lift a state court order blocking its unsolicited $460 million buyout offer for Kenner Parker Toys Inc.

headline: Advertising; Church's Fried Chicken Moves to Bloom
abstract: LEAD: Church's Fried Chicken of San Antonio is taking its advertising account to the Bloom Agency in Dallas. The ad budget is $12 million, according to Robert H. Bloom, chairman of the parent Bloom Companies.

headline: Talking Deals; Debate Grows On Insider Plan
abstract: LEAD: INSIDER traders have played fast and loose with information about sensitive corporate deals whenever they could get their hands on it. Now the Securities and Exchange Commission is trying to curb the use of such information by spelling out more clearly what is and is not legal.

headline: B.P. Unit Sets Cut Of 300 to 500 Jobs
abstract: LEAD: The British Petroleum Company's American exploration and production unit, the Standard Oil Production Company, said that between 300 and 500 part-time and full-time positions would be eliminated as a result of a reorganization. The reorganization follows British Petroleum's acquisition in June of the 45 percent of the Standard Oil Company that it did not already own.
