abstract: LEAD:                 Previous   Year        In percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   8.00        DISCOUNT RATE   5.50   5.50   6.00        FEDERAL FUNDS   6.81   6.77   5.87        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   6.20   6.16   5.29        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   6.19   6.25   5.31        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   8.53   8.59   6.74        30-YR.

headline: U.S. Again Bars Rail Merger
abstract: LEAD: The Government refused yesterday to allow a merger of the Santa Fe and Southern Pacific railroads, ending a tortured chapter in takeover history.

headline: Lorimar, a TV Star, Gambles on Movies
abstract: LEAD: Merv Adelson, the chairman and chief executive of the Lorimar-Telepictures Corporation, is not content to be the king of prime-time television programming. He wants to be a movie mogul as well.

headline: Correction
abstract: LEAD: Because of an editing error, a Washington dispatch on July 20 about the Civil Rights Commission incorrectly reported the status of Congressional action on its budget. Representative Don Edwards, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee's Subcommittee on Civil and Constitutional Rights, has recommended cutting the commission's budget to $4.5 million in the fiscal year 1988 from $7.5 million in this fiscal year; the subcommittee has not yet voted on the issue.

headline: Advertising; WCRS Rules Out Bid for Bozell, Jacobs
abstract: LEAD: Britain's WCRS Group, which has been rumored to be interested in acquiring Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt from Lorimar Telepictures, which in turn has announced plans to divest itself of it, did indeed take a look at the company, according to Tim Breene, deputy group chief executive of WCRS, but decided about a week ago not to make any kind of offer.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: British Airways P.L.C. said it would combine its tour operations with those of Sunmed Holidays in an equal joint venture. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: JARUZELSKI CANDID ON SOVIET'S PAST
abstract: LEAD: Amid a flow of official commemorations of the 48th anniversary of the outbreak of World War II, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, has given a remarkably frank portrayal of the tangled relations between Poland and the Soviet Union.

headline: Kahane Ends Refusal Of Parliament's Oath
abstract: LEAD: Rabbi Meir Kahane took an oath of allegiance to Parliament today and thus restored his right to take part in parliamentary deliberations.

headline: Iranians Take a Tour of the West Wing
abstract: LEAD: Donald T. Regan was asked about how representatives of Iran were able to gain access to the White House.

headline: The U.N. Today: Sept. 4, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

headline: Bank Charges Challenged
abstract: LEAD: An attorney for three men accused of defrauding the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company in 1982 said today that the charges might be invalid because they were filed after the statute of limitations ran out.

headline: KENYA TO EXAMINE REPORTERS' STATUS
abstract: LEAD: President Daniel arap Moi, apparently angered by mounting press reports abroad critical of Kenya's human rights record, has announced that the Government will re-examine the status of the more than 100 foreign reporters based in the country.

headline: Toting Up the Victories - and Problems
abstract: LEAD: TIME was when all eyes were on Scandinavia and its ''middle way''. Marquis Child's book on ''Sweden: The Middle Way'' was a best seller for some years after its publication in the 1930's.

headline: Pentagon Absent From Talks And Old Disputes Heat Up
abstract: LEAD: When American and Soviet officials assembled for a high-level meeting Tuesday, some key Reagan Administration officials were conspicuous by their absence.

headline: Don't Base Decisions on Distorted Data
abstract: LEAD: FOR more than a decade, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, has issued annual reports about the flow of Federal funds. He has shown that the Northern states have consistently paid more in taxes than they have received in total Federal expenditures. In fact, he notes that the Northeast-Midwest region's balance-of-payments deficit with the Federal

headline: Loss at BankAmerica: A Record $1.14 Billion
abstract: LEAD: SAN FRANCISCO, July 23 - With a $1.1 billion special addition to its reserve for loan losses, the BankAmerica Corporation today reported its largest quarterly loss to date, $1.14 billion.

headline: The Witness File
abstract: LEAD:  Name: Edwin Meese 3d  Age: 55  Position: Attorney General of the United States since February 1985. Mr. Meese has worked on and off for Ronald Reagan since he was Governor of California, including as chief of staff to Governor Reagan, adviser on the Reagan-Bush campaign committee, director of the transition team for President-elect Reagan, and counselor to the President since the beginning of 1981.

headline: Advertising; Debut of Sports Inc. Delayed Till November
abstract: LEAD: The first issue of Sports Inc., ''the sports business weekly,'' is now planned for November. The Times Mirror Company had originally scheduled the publication for a March introduction.

headline: LUFTHANSA'S BID ON HILTON'S OPPOSED
abstract: LEAD: Franz Josef Strauss, the Bavarian Premier and a member of Lufthansa A.G.'s supervisory board, said he opposed the German national airline's bid to take over the Hilton International Corporation luxury hotel chain. ''Lufthansa should stay an aircraft company and not become a conglomerate with many different activities,'' Mr.

headline: Prices Rise in Light Trading
abstract: LEAD: Bond prices ended a holiday-shortened week on a positive note, registering gains of half a point or more yesterday on signs that economic activity remains relatively weak.

headline: Reebok Purchase
abstract: LEAD: Reebok International Ltd. said today that it had agreed to buy Ellesse International, an Italian sportswear and apparel company, for about $60 million. Ellesse, based in Perugia, makes ski, tennis and other sports clothing and recently began distributing a line of footwear, according to Reebok, a maker of athletic and casual footwear.

headline: Correction
abstract: LEAD: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about changes in the capital gains tax in New York State misstated some rates. Under laws in effect through 1986, a New York City resident in the maximum bracket paid a Federal capital gains tax of 20 percent and additional state and city taxes that brought the effective rate to 25.93 percent.

headline: PANAMA IS TIED UP AS STRIKE GOES ON
abstract: LEAD: The second day of a nationwide general strike brought activity to a virtual halt here today, but public reaction to the dramatic arrest of the military leader's harshest critic was muted.

headline: Privatization Plan for Israel
abstract: LEAD: Israel has chosen two American investment banks, the First Boston Corporation and Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., to advise it on the sale of about 30 Government-owned corporations and subsidiaries to the public, the Finance Ministry said.

headline: A Dip in Oil Rig Count
abstract: LEAD: The number of working oil and gas drilling rigs in the United States slipped by 7 last week, to 1,094, Baker Hughes said today. A year ago the total was 806, the oilfield tool company said.

headline: How the Call of the Wild Pays Off
abstract: LEAD: DETROIT Zoo directors have a dream. They want the world's best chimpanzee exhibit. What they envision is a four-acre recreation of an African forest where a colony of 25 to 30 chimps can live in captivity as they would in the wild.

headline: The U.N. Today: Sept. 9, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  GENERAL ASSEMBLY

headline: Without the Playground, Mothers Meet at the Office
abstract: LEAD: ''HOW to Nurture and Maintain a Family Culture When You Work All Day, Your Mother Lives in Omaha and Your Housekeeper Comes from Ethiopia'' was the topic and it drew an eager audience. The Working Mothers Forum of the Washington Women's Bar Association was in session.

headline: CBS Officer Joins Agency
abstract: LEAD: George F. Schweitzer, vice president of communications at CBS Inc., has resigned to join Young & Rubicam as a vice president and director of corporate relations. Mr. Schweitzer had been at

headline: Advertising; Agency Sold By Mickelberry
abstract: LEAD: Lowe Howard-Spink & Bell P.L.C., London, and a management group from Laurence, Charles, Free & Lawson have purchased the New York-based agency for $24.8 million from the Mickelberry Corporation.

headline: New Light Put on Old Products
abstract: LEAD: THE two Martins at Shaw & Landey have decided that the way into the consumer consciousness in the age of advertising clutter is through the de-familiarization of products or services.

headline: Datapoint Losing Operating Officer
abstract: LEAD: Doris D. Bencsik wants a vacation.

headline: Housing Starts Are Off Again
abstract: LEAD: Housing starts fell in June for the fourth straight month, but housing industry economists remain optimistic on the outlook for the rest of the year, assuming mortgage rates do not jump again.

headline: Hicks & Haas To Buy Palco
abstract: LEAD: Hicks & Haas, a Dallas-based investment firm, said it had agreed to buy Palco Industries from a unit of the Maxxam Group for more than $300 million. The deal is expected to be completed in early September. Palco, a division of the MXM

headline: MCI to Match A.T.&T. Rate
abstract: LEAD: The MCI Communications Corporation said it would match its long-distance rival by cutting its long-distance rates an average of 5 percent. The reduced rates will go into effect Aug. 1. The rate change was in response to a similar rate cut July 1 by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

headline: Hanoi Says It Keeps No Live Americans Missing in the War
abstract: LEAD: A Presidential envoy who visited Hanoi last week said today that Vietnam insisted it did not have control over any living Americans missing in action from the war.

headline: Advertising; Manning Already Back At Work at Thompson
abstract: LEAD: Burton J. Manning was already at work at the J. Walter Thompson Company yesterday, before the WPP Group could make an official announcement of his return and appointment as chief executive of the worldwide agency.

headline: Spinoff Planned For Fibreboard
abstract: LEAD: The Louisiana-Pacific Corporation, based in Portland, Ore., said it planned to spin off its Fibreboard Corporation subsidiary early in 1988, under a plan in which all of Fibreboard's outstanding shares would be distributed to Louisiana-Pacific shareholders. The company said that spinning off Fibreboard, which is based in Concord,

headline: Mercantile House Gets Crownx Offer
abstract: LEAD: Crownx Inc., a Canadian financial services company, said it was offering to acquire the wholesale brokerage operations of Mercantile House P.L.C. for about $:289 million, or around $474 million. The bid tops an earlier offer by Quadrex Holdings Inc.

headline: IN THE TOILS OF A BUREAUCRACY THAT SCARCELY TOILS
abstract: LEAD: The Mugamma, a grim, gray hulk of a building, looms by Tahrir Square's chaotic traffic in downtown Cairo, a symbol of the sprawling, indolent bureaucracy that clogs Egyptian life.

headline: MARIJUANA TRAFFIC ON RISE
abstract: LEAD: Near-record prices for marijuana in the United States have led to a sudden upsurge in shipments of marijuana from Colombia through Mexico, according to Mexican Government officials.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, AUGUST 27, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  Companies

headline: Nomura Move in Britain
abstract: LEAD: The Nomura Securities Company Ltd. today became the first Japanese firm to make markets on the London Stock Exchange, as it began dealing in 10 leading British stocks. Nomura is entering a market in which the profits of longtime brokers have been squeezed by the so-called Big Bang deregulation last October.

headline: Swiss Bank Ends Bid For Hill Samuel Group
abstract: LEAD: In a surprise move, the Union Bank of Switzerland said today that it was no longer seeking to acquire the Hill Samuel Group P.L.C., the British merchant bank and financial services firm.

headline: Chile Letting Exiled Novelist Return
abstract: LEAD: Ariel Dorfman, the Chilean novelist and essayist, said today that the Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet had lifted its order excluding him from the country and that he would go to Santiago on Saturday.

headline: Alberto-Culver Bid
abstract: LEAD: The Alberto-Culver Company, the health and beauty-aids company that wants to acquire Lamaur Inc. in a deal worth about $135 million, said it had secured a $150 million revolving credit agreement from the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company to finance the bid. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Alberto-Culver said the agreement was subject to Alberto-Culver buying at least 30 percent of each class of Lamaur's voting stock.

headline: Japanese Trade Surplus Shrank 31% in August
abstract: LEAD: Japan's worldwide trade surplus dropped 31 percent last month, to $5.15 billion, from the level of August 1986. It was the largest of four consecutive monthly declines.

headline: Japan Most Expensive
abstract: LEAD: Japan said today that its domestic goods and services were the most expensive in the industrialized world. The costliest items include food, cigarettes, education and recreational services. Prices in Japan are 57 percent higher than in Britain, 49 percent costlier than in Italy, 30 percent up on the United States and 22 percent higher than in France, according to a report by the Economic Planning Agency, a Government organization.

headline: PATENTS; Ship Warning Device
abstract: LEAD: A proximity warning device for use on ships has been invented for the Department of Transportation. Patent 4,684,949 was granted this week to Rudolph M. Kalafus, an engineer in the department's Boston center. The device also enables several ships to communicate with one another. Licenses will be granted for manufacture.

headline: Yields at 5% to 8% On Florida Bonds
abstract: LEAD: A $101.5 million financing by the Duval County School Board in Florida was brought to market through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

headline: Espionage Trial of Marine Hears From C.I.A. Agents
abstract: LEAD: The espionage court-martial of Sgt. Clayton J. Lonetree heard testimony in closed session today from witnesses identified by defense lawyers as Central Intelligence Agency officials code-named ''Big John'' and ''Little John.''

headline: U.S. 'Dumping' Charged
abstract: LEAD: The United States is among half a dozen countries accused by the synthetic fiber industry of ''dumping'' polyester on the European market at cut-rate prices, the European Community said today. The community's executive commission said it is investigating charges that American companies - together with those of Mexico, Taiwan, Rumania, Turkey and Yugoslavia - are selling synthetic fibers in Europe below production costs.

headline: Construction Spending Declined by 1.1% in June
abstract: LEAD: Construction spending, depressed by continued weakness in apartment and office building, fell 1.1 percent in June, the second consecutive monthly decline and the largest setback since March, the Government reported today.

headline: Wesray Set to Sell Wearever Stock
abstract: LEAD: A group led by officials of the Wesray Corporation, a New York-based investment group, said it had signed an option agreement to sell its 26 million shares of Wearever-Proctorsilex Inc. for $18 a share to a group led by the company's management.

headline: TOSHIBA DETAILS TRAIL OF CRIME IN SALE OF MACHINERY TO SOVIET
abstract: LEAD: In a rare look at the inner workings of Japanese corporate crime, the Toshiba Corporation explained in detail today how a subsidiary had signed secret agreements with Moscow, twice duped Japanese authorities, silenced its employees when they complained of illegalities and burned documents once investigators were on its trail.

headline: For Vietnam's Catholic Church, a Modest Revival
abstract: LEAD: The clamor of a basketball match that shatters the afternoon calm of a cloister in St. Joseph's Seminary is, in a sense, the sound of a modest religious revival. The young men at play are student priests.

headline: Business and the Law; Debating a Bill On Job Hazards
abstract: LEAD: BUSINESS interests are deeply divided over a Congressional measure that would give workers greater notice about the hazards of their jobs. Though many opponents of the bill have applauded its goal of informing workers about hazards and creating a safer workplace, they fear more lawsuits.

headline: Reagan Won't Comment on Admiral
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan refused to comment today on whether he had been deceived by Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter.

headline: BRAZIL'S LEADER REPORTS SUCCESS IN THE ENRICHING OF URANIUM
abstract: LEAD: President Jose Sarney has announced that Brazilian scientists have succeeded in enriching uranium, a key stage in this country's development of its own nuclear energy technology.

headline: Rubbermaid's Sad Succession Tale
abstract: LEAD: THEORY has it that the best way for a chief executive to assure an orderly transition at retirement is to identify and groom an heir apparent a few years ahead of time so that he or she is comfortable with all aspects of the company when the critical time comes. If he has been running a division, bring him into headquarters.

headline: Shareholders Back Caesars Dividend
abstract: LEAD: Caesars World Inc., no longer threatened by a hostile takeover bid, said its shareholders had approved its $942.4 million recapitalization plan. The plan, under which each share of stock receives a special $26.25 dividend, was approved by 79 percent of the 22.1 million shares voted.

headline: 17 Unions Consider a Bid for Southern Pacific
abstract: LEAD: Seventeen railroad unions have decided to study whether they should make an offer for the Southern Pacific railroad, a unit of the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation.

headline: Senate Action on Angola
abstract: LEAD: The Senate today rejected a trade embargo on Angola, proposed as an amendment to the trade bill by Senator Dennis DeConcini, Democrat of Arizona. The 68-to-31 vote to table his amendment followed a sharp debate about the Administration's policy on Angola. Washington is sending millions of dollars in covert aid to rebels who are trying to overthrow the Marxist administration in Luanda.

headline: Dynamics' Net Rises by 20.9%
abstract: LEAD: The General Dynamics Corporation said that its earnings increased 20.9 percent in the second quarter of 1987, in part because of a marked increase in sales in the company's military aircraft business.

headline: Kenner Bid Begun
abstract: LEAD: New World Entertainment Ltd., the film maker and comic book publisher, said it had begun its $475 million tender offer for Kenner Parker Toys Inc. after a state judge decided late Tuesday to lift a temporary order barring the bid. Last month New World made an unsolicited offer for Kenner Parker that was rejected by the toy maker, which is based in Beverly, Mass.

headline: THE 2 KIMS: CAN THEY KEEP A UNITED FRONT?
abstract: LEAD: Through more than two weeks of street protests, strategy for anti-Government forces seemed to be directed largely by dissident clergymen and campus militants.

headline: Death Threats Delay Buyout
abstract: LEAD: Death threats against the chief figure in the proposed leveraged buyout of the Holly Sugar Corporation have delayed completion of the $130 million agreement, the Colorado Springs company said.

headline: K Mart Profit Rises by 22.5%
abstract: LEAD: The K Mart Corporation said today that its net income rose by 22.5 percent in the second quarter, with the jump attributed to higher sales that in turn were spurred by increased promotional advertising.

headline: Key Models Expected From I.B.M. and Tandy
abstract: LEAD: Tandy and I.B.M., two of the leading makers of personal computers, are expected to make significant product announcements next week, company officials and industry analysts said today.

headline: Manila Raises Gasoline Prices
abstract: LEAD: The Philippine Government raised gasoline and fuel oil prices by nearly 20 percent today, producing calls for strikes.

headline: Indian Security Forces Kill 5 Described as Sikh Extremists
abstract: LEAD: Security forces killed five suspected Sikh extremists they encountered while on patrol, and terrorists shot and killed two people, the police and news reports said Saturday.

headline: Rebel Officer Urges Struggle Against Aquino
abstract: LEAD: The leader of the failed military rebellion, in his first public statement since the Aug. 28 uprising, called on Filipinos today to support him in his struggle against the Government of President Corazon C. Aquino.

headline: Young U.S. Jews See for Themselves in Germany
abstract: LEAD: Most of the American Jewish students had come to West Germany with trepidation. Some had been warned by their parents not to go, and others were afraid of their own reactions, but all felt that they had to see for themselves.

headline: Browning-Ferris Aiding Inquiries
abstract: LEAD: Browning-Ferris Industries said it was cooperating with several Federal grand juries investigating possible illegal pricing practices in the trash-hauling industry. The antitrust division of the Justice Department said that 11 grand juries, primarily in the South and Northeast, were investigating charges of bid-rigging, price-fixing and the splitting up of customers and territories.

headline: GETTY-CLARK OIL TALKS SUSPENDED
abstract: LEAD: The Getty Petroleum Corporation said it had been unable to reach an agreement to acquire the assets of the Clark Oil and Refining Corporation, and that negotiations between the companies had been suspended. Stephen P. Salzman, Getty's vice president for finance, declined to specify the areas of disagreement, adding that no date for resuming talks has been set.

abstract: LEAD: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization       $      July 3   June 26   July 4        1987   1987   1986       Gasoline production, daily   7.1   7.3   7.1        Distillate production, daily   2.8   2.9   2.7        Gasoline stocks   231.0   230.7   226.6        Distillate stocks   104.2   102.6   106.1        Crude imports, daily   4.5   5.3   4.5        Product imports, daily   2.0   2.2   1.7        Crude stocks   324.1   325.6   319.8        Crude production, daily   8.4   8.4   8.6        Refinery utilization (%)   87.0   86.3   83.0

headline: Wesray in Deal For RKO Studio
abstract: LEAD: RKO Pictures, the legendary Hollywood studio once owned by the reclusive financier Howard Hughes, said it would be acquired by its managers and the Wesray Capital Corporation from its parent, Gencorp, for $31 million. The managers of the studio, based in Los Angeles, were unable to complete their own proposed buyout last spring, said Mary Begley Feurey, an RKO spokeswoman in New

headline: Hawker Siddeley Deal
abstract: LEAD: Britain's Hawker Siddeley Group P.L.C. said today that it agreed to buy Aerospace Avionics Inc., a private New York concern, for $:17.5 million, or $28 million, in cash. Aerospace Avionics supplies electronic subsystems to leading makers in the American aerospace industry.

headline: The Testimony: Dialogue With 'Pragmatic Elements' in Iran
abstract: LEAD: Members of Congress questioned Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter further yesterday, in his fourth day of testimony, about his role in the Iran-contra affair. Here are excerpts from his testimony, as recorded by The New York Times.

headline: S.E.C. May Act on 10% Threshold
abstract: LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission is expected to take a step this week toward abolishing a controversial tactic used in corporate takeovers.

headline: Edelman in Stock Ploy
abstract: LEAD: Asher B. Edelman, the New York investor who said on Tuesday that he might seek control of the Foster Wheeler Corporation, explained yesterday that he had recently sold part of his stake in the company in a deliberate attempt to confuse people.

headline: AQUINO DEMANDING ARREST OF LEADERS IN MILITARY REVOLT
abstract: LEAD: The leaders of an attempted coup were still at large today and the military remained on alert after Government forces put down the most serious armed challenge to the presidency of Corazon C. Aquino.

headline: CENTRAL AMERICAN PLIGHT IS PEOPLE IN ABUNDANCE
abstract: LEAD: As one of 17 children of a sharecropper, Juan Francisco Chita was forced to go to work in the fields at the age of 9. Now 37, he cannot read or write, but because he is determined to be able to own a piece of land and give his children a better life, he and his wife, Reina, have tried to limit the size of their own family.

headline: Correction
abstract: LEAD: An article last Sunday on the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn, home to many Soviet emigres, incorrectly located the Ukrainian city of Odessa.

headline: Advertising; People
abstract: LEAD: * William Lower has been promoted to executive vice president, creative director, at Wells, Rich, Greene/Chicago.

headline: Exchange of Prisoners Is Scheduled in Africa
abstract: LEAD: A prisoner exchange involving a captured South African soldier, a Frenchman, a Dutchman and 133 Angolan soldiers will take place Monday in Maputo, the capital of Mozambique, the French Government has announced.

headline: WHERE A PANAMANIAN HERO'S DEATH INTERRUPTED THE DREAM
abstract: LEAD: In this bustling farm town on Panama's fertile Azuero Peninsula, anti-Government sentiment is nothing new. It erupted dramatically in September 1985 after the killing of one of the town's leading citizens, Dr. Hugo Spadafora, an outspoken critic of the military.

headline: Sparks Tuneup Account Is Awarded to Messner
abstract: LEAD: Sparks Tuneup Centers, one of the more recent creations of Anthony A. Martino, father of Aamco and Maaco, has taken its advertising account to Messner, Vetere, Berger, Carey. Billings should be $4 million.

headline: A Man of Two Clashing Principles
abstract: LEAD: TWENTY years ago in my corporations class at the Yale Law School, the late Prof. Joseph Bishop wryly commented: ''If someone proposed a law that guaranteed substantial wage increases for law professors, I'd be first in line to lobby for it, but not Bob Bork. He's a man of principle.'' That single observation explains why Judge Bork has proved so difficult for both supporters and detractors to understand.

headline: 64 Senators Urge Reagan to Drop $1 Billion Sale of Arms to Saudis
abstract: LEAD: Sixty-four senators have sent a letter to President Reagan urging him to abandon a proposed $1.4 billion arms sale to Saudi Arabia, it was announced today.

headline: New Europe Chief For L.F. Rothschild
abstract: LEAD: L.F. Rothschild Holdings Inc., the New York-based securities firm that has been buffeted by bond trading losses recently, said yesterday that it had hired Richard C. Jackson, a longtime Citicorp executive, to head its European operations.

headline: New Delhi Bans Meetings at Protest Center
abstract: LEAD: For years, a long broad lawn in the heart of this city has been the country's most popular protest center, reflecting the frustrations, aspirations, angers and hopes of Indian democracy.

headline: MINERS IN AFRICA AGREE TO CONTINUE DISRUPTIVE STRIKE
abstract: LEAD: Leaders of 300,000 black miners on strike at South Africa's economically vital gold and coal mines voted today to reject an offer from employers and decided to continue the 17-day-old nationwide strike.

headline: PERU PLANNING TO NATIONALIZE BANKS
abstract: LEAD: President Alan Garcia announced today that he planned to nationalize the nation's banks and close private money-exchange houses in a dramatic move to gain control over the country's turbulent financial system.

headline: U.S., Offering New Missile Plan, Moves Closer to Pact With Soviet
abstract: LEAD: In a move that is likely to bring the United States and the Soviet Union closer to a new arms agreement, American officials offered a new plan today for monitoring an accord to eliminate the two sides' medium- and shorter-range missiles.

headline: Bond Prices Slightly Higher
abstract: LEAD: Bond prices ended slightly higher yesterday, buoyed by weakening oil prices and some expectation among securities dealers and institutional investors that Congress would produce a budget package that would extend the debt ceiling.

headline: Rates Up a Bit At Citicorp Sale
abstract: LEAD: Interest rates rose slightly at Citicorp's weekly commercial paper auctions.

headline: Chemical Industry Sees Rush To Invent Safer Alternatives
abstract: LEAD: An international agreement to limit production of chlorofluorocarbons and halons will touch off a race in the $2.2 billion industry to develop chemical alternatives that are not hazardous to the earth's ozone layer, officials at several American chemical companies said yesterday.

headline: NEC Britain Move
abstract: LEAD: The NEC Corporation will start making car telephones at its British subsidiary beginning next summer, becoming the first Japanese company to shift car phone output to Europe, a company spokesman said. The move is aimed at avoiding trade friction over phone exports, he said. NEC Technologies U.K. Ltd., which is based in Birmingham, England, will initially produce 3,000 to 4,000 telephones a month at its plant in Telford for sale in Britain.

headline: Storm of Protest Rages Over Dam Near Leningrad
abstract: LEAD: From the shore of this town west of Leningrad, a sand and earthen breakwater stretches across the Gulf of Finland to within a mile of the other side.

headline: DEBT ACTIONS MAY EFFECT BANK LOANS, DIVIDENDS
abstract: LEAD: With leading banks setting aside additional reserves for losses on third-world debt, bank shareholders may end up with skimpier returns and both business and individual borrowers might find it harder to obtain loans, experts on the banking industry say.

headline: Sale of Assets By Burlington
abstract: LEAD: Burlington Holdings, the investment group led by Morgan Stanley & Company that recently acquired Burlington Industries for $2.2 billion, said today that it would seek to raise $900 million by selling assets over a two-year period.

headline: NEW VIOLENCE FLARES IN SEOUL AS POLICE HALT MARCH
abstract: LEAD: Thousands of students clashed with the police today in the worst confrontation since the Government announced major political concessions a week ago.

headline: Thrift Unit In Jersey Acquired
abstract: LEAD: One of New Jersey's largest savings and loan associations, the Carteret Savings Bank, was sold yesterday, and a big banking company in the state, the First Jersey National Corporation, said it was involved in takeover talks.

headline: Profits Climb At Unilever
abstract: LEAD: Unilever, the British-Dutch household products company, said today that its net income jumped 31.9 percent in the second quarter from a year ago.

headline: BRUNEI REGAINS $10 MILLION
abstract: LEAD: Brunei has recovered, with interest, its mislaid $10 million of contra-related aid and is saying it was meant for Central America's poor, not the Nicaraguan rebels, the Malaysian national news agency said today.

headline: Tax Watch; STATES STUDY FLORIDA ACTIONS
abstract: LEAD: FLORIDA'S bitter experience with a sweeping new sales tax on services is bound to make legislators in other states think twice about following suit. But even if Florida lawmakers decide to end the tax this week to protect their political scalps, taxpayers should not presume that the idea of taxing services is a dead issue.

headline: Steel Innovator's Risky Plan
abstract: LEAD: Although the Nucor Corporation will not break ground until next month for a steel mill it intends to build in central Indiana, all eyes in the steel industry have been on the project since the plans were announced early this year.

headline: Decisions on 3 Arms Issues Are Reported by the Senate
abstract: LEAD: The Senate handed the White House a trio of victories today as it rejected efforts to halt underground nuclear tests, delay the production of new chemical weapons and block a medium-range arms-control agreement.

headline: Japan's Efforts to Soften U.S. Anger on Toshiba
abstract: LEAD: In its desire to quell American anger over a Japanese company's sale of militarily sensitive technology to the Soviet Union, Japan is taking steps that may seem extraordinary to Americans, but make perfect sense to Japanese.

headline: The Witness File
abstract: LEAD:  Name: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North  Age: 43  Position: Deputy director of the political-military affairs bureau at the National Security Council from 1981 until dismissed by the President on Nov. 25, 1986. Now he is on the staff at Marine headquarters in Washington.  Role: Colonel North has been described as the chief operator in the programs to sell American arms to Iran and subsequently to divert profits to the Nicaraguan contras.

headline: INDUSTRY EXPANDED IN AUGUST
abstract: LEAD: The nation's industrial economy continued to expand in August, with increases in production, new orders and employment, the National Association of Purchasing Managers said in its latest report, to be released today.

headline: Business Climates
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Carnival Ships
abstract: LEAD: Carnival Cruise Lines Inc. said it had ordered two passenger ships from Finland's Wartsila Marine Industries in what it called the largest contract ever awarded for passenger ships. Carnival said it had signed a letter of agreement for the deal, worth about $400 million. The new vessels will be identical to a 70,000-ton ship, to be named Fantasy, that Wartsila is currently building for Carnival for about $200 million.

headline: SWANK INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Costa Ricans to Plant Trees On Airstrip North Arranged
abstract: LEAD: Children will plant tree seedlings Saturday on an airstrip in Costa Rica that was built by the private network Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North set up to assist the Nicaraguan contras, Costa Rican officials say.

headline: Hong Kong's Growth
abstract: LEAD: Fueled by surging exports, Hong Kong's economy will grow by 12 percent this year, doubling initial forecasts, Financial Secretary Piers Jacobs said today. Some private economists estimate that growth could reach 14.5 percent, the highest level in a decade.

headline: Tokyo Journal; To Be Sorely Tried, Try Filing a Lawsuit in Japan
abstract: LEAD: Hideo Yokochi was 48 years old when he filed suit against a Japanese company whose contaminated cooking oil gave him a liver disorder and a severe skin disease.

headline: Big-Computer Pact
abstract: LEAD: The Scientific Computer Systems Corporation, a San Diego maker of near-supercomputers, which approach the standards of the benchmark Cray model at a lower price, said it had entered a joint marketing agreement with the MacNeal-Schwendler Corporation of Los Angeles. Under the agreement, Scientific will offer MacNeal's MSC-Nastran software on the SCS-40 near-supercomputer system, with availability expected by the end of the year.

headline: ARCHITECT OF SOVIET CHANGE
abstract: LEAD: Abel G. Aganbegyan, a key architect of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's audacious new economic program, likes to travel. ''It's my passion,'' he said, reporting that he covers 150,000 miles a year crisscrossing the Soviet Union on economic missions.

headline: Kenner Bid Ended
abstract: LEAD: New World Entertainment Ltd. has given up its hostile $47-a-share tender offer for Kenner Parker Toys Inc. New World's announcement today had been expected since directors of Kenner Parker, based in Beverly, Mass., agreed earlier this month to recommend that shareholders accept a tender offer of $51 a share, or $622 million, from the Tonka Corporation of Minnetonka, Minn.

headline: Japan Quietly Recalls World War II Surrender
abstract: LEAD: Japan's past militarism and its present-day diplomacy converged today as the country paused to recall its surrender 42 years ago to end World War II.

headline: Cameroon Battles Against Bureaucracy
abstract: LEAD: They are called ''Pajero-crats'' - a proud caste of bureaucrats who ride around town in luxurious Jeep-like vans made by Japanese auto makers.

headline: New Chief Named For Cleveland Fed
abstract: LEAD: W. Lee Hoskins did not intend to stay long at the Federal Reserve Bank when he first took a job in the Philadelphia office after graduate school in 1969. But, he said yesterday, ''one thing led to another'' and he ended up in various Federal Reserve economic research posts for 10 1/2 years before he went into the banking business.

headline: Ex-Guerrilla Leader Reported To Plan Return to Nicaragua (uf881) DTL
abstract: LEAD: Eden Pastora Gomez, the former guerrilla leader, was quoted today as saying he was preparing for a possible return to Nicaragua and was considering entering Nicaraguan politics.

headline: U.S. ACCUSES CHILE OF INACTION
abstract: LEAD: The State Department accused the Chilean Government today of failing to take swift action in two noted murder cases and of a general tolerance of abuses by Chilean security forces.

headline: Contract Won By McDonnell
abstract: LEAD: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said today that it plans to launch two satellites for a British broadcaster beginning in 1989 in what would be the first commercial use of its Delta rocket.

headline: Patents; New Compositions Aid Absorption, Filtration
abstract: LEAD: The Scopas Technology Company of New York received a patent this week for a family of new compositions designed for selected absorption, separation and filtration of molecular mixtures. Patent 4,683,318 was obtained by Aaron A. Rosenblatt, president, and Kenneth S. Deffeves, a scientific adviser to the company.

headline: OFFER FOR PHILLIPS-VAN HEUSEN
abstract: LEAD: Caroline Hunt Schoellkopf, by some accounts the country's richest woman, wants to own a shirt company.

headline: Unresolved Issues
abstract: LEAD:  Timing

headline: Calm Summer Is Anticipated
abstract: LEAD: The calm that descended on the credit markets a few weeks ago could continue well into the summer, analysts and traders say, setting the stage for steady to modest declines in interest rates.

headline: Ivory Coast Official Is Freed By Kidnappers After 4 Days
abstract: LEAD: A wealthy Ivory Coast official, Aoussou Koffi, has been released unharmed by kidnappers after being held four days, President Felix Houphouet-Boigny said today.

headline: Hiring Mediators Instead of Lawyers
abstract: LEAD: AFTER five years of stormy marriage, a Long Island couple, whom we will call Ted and Alice, split up last January.

headline: Some Midwest Farms Prospering
abstract: LEAD: Southeastern Minnesota has hardly been immune from the hard times that have hit the Farm Belt. But, as farmers in this region demonstrate, not everyone is suffering.

headline: Union Texas Sale
abstract: LEAD: Allied-Signal Inc. said it would sell almost 20 percent of its common stock in Union Texas Petroleum Holdings Inc. and realize a net gain of about $170 million. It said the sale would be made as a secondary offering in connection with an initial public offering of 29 million Union Texas common shares.

headline: Long Family Tie Cited By Buyer of Kodak Unit
abstract: LEAD: Carl D. Newton 3d, who is waiting to complete his purchase of the Fox Photo retail unit from the Eastman Kodak Company, says that the decision to buy the stores was based on more than just business.

headline: Johannesburg Township Celebrates a Birthday
abstract: LEAD: Fifteen months ago, this impoverished township adjoining Johannesburg's affluent suburbs witnessed grim street battles between black youths and policemen. But today, Alexandra erupted into a joyous 12-hour celebration of the 104th birthday of the Rev. Alson Dlamini. Accompanied by his 101-year-old wife, Jessie, Mr.

headline: Market Place; Colgate View Seems Bright
abstract: LEAD: THE Colgate-Palmolive Company, with 48-year-old Reuben Mark at the helm as its chairman and chief executive, continues to speed through a restructuring plan that has erased its once stodgy image while raising long-range prospects of even better earnings growth and equity appreciation.

headline: U.N. Parley Deadlocked Over Third World Debt
abstract: LEAD: A huge United Nations economic conference, attended by most of the world's countries, was deadlocked tonight by a dispute over steps to ease the developing-world's debt burden, now approaching $1 trillion.

headline: South Korea's Costly Summer
abstract: LEAD: Although they are wary of declaring that the unusual summer of labor unrest is over, South Korean businessmen and Government officials are certain of one thing: The strikes have slowed their export-driven economy.

headline: A Resignation At MacGregor
abstract: LEAD: MacGregor Sporting Goods Inc. said yesterday that Herbert A. Rosenfeld had resigned as president, chief operating officer and a director.

headline: British Paper Publishes Excerpts of M.I.5 Book
abstract: LEAD: Britain's Attorney General said today that he would take legal action against The Sunday Times for publishing excerpts of a banned book on the country's secret service, M.I.5.

headline: Jacobs, Partner Weigh An Offer For Allegheny
abstract: LEAD: The Minneapolis businessmen Irwin L. Jacobs and Carl R. Pohlad said yesterday that they might seek control of Allegheny International Inc., but some Wall Streeters dismissed their statement as a ploy to stir up interest in the stock.

headline: U.N. OFFICIALS SAY WAR CRIMES FILES MAY SOON BE OPEN
abstract: LEAD: The United Nations files containing accusations about Nazi war crimes collected at the end of World War II are expected to be opened later this month to historians and researchers, according to diplomats and United Nations officials.

headline: MORE U.S. SHOOTING
abstract: LEAD: The Defense Department said today that at least three Iranian sailors were killed and 26 seized, including four wounded, as a result of the attack by an American military helicopter on an Iranian mine-laying ship Monday night in the Persian Gulf. Ten mines were found aboard the ship, which was seized by American personnel.

headline: Sandinista Foes Are Dubious
abstract: LEAD: Opposition leaders expressed doubt today that the Sandinista Government would live up to its obligations under the new Central American peace accord.

headline: JAPANESE SAY AIM IS LOW RATES
abstract: LEAD: In the face of some isolated increases in his country's interest rates, a senior Japanese financial official said today that he saw too little inflation in his economy to warrant widespread increases and that the central bank of Japan was trying to keep rates from rising.

headline: Takeover Benefit Plan Is Proposed by Texaco
abstract: LEAD: Texaco Inc., which is operating under bankruptcy court protection from its creditors, has asked a court to allow it to tack on as much as $2.5 billion in wage and bonus guarantees in the event of a hostile takeover.

headline: NATO Picks German General
abstract: LEAD: Lieut. Gen. Eberhard Eimler, chief of staff of the West German Air Force, has been appointed a NATO deputy supreme allied commander in Europe, the Western alliance announced today. He replaces Gen. Hans-Joachim Mack, also a West German, who is retiring.

headline: BIG CROP TESTS ALMOND SELLER
abstract: LEAD: One year after a crop failure left supplies short and prices increasing, the almond growers of California's lush central valley are harvesting what appears to be their largest crop ever.

headline: Hewlett Adds Terminals
abstract: LEAD: The Hewlett-Packard Company announced its entry today into the general-purpose market for computer terminals.

headline: Sowell Airs Letter To Todd Shipyards
abstract: LEAD: The Dallas investor James E. Sowell, who holds a 9.9 percent stake in the Todd Shipyards Corporation, has listed several alternatives that he said the Jersey City-based naval construction, repair and overhaul concern should pursue ''as soon as practical.'' The list was part of a July 7 letter to the board of the financially troubled concern.

headline: Market Place; Grocery-Chain Selections
abstract: LEAD: MOST money managers have ignored grocery-chain stocks in the current bull market. As one Wall Street analyst observed yesterday, ''It's hard to put sex appeal into a sack of potatoes.''

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * American Express Bank Ltd., elected Dr. Heinz D. Zimmer director and vice chairman for global private banking.

headline: 39 Die at China Building Site
abstract: LEAD: Thirty-nine laborers died when a three-story building they were constructing collapsed at Yuan Jiang in China's central province of Hunan, the state radio and television news said today. The building toppled into a river beside the construction site while the men were asleep at midnight Monday, and the sole survivor was found clinging to a log floating in the water.

headline: President Says Support For Contras Is on Rise
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan said in his weekly radio address today that support for the Nicaraguan rebels had dramatically grown as Americans learned the facts about Nicaragua.

headline: Advertising; New Group Publisher At Hearst Magazines
abstract: LEAD: D. Claeys Bahrenburg, 40, has replaced K. Robert Brink, 48, as one of two group publishers at Hearst Magazines. Mr. Brink went on ''an extended leave of absence'' two weeks ago without any internal or external corporate announcement. There is also no official word on when he is expected back, and the company has no comment on the change.

headline: U.S.-Japan Car Accord: Little Gain
abstract: LEAD: A year of negotiations aimed at getting Japanese auto makers to buy more parts from American suppliers ended yesterday without a commitment by the Japanese to increase their purchases. Instead, they agreed to supply information every six months on how much they were buying from American companies.

headline: U.S. in Plea To Canada
abstract: LEAD: American trade officials, hoping to woo Canada back to the bargaining table for talks on a free trade agreement, made two appeals today to officials in Ottawa and remained cautiously optimistic that negotiations could resume early next week.

headline: EX-DEFENSE CHIEF VICTOR IN MANILA
abstract: LEAD: Juan Ponce Enrile, the former Defense Minister who was dismissed last year after a series of threatened coups, won the last of 24 Senate seats today, three months after an election in which the final votes are still being counted.

headline: U.S. Jet Crashes in Europe
abstract: LEAD: An American F-16 jet fighter based in West Germany crashed today near the French-German border, but both men aboard ejected safely, United States officials said. The two were identified as Capt. Phillip D. Tau, 26 years old, of Mesa, Ariz., and Capt. James P. Callahan, 31, of Parlin, N.J.

headline: Looking Forward to the Casino Society
abstract: LEAD: THOUSANDS of pages have been written on the question of what American industry must do to become competitive in the world market, or at least in the American market. Experts usually tell us that we must learn to make desirable products of good quality at reasonable prices. The same experts, faced with the question: ''How do I become the major league batting champion?

headline: For Nicaraguans, Sign of Hope After Years of War
abstract: LEAD: In the largest demonstration of the hopes unleashed by the recent regional peace agreement, thousands of Nicaraguans crossed the border here today to be reunited with family members who had fled a decade of war.

headline: Panhandle Eastern Names Chairman
abstract: LEAD: Robert D. Hunsucker, president and chief executive of the Panhandle Eastern Corporation, has been elected to the additional post of chairman, the company said yesterday. Mr. Hunsucker, 62 years old, will replace Richard L. O'Shields, who is retiring effective Jan. 1, 1988.

headline: A Reporter's Notebook: But Under the Veils of Arabia, 'It's Another Story'
abstract: LEAD: Descending, the women changed, molting funereally as they approached the homeland.

headline: AT LEAST 30 DIE IN WEST GERMANY IN EXPLOSION OF A GASOLINE TRUCK
abstract: LEAD: A tank truck loaded with gasoline crashed into an ice cream parlor Tuesday night, blew up and set off other explosions, killing at least 30 people and injuring 29, officials said. The truck driver survived.

headline: A.T.&T.'s PROFITS RISE BY 41.2%
abstract: LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that second-quarter profits jumped 41.2 percent, helped by gains in its long-distance telephone business and early success in controlling costs.

headline: The New Math of Car Incentive Plans
abstract: LEAD: CAR buyers are being seduced by juicy incentive offers from auto makers: financing as low as 1.9 percent and rebates of up to $1,000. It requires some heavy calculating, however, to figure out which is the best deal - or whether the incentive packages are good deals at all. ''It's all a big sham,'' said Hank Madden, a financial planner with IDS Financial Services in Jacksonville,

headline: A Quick Fix That Would Be Harmful
abstract: LEAD: THE search for a quick fix for the Latin American debt problem has generated numerous proposals for concessional debt relief. But a close analysis suggests that, except for some extreme cases (Bolivia, for example), such relief is not needed and actually would be counterproductive.

headline: White House Rethinking Its Outlook
abstract: LEAD: White House officials say they mishandled their approach this week to the Congressional testimony of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and made themselves and the President look silly in the process.

headline: India Says Delay in Sri Lanka Is Result of Tamils' Rivalries
abstract: LEAD: The recent accord between India and Sri Lanka intended to end ethnic strife on the island has been slowed in being put into effect by the bitter divisions and suspicions among the Tamil rebel groups, Indian officials say.

headline: AQUINO ASKS NATION TO 'BEAR WITH US'
abstract: LEAD: President Corazon C. Aquino asked the country today to ''bear with us if we failed in some aspects,'' but she gave no indication of her plans a day after the mass resignation of her Cabinet.

headline: Talking Business/with Currey of Greyhound; The Proposal For Trailways
abstract: LEAD: The Greyhound Lines bus company, which is now owned by a group of Dallas investors, received tentative permission late last week to take over the money-losing Trailways Corporation, its main competitor. Greyhound had asked for quick approval, warning that Trailways was in poor shape and that if the Interstate Commerce Commission took its time there would be little of value to take over.

headline: Keeping the Air Lanes Free: Lessons of a Horror
abstract: LEAD: Nelly Sovenko works at a small communications console in the regional air traffic control center in this far eastern city. With the touch of a button, she can instantly open telephone communications with air traffic controllers in Tokyo and Anchorage.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;
abstract: LEAD: The British Government will sell its holding in the British Petroleum Company in late October for the equivalent of $12.1 billion, the Government's financial advisers said today.

headline: Disarming of Tamil Fighters Is Delayed
abstract: LEAD: The leader of a Tamil guerrilla group conferred with his regional commanders today, delaying a surrender of weapons that is a key element in a peace agreement signed last week, Sri Lankan and Indian officials said.

headline: Illuminating Co.
abstract: LEAD: The United Illuminating Company is offering $100 million of 12 percent debentures due in 2017 at a price of 99, to yield 12 1/8 percent through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. The debentures, which are rated Baa-3 by Moody's and BBB- by S.&P., were offered to yield 3 1/4 percentage points more than 30-year Treasury bonds.

headline: Japanese Plan For Debtors
abstract: LEAD: Japan's Finance Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, today suggested establishing global ''risk insurance'' for foreign loans and a system to help debtor nations, the Kyodo News Service reported.

headline: Canadians Confer on Trade Rift
abstract: LEAD: The Canadian Cabinet met in an atmosphere of crisis today to discuss the collapse of trade negotiations with the United States. Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said afterward that his Government remained eager for an agreement if appropriate conditions could be obtained from the United States.

headline: Journey to a Joint Understanding
abstract: LEAD:  June 9, 1977  NATO reports the Soviet Union has been deploying the SS-20, a three-warhead, intermediate-range ballistic missile, in its western regions.  Oct. 28, 1977  In a speech in London on the dangers of an escalating arms race, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany expresses particular concern about the SS-20.

headline: Japanese Get Role On German Bonds
abstract: LEAD: Japanese banks and investment houses will be allowed to lead underwriting syndicates for Eurobonds denominated in West German marks as of Oct. 1, a spokesman for the Bundesbank said today.

headline: 28 STILL CONFINED IN TEHERAN IN A FRENCH-IRANIAN STANDOFF
abstract: LEAD: Twenty-eight French citizens remained confined to the French Embassy in Teheran for a fourth day today as a standoff continued between France and Iran over an Iranian wanted for questioning here.

headline: The Cost of Pursuing a Private Adoption
abstract: LEAD: A Brooklyn couple whom we shall call Mary and Phil had been trying to have a child without success for several years when they decided to adopt. For them, agencies were not an option. ''We hadn't been married long enough, and the waiting list was so long,'' Mary said. Instead, they decided to pursue an independent adoption - a procedure in which the would-be parents search out an expectant mother who plans to give up her baby.

headline: Advertising; Dispelling Doubts for Post Cereal
abstract: LEAD: PARENTS with TV-viewing youngsters should prepare for a flood of ''indubitably.''

headline: Hungary Seeks Way to Cut High Suicide Rate
abstract: LEAD: Worried by the highest recorded suicide rate in the world, the Hungarian Government is encouraging an extensive study of its causes to seek ways of prevention.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Financial Corp.
abstract: LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged the Financial Corporation of America, the nation's largest savings and loan institution, with filing ''false and misleading'' financial data with the agency over a six-year period between 1980 and 1986.

headline: Computers Introduced At A.T.&T.
abstract: LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday introduced a desktop computer and a minicomputer that offer significant advances in technology at a competitive price.

headline: BIG ARMS SALE TO SAUDIS PLANNED
abstract: LEAD: Senior Reagan Administration officials told Congressional leaders today that the Administration intended to ask Congress to approve a $1 billion arms-sale package to Saudi Arabia.

headline: Aquino's Son Says Rebels Opened Fire as He Spoke
abstract: LEAD: When the son of President Corazon C. Aquino approached his house at 2 A.M. Friday, he noticed that the street lights were out and soldiers were lying on the ground nearby.

headline: U.S. IS CRITICAL OF SOVIET ARMS PROPOSAL
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union today presented what Soviet officials called a new proposal to restrict the testing of anti-missile defensive systems. But the United States called the proposal disappointing because it did not mark an important change in the Soviet position.

headline: No Retirement For IDS Head
abstract: LEAD: Robert F. Froehlke started his retirement job yesterday -as president and chief executive of the $17 billion IDS Mutual Fund Group, a unit of the American Express Company.

headline: Gates in New Deal To Sell Learjet Unit
abstract: LEAD: The Gates Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its 64.8 percent stake in Gates Learjet for $56.8 million, or about 12 percent more than the latest of three proposed sales that had fallen through in the last year.

headline: Iranian Airliner Held 5 Hours in Frankfurt
abstract: LEAD: The West German border police prevented an Iranian jetliner from leaving Frankfurt Airport today until Iranian guards released an Iranian man being held on board.

headline: Foreign Stakes in Rolls
abstract: LEAD: Rolls-Royce P.L.C. said today that foreign holdings of its stock had exceeded the 15 percent limit set by the Government when the maker of airplane engines was sold to the public in May. Shares were sold under a plan allowing two installment payments. Banks handling the second installment, due today, said foreigners now owned 16.6 percent of the company.

headline: WALL ST. EYES ARE ON TELEDYNE
abstract: LEAD: A lot of people are speculating these days that Henry E. Singleton, the savvy head of Teledyne Inc., is revamping his company's investment portfolio. Yet some analysts say they think the speculators are dead wrong.

headline: THE ACTORS: WHO WON AND WHO LOST?
abstract: LEAD: As the Senate and House committees investigating the Iran-contra affair completed the public phase of their work today, as the television lights were switched off and the hearing room emptied, the capital turned to the sport of identifying winners and losers.

headline: The Outlook For Inflation
abstract: LEAD: WITH the economic news full of surprises -most strikingly the jump in the United States trade deficit to a record level in June, when it was supposed to shrink - the stock market has become extremely nervous.

headline: Cleveland Cliffs
abstract: LEAD: Cleveland-Cliffs Inc. announced today that it had filed suit in Federal court in Cleveland to challenge the right of David F. Bolger, a New Jersey investment banker, to call a special shareholders meeting. Mr. Bolger is seeking to oust the management of the iron ore manufacturer. He delivered proxies representing 25 percent of the company's shares in favor of such a meeting to the company.

headline: Freedom Urged for Seoul Political Prisoners
abstract: LEAD: As Korean-Americans marked South Korean Liberation Day yesterday with rallies for democracy, Amnesty International urged the South Korean Government to release all prisoners of conscience and provide new guarantees for human rights.

headline: U.S. Takes New Tack On Japanese Dumping
abstract: LEAD: In an action that could speed up price increases on products imported from Japan, the Commerce Department has found that two Japanese companies have been selling roller bearings at illegally low prices.

headline: U S Sprint Asks Rate Cut
abstract: LEAD: The U S Sprint Communications Company said today that it had filed for an across-the-board rate reduction of 4.25 percent to keep its rates lower than those of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

headline: Utility Default Settled in Part
abstract: LEAD: The first settlement in the litigation surrounding the Washington Public Power Supply System's default on $2.25 billion worth of bonds in July 1983 was announced Thursday by Junius Hoffman, the settlement master in the Federal court case.

headline: Senate Accepts Compromise Bill On Bank System
abstract: LEAD: After a tortuous legislative battle, the Senate gave final Congressional approval today to a sweeping banking law designed to shore up the weakened savings and loan industry with billions of dollars and to halt further deregulation of banking.

headline: Omnicom's Approach To Buying
abstract: LEAD: APPARENTLY almost everyone in advertising with adequate buying power is anxious to test the limits of their clout. Not all in the same way, however.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: Eastern Tightens Policy On Assisting Travelers
abstract: LEAD: Eastern Air Lines, plagued by delays and flight cancellations, has ended an experimental policy that allowed its ticket agents at La Guardia Airport to give travel, hotel and food vouchers to stranded travelers.

headline: GORBACHEV AGREES TO U.S. SUGGESTION FOR A MISSILE BAN
abstract: LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev said in an interview published today that the Soviet Union was prepared to accept a worldwide ban on medium-range and short-range missiles.

headline: Chicago Merc and Reuters Set Link
abstract: LEAD: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange and Reuters agreed yesterday to establish a global electronic trading system.

headline: P.&G. Splits Duties Of Former Ad Chief
abstract: LEAD: When the Procter & Gamble Company looked around to replace the late Robert V. Goldstein, who had been in charge of all of its consumer advertising, it decided to split those duties between two men who had been with the company all of their professional lives.

headline: INVESTING
abstract: LEAD: ANALYSTS who monitor stock purchases and sales by corporate insiders have been reporting levels of insider bullishness in recent weeks that in the past have often preceded major market upswings. The readings surprise some analysts, who note that insider buying tends to be heaviest around market lows, rather than after large advances.

headline: Dewey Warren
abstract: LEAD: The insurance broker Dewey Warren Holdings P.L.C. said it planned to raise its stake in the merchant bankers Morgan Grenfell Group P.L.C. to 7.85 million shares, from 1.15 million. It also said it planned to start a rights issue for an unspecified sum. Buying 6.7 million shares would cost the company about $:33.2 million, or $53.2 million.

headline: NEW CONTRA PLAN CALLED A THREAT TO LATIN ACCORD
abstract: LEAD: As the Reagan Administration presented its proposal for $270 million in new aid for the Nicaraguan rebels, leading Congressional Democrats said today that the move could damage peace negotiations in Central America and would be rejected by Congress.

headline: I.B.M. Computers
abstract: LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation said that two versions of its newest mid-range computers, the 9370, were being shipped two months earlier than planned. The machine, the smallest of I.B.M.'s System/370 family of mainframes, is considered a key element in the company's plan to regain its position in the mid-range computer market, where I.B.M.

headline: South Korea Proposes Talks With the North
abstract: LEAD: South Korea today proposed Cabinet-level talks with North Korea, and the United States expressed strong support for the move.

headline: IN QUOTES
abstract: LEAD: ''We're ready to go on the defensive on day one.'' - A. Robert Abboud, on his strategy at First City Bancorporation

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: LEAD: In percent          Tax-Exempt Bonds   8.32        Bond Buyer 20-Bond Index               Money Market Funds   6.41        Donoghue's Money Fund 7-Day Compound Yield               Bank Money Market Accounts   5.67        Bank Rate Monitor               Home Mortgage   10.28        Federal Home Loan Bank, national average               Unsecured Personal Loans        Minimum fixed rate, 3-year maturity        Chase Manhattan, New York   14.50        Continental Illinois, Chicago   14.00        Bank of America, San Francisco   18.25

headline: Contras Are Reported to Establish A Foothold in Central Nicaragua
abstract: LEAD: Guerrillas backed by the United States have established a foothold here in central Nicaragua, residents of the area say.

headline: Producer Prices Steady in August
abstract: LEAD: In an encouraging report on inflation, the Labor Department reported today that the Producer Price Index for finished goods held steady in August, with a continued drop in food costs helping to offset rising energy prices.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JULY 23, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  Companies

headline: Fixed-Rate Mortgages Up
abstract: LEAD: Interest rates for fixed-term mortgages rose last week to their highest level since 1985, the Federal Home Mortgage Corporation reported yesterday.

headline: 'BABY BELL' EXPANSIONS ARE VIEWED AS UNLIKELY
abstract: LEAD: The seven regional ''Baby Bell'' telephone companies have almost no chance of persuading Federal District Judge Harold H. Greene to allow them to expand vastly by providing long-distance service, and only a slim chance of winning permission to manufacture equipment, lawyers and other telecommuniciations specialists maintain.

headline: The Complex Interest Rules
abstract: LEAD: WHEN the Internal Revenue Service proposed new regulations governing interest deductions earlier this month, tax practitioners were shocked by their complexity, and taxpayers were left confused. Tax professionals are still struggling to absorb the new record-keeping and procedural rules, and they wonder if the average taxpayer will ever be able to understand them, let alone keep up with the burdensome requirements.

headline: Iraqis Are Facing a Growing War From Within
abstract: LEAD: Locked in conventional war with Iran, Iraq is facing another war from within, waged by Kurdish guerrillas in the north and by a shadowy underground movement drawn from its Shiite Moslem majority, diplomats here say.

headline: Blame Placed For Seabrook
abstract: LEAD: A consultant's report released today blames the lead owner of the Seabrook nuclear power plant for $333 million in unreasonable costs for the $4.9 billion project.

headline: Japan Rate Rise Is Called Likely
abstract: LEAD: Japan's long-term credit banks are likely to raise their long-term prime rate by three-tenths to four-tenths of a percentage point later this week from the current record low of 4.9 percent, bankers said today.

headline: Air Travelers Need 'Truth In Scheduling'
abstract: LEAD: THE flying public might still be confused about the causes of - and solutions to - the worsening rash of flight delays, baggage mix-ups, near-collisions in midair and other signs of a deteriorating aviation system in America.

headline: Home Loans By Credit Card
abstract: LEAD: WHEN Andrew Russell, a Louisville, Ky., attorney, took out a home equity loan last year, he found that he could get access to the money available to him by using a gold Mastercard. And he has since used the credit card to buy a number of items, including a car and equipment for his farm.

headline: Money Fund Assets Up
abstract: LEAD: Assets of the nation's 386 money market mutual funds increased $1.46 billion, to $237.61 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 96 institutional funds were up $516.8 million, to $65.06 billion. Assets of the 200 general-purpose funds were down $459.7 million, to $67.65 billion.

headline: Advertising; Perrier Assignment For Altschiller Reitzfeld
abstract: LEAD: The Perrier Group has assigned three of its regional bottled water brands to Altschiller Reitzfeld. Billings could reach $4 million, trade sources indicate.

headline: 5 Sentenced In Bevill Case
abstract: LEAD: A Federal judge today sentenced five former officers of Bevill, Bresler & Schulman Inc., a bankrupt securities firm, to prison terms on charges of securities fraud.

headline: Duarte Offers to Meet Rebels on Sept. 15 for Talks
abstract: LEAD: President Jose Napoleon Duarte offered today to meet leftist guerrillas in El Salvador on Sept. 15 for new peace talks, and he called on the Nicaraguan Government to open peace talks with its rebel opponents on the same day.

headline: World Bank Assailed
abstract: LEAD: A Reagan Administration official today criticized the sweeping reorganization of the World Bank as not tough enough. The official, who asked not to be identified, said that although a top-to-bottom reorganization of the 6,000-employee lending agency has caused widespread dissension and disruption in the bank, the 390 layoffs expected by the end of the year were ''peanuts.

headline: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS, INTEL IN CHIP ACCORD
abstract: LEAD: Texas Instruments Inc. and the Intel Corporation said today that they had agreed to cooperate in developing semi-customized computer chips, one of the fastest-growing segments of the semiconductor business.

headline: K Mart Board Elects Chief
abstract: LEAD: The K Mart Corporation said yesterday that its board, as expected, elected Joseph E. Antonini, president, to the additional posts of chairman and chief executive, effective Oct. 1. He will succeed Bernard M. Fauber, who has been chairman and chief executive for seven years. Mr. Fauber will retire after a 45-year career with K Mart.

headline: Zenith to Cut Staff
abstract: LEAD: The Zenith Electronics Corporation, struggling against a flood of lower-priced imports, said it would try to cut costs in its consumer products operations by offering early retirement to about 650 employees. A spokesman for Zenith said the consumer products unit would therefore report an operating loss in the third quarter.

headline: OIL MARKETS: UP, BUT UNEASY
abstract: LEAD: Driven by concerns that the war between Iran and Iraq could disrupt oil supplies from the Middle East, world crude oil prices have moved above $22 a barrel in volatile trading this week. However, energy experts in the United States said yesterday that the market's fears have exceeded the realistic prospects of a cutoff of crude oil supplies or even of a substantial reduction in Middle East shipments.

headline: THE PLIGHT OF FEMALE MINERS
abstract: LEAD: Cosby Totten, a coal miner laid off since 1982, does not easily hide her opinion of what has happened to Appalachia's struggling coal industry since Ronald Reagan has been President. ''I can't fault the old man too much,'' she said. ''I bought a brand new color TV when Carter was President, and Reagan gave me the time to watch it.

headline: Ambitious Tactic That Backfired
abstract: LEAD: During the oil boom of the early 1980's, the big ambition at the First City Bancorporation of Texas was to be the leading energy lender in the Southwest.

headline: Inflation 4.4% in Britain
abstract: LEAD: Britain's annual inflation rate remained steady at 4.4 percent in August, the Government said today. The annual inflation rate reflects the rise in the Government's retail price index, a measure of the costs of consumer goods, over the previous 12 months.

headline: Shevardnadze Speaks At the U.N.
abstract: LEAD: Following are excerpts from Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze's remarks on East-West relations in a speech to the General Assembly today, as translated by the Soviet Mission:

headline: U.S. KEEPS TAX STATUS ON ANTILLES
abstract: LEAD: The Treasury Department gave in yesterday to pressure from Americans who own bonds of corporate subsidiaries in the Netherlands Antilles, saying it would ask Congress to allow interest on the bonds to remain exempt from withholding taxes.

headline: Treasury to Set Details of Financing
abstract: LEAD: The Treasury is expected to announce this morning details of a delayed but indispensable August note and bond financing.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: BACKSTAGE VIEW EMERGES OF THE PRESIDENT'S MISSTATEMENT ON THE IRAN-CONTRA AFFAIR
abstract: LEAD: The testimony of Secretary of State George P. Shultz last week and documents offered as evidence in the Iran-contra hearings provide a backstage look at why President Reagan made misleading statements about the Iran arms sales soon after they were disclosed.

headline: PATENTS; Boy From Brooklyn Honored as Inventor
abstract: LEAD: Michael Oliveras, a Brooklyn elementary school student, and his teacher, Carole Teller, were honored at a ceremony in New York City this week. Michael, the inventor of a swivel headrest, is the national fifth-grade winner in the Invent America program of the United States Patent Model Foundation.

headline: Estimate of Business Outlays Is Cut
abstract: LEAD: Business investment spending, hurt by rising interest rates and the adverse effect of the new tax law, will probably be even weaker this year than previously believed.

headline: At U.N., Haiti Chief Reaffirms Plans for Democracy
abstract: LEAD: Two months before Haiti's first presidential elections in three decades are to be held, the country's military leader said here today that his Government had made great strides toward democracy.

headline: Poles Print a Poet's Lament on Insensitivity
abstract: LEAD: In a despairing 42-year-old letter that has just come to light, Czeslaw Milosz, the Nobel Prize poet, deplored what he saw as insensitivity in his fellow Poles.

headline: Dow Below 2,600 After Volatile Day
abstract: LEAD: The stock market continued its retreat and the Dow Jones industrial average closed below 2,600 after another volatile session in which individual stock prices seesawed wildly.

headline: Japanese Exporting to Japan
abstract: LEAD: Thanks to the lower value of the dollar against the yen, some Japanese companies are finding it profitable to export to Japan from plants in the United States.

headline: Mubarak Backed for 2d Term
abstract: LEAD: President Hosni Mubarak was nominated today by Parliament for a second six-year term, with only minor political parties opposing him. The main opposition grouping, led by the Moslem Brotherhood and the Labor Party, which is Socialist, supported Mr. Mubarak but urged him to govern Egypt under strict Islamic law.

headline: London Journal; American Football? Fans Often Are Not Amused
abstract: LEAD: It looked like a stroke of inspired typecasting -getting a comedy team known as the Vicious Boys to be hosts of a television program about American football that had become, in the eyes of the producer, ''too staid.''

headline: G.M. Sets 1.9% Loans, Rebates
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation, which had vowed to resist any more large-scale sales-incentive campaigns, announced its biggest incentives ever today, with interest rates on car loans as low as 1.9 percent and rebates of up to $1,000.

headline: Advertising; 3 Chiat/Day Executives Promoted to New Posts
abstract: LEAD: Chiat/Day Inc., in a move to strengthen management on both coasts, has named three executives to new posts. Bob Wolf, executive vice president and general manager of the New York office, has been appointed president and chief executive of the Los Angeles office. Fred Goldberg, executive vice president and chief operating officer of Chiat/Day Inc.

headline: Tensions Rising Over Draft Charter in Brazil
abstract: LEAD: Brazil's armed forces, in their most direct intervention in politics since civilian rule returned here 30 months ago, have strongly criticized the latest draft of a new constitution that is being prepared by a special assembly for a final vote later this year.

headline: BRITAIN TO PUNISH PAPER IN SPY CASE
abstract: LEAD: The British Government said today that it would prosecute a newspaper that published excerpts from the banned memoirs of a former counterintelligence agent.

headline: Market Place; New Strategies On New Issues
abstract: LEAD: IF the bull market keeps rolling along, selected companies going public for the first time are also likely to prosper, according to Standard & Poor's Outlook. ''New issues as a group,'' it said, ''tend to exaggerate the underlying trend of the overall market.''

headline: Colombia Chief Seeks a True Two-Party State
abstract: LEAD: Professorial in appearance, introspective in character, aloof in his political style and pro-American by conviction, President Virgilio Barco Vargas seems an unlikely revolutionary.

headline: Personal Use of Funds? 'I Never Took a Penny'
abstract: LEAD: In response to questions that have been raised about his use of money from the covert operation in support of the Nicaraguan rebels, Colonel North offered his account of the transactions.

headline: HUMANIZING BANK MACHINES
abstract: LEAD: In the decade since banks began deploying automatic teller machines in an effort to reduce their labor costs and shorten customer lines, the devices have become a familiar part of the landscape. But because a large percentage of the population appears to be reluctant to use the machines, A.T.M. designers are working to make them easier to operate and more useful.

headline: Disclosure By Hunts
abstract: LEAD: Two bankrupt companies controlled by the Hunt brothers filed a consolidated disclosure statement today in Federal bankruptcy court, completing the financial picture of the Hunts' major holdings.

headline: 20,000 WORKERS IN SOUTH KOREA RESUME STRIKE AGAINST HYUNDAI
abstract: LEAD: Nearly 20,000 shipyard workers walked off the job today at South Korea's biggest conglomerate, resuming a strike that had become an important symbol in the recent wave of labor unrest.

headline: Founder Plays Part In Latest UIS Deal
abstract: LEAD: UIS Inc., a private company with a taste for acquisitions, has quietly created a small industrial empire of 14 companies under the leadership of Harry Lebensfeld, its 83-year-old chairman and chief executive.

headline: British Jobless Rate Dips
abstract: LEAD: Britain's unemployment rate fell to a seasonally adjusted 10.2 percent in August, from 10.4 percent in July, the Department of Employment said today. The August figure was down from 11.6 percent in August 1986.

headline: Advertising; D'Arcy Masius Resigns MCI Communications
abstract: LEAD: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles announced yesterday that it had resigned the $40 million MCI Communications account because the two parties could not agree on advertising.

headline: The U.N. Today: Aug. 20, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  GENERAL ASSEMBLY

headline: New Philips Chip
abstract: LEAD: Philips N.V. said it had made its first one-megabit semiconductor, a submicron SRAM, or static random access memory, chip. The development came as part of a $1 billion joint project with Siemens A.G. of West Germany. Aanalysts said that major American and Japanese companies were still likely to sell their chips first and dominate the market.

headline: Dow Off 22.32; Stock Drop Is Wide
abstract: LEAD: The stock market retreated yesterday, losing the momentum that caused the Dow Jones industrial average on Friday to close above 2,500 for the first time.

headline: U.S. Study of Mexico Quake Cites Faults in Building Design
abstract: LEAD: Building design contributed to much of the damage in the 1985 Mexico City earthquake that killed more than 4,000 people, according to a new United States Government study.

headline: Progress Seen on Heart Drug
abstract: LEAD: Integrated Genetics Inc., a biotechnology company in Framingham, Mass., said yesterday that it had developed a longer-acting form of tissue plasminogen activator, a drug that might be used to treat heart attack victims.

headline: Intercontinental Hotels, In Split, Loses Leader
abstract: LEAD: The Intercontinental Hotels Corporation has accepted the resignation of its chief executive, Hans G. Sternik, and plans to appoint a successor in the next week or so.

headline: GULF MINES SIGHTED SOUTH OF AREA OF FRIDAY BLAST
abstract: LEAD: Merchant vessels in the Persian Gulf reported a new sighting of mines today, off the Saudi Arabian coast and south of the area where a Kuwaiti tanker flying the American flag and escorted by American warships struck a mine on Friday.

headline: West Germany Arrests 78 In Protest Over Hess's Death
abstract: LEAD: Right-wing extremists, some wearing clothing emblazoned with swastikas and others in Nazi uniforms unfurled Nazi banners and chanted ''Rudolf Hess!'' today in this Bavarian town, where the convicted war criminal, is to be buried next week.

headline: Kohl's Party Set Back in Vote
abstract: LEAD: Hurt by summer-long internal wrangling, economic problems and an 11th-hour campaign scandal, the Christian Democratic Union of Chancellor Helmut Kohl suffered heavy losses today in two state elections, the party's second serious setback in regional polling this year.

headline: Chrysler Profit, Off 12%, Tops Wall St. Forecasts
abstract: LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation today reported second-quarter earnings of $428.7 million, or $2 a share, exceeding Wall Street's expectations.

headline: No. 2 in the Philippines Quits Cabinet Position
abstract: LEAD: Vice President Salvador H. Laurel broke politically with President Corazon C. Aquino today, saying his resignation as Foreign Secretary, tendered last week, was final.

headline: Market Place; Interstate Tops Bakery Stocks
abstract: LEAD: BAKING bread and cakes may sound like a pretty dull business, but shares of the major publicly traded producers of baked goods sold last week at or near record prices.

headline: CONSUMERS CUT DEBTS BY $560 MILLION IN MAY
abstract: LEAD: Americans paid off $560 million more in debt than they borrowed during May, the first reduction in consumer credit in nearly five years, the Federal Reserve reported today.

headline: North, Minus His Slides, Makes Cause for Contras
abstract: LEAD: The issue that has simmered just beneath the surface throughout the Iran-contra hearings -aid to the contras - broke into full public view today in a dispute over a slide show that was to be given by Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North. Congress has been split almost evenly on the contra subject for years, and today the fight was resolved with a compromise.

headline: Talks About Sri Lanka Held in Southern India
abstract: LEAD: Indian officials held talks in the southern Indian city of Madras today with Tamil leaders on new proposals to resolve the ethnic conflict in Sri Lanka, Indian and Sri Lankan officials said.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JULY 25, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  The Economy

headline: Financier Is Returning To Leveraged Buyouts
abstract: LEAD: Neil R. Austrian, a financier who in the last decade has done some dabbling in advertising and show business, is back where he began his career: on Wall Street, doing leveraged buyouts.

headline: Saudi King Vows Strong Defense of Homeland and Holy Sites
abstract: LEAD: King Fahd, in his first public comment on the riots last week in which hundreds died, vowed today to defend Islam's holy places.

headline: SIGN OF TIMES AT TAJ MAHAL: BARBWIRE
abstract: LEAD: The Taj Mahal, the classic monument to personal grief and architectural splendor, has become a barometer of India's smoldering ethnic vendettas.
